found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3892/etm.2013.1338","date":"2013-09-27","title":"Melatonin reduces bacterial translocation by preventing damage to the intestinal mucosa in an experimental severe acute pancreatitis rat model","abstract":"Recent studies have demonstrated that melatonin significantly decreased all studied acute pancreatitis-associated inflammatory parameters, in addition to reducing apoptosis and necrosis associated with pancreatic injury.\n However, the effect of melatonin on gut barrier dysfunction and bacterial translocation has not been fully elucidated.\n This study aimed to investigate the protective effects of melatonin on intestinal integrity in a rat model of severe acute pancreatitis (SAP) to evaluate whether melatonin prevented intestine barrier dysfunction and reduced bacterial translocation.\n Forty male Sprague Dawley (SD) rats were randomly divided into three groups, with 8 rats in the sham operation (SO) group, 18 rats in the SAP group and 14 SAP rats in the melatonin treatment (MT) group.\n SAP was induced by retrograde injection of 4% taurocholate into the biliopancreatic duct.\n Melatonin was administered 30 min prior to taurocholate injection in the melatonin-treated rats.\n All rats were sacrificed 24 h subsequent to pancreatitis induction.\n Real-time fluorescence quantitative polymerase chain reaction was used to detect and quantify Escherichia coli (E.\n coli) O157 in postcava blood.\n The microvilli structure was also analyzed with transmission electron microscopy.\n The level of E.\n coli DNA in the MT group was significantly lower than in rats in the SAP group.\n No E.\n coli DNA was detected in the control group.\n Villus height and crypt depth in the ileum were significantly higher in the MT and control groups compared to the SAP group, and were significantly higher in the MT group than in the SAP group.\n These results suggested that melatonin prevented gut barrier dysfunction and reduced bacterial translocation, resulting in reduced pancreatic-associated infections and decreased early mortality rates.\n","id":"PMC3829749","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"XUECHENG","surname":"SUN","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"YINGYING","surname":"SHAO","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"YIN","surname":"JIN","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"JIAPING","surname":"HUAI","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"QIONG","surname":"ZHOU","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"ZHIMING","surname":"HUANG","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"JIANSHENG","surname":"WU","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1093/toxsci/kfr205","date":"1970-01-01","title":"2,3,7,8-Tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin Colorectal Cancer Susceptibility","abstract":"It is well established that the intestinal microbiota plays a key role in the pathogenesis of Crohn's disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC) collectively referred to as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).\n Epidemiological studies have provided strong evidence that IBD patients bear increased risk for the development of colorectal cancer (CRC).\n However, the impact of the microbiota on the development of colitis-associated cancer (CAC) remains largely unknown.\n In this study, we established a new model of CAC using azoxymethane (AOM)-exposed, conventionalized-Il10?/? mice and have explored the contribution of the host intestinal microbiota and MyD88 signaling to the development of CAC.\n We show that 8/13 (62%) of AOM-Il10?/? mice developed colon tumors compared to only 3/15 (20%) of AOM- wild-type (WT) mice.\n Conventionalized AOM-Il10?/? mice developed spontaneous colitis and colorectal carcinomas while AOM-WT mice were colitis-free and developed only rare adenomas.\n Importantly, tumor multiplicity directly correlated with the presence of colitis.\n Il10?/? mice mono-associated with the mildly colitogenic bacterium Bacteroides vulgatus displayed significantly reduced colitis and colorectal tumor multiplicity compared to Il10?/? mice.\n Germ-free AOM-treated Il10?/? mice showed normal colon histology and were devoid of tumors.\n Il10?/?; Myd88?/? mice treated with AOM displayed reduced expression of Il12p40 and Tnf? mRNA and showed no signs of tumor development.\n We present the first direct demonstration that manipulation of the intestinal microbiota alters the development of CAC.\n The TLR/MyD88 pathway is essential for microbiota-induced development of CAC.\n Unlike findings obtained using the AOM/DSS model, we demonstrate that the severity of chronic colitis directly correlates to colorectal tumor development and that bacterial-induced inflammation drives progression from adenoma to invasive carcinoma.\n","id":"PMC2696084","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Joshua Mucosa-Associated Microbiota Determine Physiological Expression of TLR2 and TLR4 in Murine Colon","abstract":"Many colonic mucosal genes that are highly regulated by microbial signals are differentially expressed along the rostral-caudal axis.\n This would suggest that differences in regional microbiota exist, particularly mucosa-associated microbes that are less likely to be transient.\n We therefore explored this possibility by examining the bacterial populations associated with the normal proximal and distal colonic mucosa in context of host Toll-like receptors (TLR) expression in C57BL/6J mice housed in specific pathogen-free (SPF) and germ-free (GF) environments.\n 16S rRNA gene-based terminal restriction fragment length polymorphism (T-RFLP) and clone library analysis revealed significant differences in the community structure and diversity of the mucosa-associated microbiota located in the distal colon compared to proximal colon and stool, the latter two clustering closely.\n Differential expression of colonic TLR2 and TLR4 along the proximal-distal axis was also found in SPF mice, but not in GF mice, suggesting that enteric microbes are essential in maintaining the regional expression of these TLRs.\n TLR2 is more highly expressed in proximal colon and decreases in a gradient to distal while TLR4 expression is highest in distal colon and a gradient of decreased expression to proximal colon is observed.\n After transfaunation in GF mice, both regional colonization of mucosa-associated microbes and expression of TLRs in the mouse colon were reestablished.\n In addition, exposure of the distal colon to cecal (proximal) microbiota induced TLR2 expression.\n These results demonstrate that regional colonic mucosa-associated microbiota determine the region-specific expression of TLR2 and TLR4. Conversely, region-specific host assembly rules are essential in determining the structure and function of mucosa-associated microbial populations.\n We believe this type of host-microbial mutualism is pivotal to the maintenance of intestinal and immune years with BMI 18.5–25 kg/m2 were recruited from central North Carolina between July 2014 and March 2015. Participants provided a single fecal sample and completed an online psychiatric questionnaire that included five measures: (i) Beck Anxiety Inventory; (ii) Beck Depression Inventory-II; (iii) Eating Disorder Examination-Questionnaire; (iv) Perceived Stress Scale; and (v) Mini International Personality Item Pool.\n\n Bacterial composition and diversity were characterized by Illumina sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene, and associations were examined using Kendall’s tau-b correlation coefficient, in conjunction with Benjamini and Hochberg’s False Discovery Rate procedure.\n\n\nResults\nWe found no significant associations between microbial markers of gut composition and diversity and scores on psychiatric measures of anxiety, depression, eating-related thoughts and behaviors, stress, or personality in a large cohort of healthy adult females.\n\n\nDiscussion\nThis study was the first specifically to examine associations between the intestinal microbiota and psychiatric measures in healthy females, and based on 16S rRNA taxonomic abundances and diversity measures, our results do not suggest a strong role for the enteric microbe-gut-brain axis in normal variation on responses to psychiatric measures in this population.\n\n However, the role of the intestinal microbiota in the pathophysiology of psychiatric illness may be limited to more severe psychopathology.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5245801","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Susan C.","surname":"Kleiman","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Emily C.","surname":"Bulik-Sullivan","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Elaine M.","surname":"Glenny","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Stephanie C.","surname":"Zerwas","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Eun Young","surname":"Huh","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Matthew C. Use in Pregnancy","abstract":"During pregnancy, tryptophan (Trp) is required for several purposes, and Trp metabolism varies over time in the mother and fetus.\n Increased oxidative stress (OS) with high metabolic, energy and oxygen demands during normal pregnancy or in pregnancy-associated disorders has been reported.\n Taking the antioxidant properties of Trp and its metabolites into consideration, we made four hypotheses.\n First, the use of Trp and its metabolites is optional based on their antioxidant properties during pregnancy.\n Second, dynamic Trp metabolism is an accommodation mechanism in response to OS.\n Third, regulation of Trp metabolism could be used to control/attenuate OS according to variations in Trp metabolism during pregnancy.\n Fourth, OS-mediated injury could be alleviated by regulation of Trp metabolism in pregnancy-associated disorders.\n Future studies in normal/abnormal pregnancies and in associated disorders should include measurements of free Trp, total Trp, Trp metabolites, and activities of Trp-degrading enzymes in plasma.\n Abnormal pregnancies and some associated disorders may be associated with disordered Trp metabolism related to OS.\n Mounting evidence suggests that the investigation of the use of Trp and its metabolites in pregnancy will be found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0039743","date":"2012-05-25","title":"Human Intestinal Lumen and Mucosa-Associated Microbiota in Patients with Colorectal Cancer","abstract":"Recent reports have suggested the involvement of gut microbiota in the progression of colorectal cancer (CRC).\n We utilized pyrosequencing based analysis of 16S rRNA genes to determine the overall structure of microbiota in patients with colorectal cancer and healthy controls; we investigated microbiota of the intestinal lumen, the cancerous tissue and matched noncancerous normal tissue.\n Moreover, we investigated the mucosa-adherent microbial composition using rectal swab samples because the structure of the tissue-adherent bacterial community is potentially altered following bowel cleansing.\n Our findings indicated that the microbial structure of the intestinal lumen and cancerous tissue differed significantly.\n Phylotypes that enhance energy harvest from diets or perform metabolic exchange with the host were more abundant in the lumen.\n There were more abundant Firmicutes and less abundant Bacteroidetes and Proteobacteria in lumen.\n The overall microbial structures of cancerous tissue and noncancerous tissue were similar; howerer the tumor microbiota exhibited lower diversity.\n The structures of the intestinal lumen microbiota and mucosa-adherent microbiota were different in CRC patients compared to matched microbiota in healthy individuals.\n Lactobacillales was enriched in cancerous tissue, whereas Faecalibacterium was reduced.\n In the mucosa-adherent microbiota, Bifidobacterium, Faecalibacterium, and Blautia were reduced in CRC patients, whereas Fusobacterium, Porphyromonas, Peptostreptococcus, and Mogibacterium were enriched.\n In the lumen, predominant phylotypes related to metabolic disorders or metabolic exchange with the host, Erysipelotrichaceae, Prevotellaceae, and Coriobacteriaceae were increased in cancer patients.\n Coupled with previous reports, these results suggest that the intestinal microbiota is associated with CRC risk and that intestinal lumen microflora potentially influence CRC risk via cometabolism or metabolic exchange with the host.\n However, mucosa-associated microbiota potentially affects CRC risk primarily through direct interaction with the host.\n","id":"PMC3386193","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Weiguang","surname":"Chen","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Fanlong","surname":"Liu","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Zongxin","surname":"Ling","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xiaojuan","surname":"Tong","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Charlie","surname":"Xiang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Antonio","surname":"Moschetta","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Antonio","surname":"Moschetta","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0041594","date":"2012-06-22","title":"Inflammation Drives Dysbiosis and Bacterial Invasion in Murine Models of Ileal Crohn’s Disease","abstract":"Background and Aims\nUnderstanding the interplay between genetic susceptibility, the microbiome, the environment and the immune system in Crohn’s Disease (CD) is essential for developing optimal therapeutic strategies.\n\n We sought to examine the dynamics of the relationship between inflammation, the ileal microbiome, and host genetics in murine models of ileitis.\n\n\nMethods\nWe induced ileal inflammation of graded severity in C57BL6 mice by gavage with Toxoplasma gondii, Giardia muris, low dose indomethacin (LDI;0.1 mg/mouse), or high dose indomethacin (HDI;1 mg/mouse).\n\n The composition and spatial distribution of the mucosal microbiome was evaluated by 16S rDNA pyrosequencing and fluorescence in situ hybridization.\n\n Mucosal E.\n\n coli were enumerated by quantitative PCR, and characterized by phylogroup, genotype and pathotype.\n\n\nResults\nModerate to severe ileitis induced by T.\n\n gondii (day 8) and HDI caused a consistent shift from &gt;95% Gram + Firmicutes to &gt;95% Gram - Proteobacteria.\n\n This was accompanied by reduced microbial diversity and mucosal invasion by adherent and invasive E.\n\n coli, mirroring the dysbiosis of ileal CD.\n\n In contrast, dysbiosis and bacterial invasion did not develop in mice with mild ileitis induced by Giardia muris.\n\n Superimposition of genetic susceptibility and T.\n\n Gondii infection revealed greatest dysbiosis and bacterial invasion in the CD-susceptible genotype, NOD2?/?, and reduced dysbiosis in ileitis-resistant CCR2?/? mice.\n\n Abrogating inflammation with the CD therapeutic anti-TNF-?-mAb tempered dysbiosis and bacterial invasion.\n\n\nConclusions\nAcute ileitis induces dysbiosis and proliferation of mucosally invasive E.\n\n coli, irrespective of trigger and genotype.\n\n The identification of CCR2 as a target for therapeutic intervention, and discovery that host genotype and therapeutic blockade of inflammation impact the threshold and extent of ileal dysbiosis are of high relevance to developing effective therapies for CD.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3404971","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Melanie","surname":"Craven","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Charlotte M.","surname":"Heimesaat","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/1471-230X-13-131","date":"2013-08-06","title":"Association of gut microbiota with post-operative clinical course in Crohn’s disease","abstract":"Background\nThe gut microbiome is altered in Crohn’s disease.\n\n Although individual taxa have been correlated with post-operative clinical course, global trends in microbial diversity have not been described in this context.\n\n\nMethods\nWe collected mucosal biopsies from the terminal ileum and ascending colon during surgery and post-operative colonoscopy in 6 Crohn’s patients undergoing ileocolic resection (and 40 additional Crohn’s and healthy control patients undergoing either surgery or colonoscopy).\n\n Using next-generation sequencing technology, we profiled the gut microbiota in order to identify changes associated with remission or recurrence of inflammation.\n\n\nResults\nWe performed 16S ribosomal profiling using 101 base-pair single-end sequencing on the Illumina GAIIx platform with deep coverage, at an average depth of 1.3 million high quality reads per sample.\n\n At the time of surgery, Crohn’s patients who would remain in remission were more similar to controls and more species-rich than Crohn’s patients with subsequent recurrence.\n\n Patients remaining in remission also exhibited greater stability of the microbiota through time.\n\n\nConclusions\nThese observations permitted an association of gut microbial profiles with probability of recurrence in this limited single-center study.\n\n These results suggest that profiling the gut microbiota may be useful in guiding treatment of Crohn’s patients undergoing surgery.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3848607","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Neelendu","surname":"Dey","email":"dey@post.harvard.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"David Microbiome Changes in a Mouse Model of Parenteral Nutrition Associated Liver Injury and Intestinal Inflammation","abstract":"Background\nParenteral nutrition (PN) has been a life-saving treatment in infants intolerant of enteral feedings.\n\n However, PN is associated with liver injury (PN Associated Liver Injury: PNALI) in a significant number of PN-dependent infants.\n\n We have previously reported a novel PNALI mouse model in which PN infusion combined with intestinal injury results in liver injury.\n\n In this model, lipopolysaccharide activation of toll-like receptor 4 signaling, soy oil-derived plant sterols, and pro-inflammatory activation of Kupffer cells (KCs) played key roles.\n\n The objective of this study was to explore changes in the intestinal microbiome associated with PNALI.\n\n\nMethodology and Principal Findings\nMicrobiome analysis in the PNALI mouse identified specific alterations within colonic microbiota associated with PNALI and further association of these communities with the lipid composition of the PN solution.\n\n Intestinal inflammation or soy oil-based PN infusion alone (in the absence of enteral feeds) caused shifts within the gut microbiota.\n\n However, the combination resulted in accumulation of a specific taxon, Erysipelotrichaceae (23.8% vs.\n\n 1.7% in saline infused controls), in PNALI mice.\n\n Moreover, PNALI was markedly attenuated by enteral antibiotic treatment, which also was associated with significant reduction of Erysipelotrichaceae (0.6%) and a Gram-negative constituent, the S24-7 lineage of Bacteroidetes (53.5% in PNALI vs.\n\n 0.8%).\n\n Importantly, removal of soy oil based-lipid emulsion from the PN solution resulted in significant reduction of Erysipelotrichaceae as well as attenuation of PNALI.\n\n Finally, addition of soy-derived plant sterol (stigmasterol) to fish oil-based PN restored Erysipelotrichaceae abundance and PNALI.\n\n\nConclusions\nSoy oil-derived plant sterols and the associated specific bacterial groups in the colonic microbiota are associated with PNALI.\n\n Products from these bacteria may directly trigger activation of KCs and promote PNALI.\n\n Furthermore, the results indicate that lipid modification of PN solutions may alter specific intestinal bacterial species associated with PNALI, and thus suggest strategies for management of PNALI.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4203793","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"J. found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1038/ctg.2014.21","date":"2014-11-22","title":"Effect of Exclusive Enteral Nutrition on the Microbiota of Children With Newly Diagnosed Crohn's Disease","abstract":"Objectives:\nExclusive enteral nutrition (EEN) is commonly used to treat pediatric Crohn's disease (CD).\n\n Meta-analysis of pediatric studies that have compared the effect of EEN with other treatments have shown that EEN induces remission in up to 80–85% of patients.\n\n We aimed to gain a comprehensive understanding of the effect of EEN on the microbiota of CD patients.\n\n\nMethods:\nWe used 16S rRNA gene and whole-genome high throughout sequencing to determine changes in the fecal microbiota of five CD children, before, during, and after EEN therapy and compared this with five healthy controls.\n\n\nResults:\nThe microbial diversity observed in CD patients tended to be lower than that in controls (CD: 2.25±0.24, controls: 2.75±0.14, P=0.11).\n\n In all CD patients, dysbiosis was observed prior to therapy.\n\n EEN therapy had a positive effect in all patients, with 80% going into remission.\n\n In some patients, the positive effect diminished following the conclusion of EEN therapy.\n\n Significantly, the number of operational taxonomic units (OTU) decreased dramatically upon starting EEN and this corresponded with CD remission.\n\n Recurrence of CD corresponded with an increase in OTUs.\n\n Six families within the Firmicutes were found to correlate with disease activity during and following EEN therapy, a finding that was confirmed by whole-genome high throughput sequencing.\n\n\nConclusions:\nOur results demonstrate that EEN leads to common and patient-specific alterations in the microbiota of CD patients, a number of which correlate with disease activity.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4418409","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Nadeem fewer occurrences, human erysipeloid.\n\n It is ubiquitous in nature and commensal in diverse species of animals, wild or domestic, from mammals and birds to reptiles and fish.\n\n Mechanisms of its virulence and pathogenicity are poorly understood.\n\n\nResults\nMaking use of the complete genome sequencing of E.\n\n rhusiopathiae strain SY1027 and comparative genome analysis between the three highly pathogenic strains (SY1027, Fujisawa and ATCC19414), the genomic structure and putative functional elements, such as pathogenicity island (PAI)-like regions, potential virulence factors and horizontal transferring genes of the bacteria are identified.\n\n Strain SY1027 genome is 1,752,910 base pairs long, just 30 kilobases smaller than strain Fujisawa, with the same GC level of 36.36%.\n\n It contains 1,845 open reading frames (ORF) predicted by GLIMMER 3.02, of which 1,775 were annotated by PGAAP, 1,757 (~95.23%) were annotated by NCBI nr blast, 1,209 by COG database and 1,076 by KEGG database.\n\n 37 potential virulence factors were annotated in strain SY1027 by VFDB, while 19 (~51.35%) of them are common in the 2 strains, 7 of which are potentially related to antibiotic resistance and highly conserved (~98-100% match identity (ID)) amongst the three strains of E.\n\n rhusiopathiae and modestly homologous to other gastrointestinal tract-inhabiting Firmicutes (~40% match ID), e.\n\ng.\n\n Clostridium spp.\n\n, Enterococcus spp.\n\n Genomic island- and pathogenicity island-like regions were also predicted, in which some showed association with tRNA and potential virulence factors.\n\n\nConclusion\nComplete genome sequencing of Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae, the causative agent of animal erysipelas, was performed.\n\n Molecular identification of various genomic elements pave the way to the better understanding of mechanisms underlying metabolic capabilities, pathogenicity of swine erysipelas and prospective vaccine targets besides the Ulcerative Colitis and Type 2 Diabetes Metagenomes","abstract":"We performed an analysis to determine the importance of bile acid modification genes in the gut microbiome of inflammatory bowel disease and type 2 diabetic patients.\n We used publicly available metagenomic datasets from the Human Microbiome Project and the MetaHIT consortium, and determined the abundance of bile salt hydrolase gene (bsh), 7 alpha-dehydroxylase gene (adh) and 7-alpha hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase gene (hsdh) in fecal bacteria in diseased populations of Crohn's disease (CD), Ulcerative Colitis (UC) and Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).\n Phylum level abundance analysis showed a significant reduction in Firmicute-derived bsh in UC and T2DM patients but not in CD patients, relative to healthy controls.\n Reduction of adh and hsdh genes was also seen in UC and T2DM patients, while an increase was observed in the CD population as compared to healthy controls.\n A further analysis of the bsh genes showed significant differences in the correlations of certain Firmicutes families with disease or healthy populations.\n From this observation we proceeded to analyse BSH protein sequences and identified BSH proteins clusters representing the most abundant strains in our analysis of Firmicute bsh genes.\n The abundance of the bsh genes corresponding to one of these protein clusters was significantly reduced in all disease states relative to healthy controls.\n This cluster includes bsh genes derived from Lachospiraceae, Clostridiaceae, Erysipelotrichaceae and Ruminococcaceae families.\n This metagenomic analysis provides evidence of the importance of bile acid modifying enzymes in health and disease.\n It further highlights the importance of identifying gene and protein clusters, as the same gene may be associated with health or disease, depending on the strains expressing the enzyme, and differences in the enzymes S.","surname":"Day","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1242/dmm.017400","date":"1970-01-01","title":"How informative is the mouse for human gut microbiota research?","abstract":"The microbiota of the human gut is gaining broad attention owing to its association with a wide range of diseases, ranging from metabolic disorders (e.\ng.\n obesity and type 2 diabetes) to autoimmune diseases (such as inflammatory bowel disease and type 1 diabetes), cancer and even neurodevelopmental disorders (e.\ng.\n autism).\n Having been increasingly used in biomedical research, mice have become the model of choice for most studies in this emerging field.\n Mouse models allow perturbations in gut microbiota to be studied in a controlled experimental setup, and thus help in assessing causality of the complex host-microbiota interactions and in developing mechanistic hypotheses.\n However, pitfalls should be considered when translating gut microbiome research results from mouse models to humans.\n In this Special Article, we discuss the intrinsic similarities and differences that exist between the two systems, and compare the human and murine core gut microbiota based on a meta-analysis of currently available datasets.\n Finally, we discuss the external factors that influence the capability of mouse models to recapitulate the gut microbiota shifts associated with human diseases, and investigate which alternative model systems exist for gut microbiota research.\n","id":"PMC4283646","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Thi Loan ileitis independent of failure in antimicrobial defence","abstract":"Objectives\nDysbiosis of the intestinal microbiota is associated with Crohn's disease (CD).\n\n Functional evidence for a causal role of bacteria in the development of chronic small intestinal inflammation is lacking.\n\n Similar to human pathology, TNFdeltaARE mice develop a tumour necrosis factor (TNF)-driven CD-like transmural inflammation with predominant ileal involvement.\n\n\nDesign\nHeterozygous TNFdeltaARE mice and wildtype (WT) littermates were housed under conventional (CONV), specific pathogen-free (SPF) and germ-free (GF) conditions.\n\n Microbial communities were analysed by high-throughput 16S ribosomal RNA gene sequencing.\n\n Metaproteomes were measured using LC-MS.\n\n Temporal and spatial resolution of disease development was followed after antibiotic treatment and transfer of microbial communities into GF mice.\n\n Granulocyte infiltration and Paneth cell function was assessed by immunofluorescence and gene expression analysis.\n\n\nResults\nGF-TNFdeltaARE mice were free of inflammation in the gut and antibiotic treatment of CONV-TNFdeltaARE mice attenuated ileitis but not colitis, demonstrating that disease severity and location are microbiota-dependent.\n\n SPF-TNFdeltaARE mice developed distinct ileitis-phenotypes associated with gradual loss of antimicrobial defence.\n\n 16S analysis and metaproteomics revealed specific compositional and functional alterations of bacterial communities in inflamed mice.\n\n Transplantation of disease-associated but not healthy microbiota transmitted CD-like ileitis to GF-TNFdeltaARE recipients and triggered loss of lysozyme and cryptdin-2 expression.\n\n Monoassociation of GF-TNFdeltaARE mice with the human CD-related Escherichia coli LF82 did not induce ileitis.\n\n\nConclusions\nWe provide clear experimental evidence for the causal role of gut bacterial dysbiosis in the development of chronic ileal inflammation with subsequent failure of Paneth cell found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0090849","date":"2014-01-30","title":"Analysis of the Intestinal Lumen Microbiota in an Animal Model of Colorectal Cancer","abstract":"Recent reports have suggested that multiple factors such as host genetics, environment and diet can promote the progression of healthy mucosa towards sporadic colorectal carcinoma.\n Accumulating evidence has additionally associated intestinal bacteria with disease initiation and progression.\n In order to examine and analyze the composition of gut microbiota in the absence of confounding influences, we have established an animal model of 1, 2-dimethylhydrazine (DMH)-induced colon cancer.\n Using this model, we have performed pyrosequencing of the V3 region of the 16S rRNA genes in this study to determine the diversity and breadth of the intestinal microbial species.\n Our findings indicate that the microbial composition of the intestinal lumen differs significantly between control and tumor groups.\n The abundance of Firmicutes was elevated whereas the abundance of Bacteroidetes and Spirochetes was reduced in the lumen of CRC rats.\n Fusobacteria was not detected in any of the healthy rats and there was no significant difference in observed Proteobacteria species when comparing the bacterial communities between our two groups.\n Interestingly, the abundance of Proteobacteria was higher in CRC rats.\n At the genus level, Bacteroides exhibited a relatively higher abundance in CRC rats compared to controls (14.92% vs.\n 9.22%, p&lt;0.001).\n Meanwhile, Prevotella (55.22% vs.\n 26.19%), Lactobacillus (3.71% vs.\n 2.32%) and Treponema (3.04% vs.\n 2.43%), were found to be significantly more abundant in healthy rats than CRC rats (p&lt;0.001, respectively).\n We also demonstrate a significant reduction of butyrate-producing bacteria such as Roseburia and Eubacterium in the gut microbiota of CRC rats.\n Furthermore, a significant increase in Desulfovibrio, Erysipelotrichaceae and Fusobacterium was also observed in the tumor group.\n A decrease in probiotic species such as Ruminococcus and Lactobacillus was likewise observed in the tumor group.\n Collectively, we can conclude that a significant difference in intestinal bacterial flora exists between healthy rats and CRC been associated with influenza in children, including abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.\n\n\nMethods\nFrom September 2005 and April 2008, pediatric patients in Indonesia presenting with concurrent diarrhea and influenza-like illness were enrolled in a study to determine the frequency of influenza virus infection in young patients presenting with symptoms less commonly associated with an upper respiratory tract infection (URTI).\n\n Stool specimens and upper respiratory swabs were assayed for the presence of influenza virus.\n\n\nResults\nSeasonal influenza A or influenza B viral RNA was detected in 85 (11.6%) upper respiratory specimens and 21 (2.9%) of stool specimens.\n\n Viable influenza B virus was isolated from the stool specimen of one case.\n\n During the time of this study, human infections with highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N1) virus were common in the survey area.\n\n However, among 733 enrolled subjects, none had evidence of H5N1 virus infection.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe detection of influenza viral RNA and viable influenza virus from stool suggests that influenza virus may be localized in the gastrointestinal tract of children, may be investigated here whether CCL25/CCR9 interactions also play a role in the regulation of inflammatory responses in the large intestine.\n\n\nMethods\nAcute inflammation and recovery in wild-type (WT) and CCR9?/? mice was studied in a model of dextran sulfate sodium (DSS)-induced colitis.\n\n Distribution studies and phenotypic characterization of dendritic cell subsets and macrophage were performed by flow cytometry.\n\n Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) scores were assessed and expression of inflammatory cytokines was studied at the mRNA and the protein level.\n\n\nResults\nCCL25 and CCR9 are both expressed in the large intestine and are upregulated during DSS colitis.\n\n CCR9?/? mice are more susceptible to DSS colitis than WT littermate controls as shown by higher mortality, increased IBD score and delayed recovery.\n\n During recovery, the CCR9?/? colonic mucosa is characterized by the accumulation of activated macrophages and elevated levels of Th1/Th17 inflammatory cytokines.\n\n Activated plasmacytoid dendritic cells (DCs) accumulate in mesenteric lymph nodes (MLNs) of CCR9?/? animals, altering the local ratio of DC subsets.\n\n Upon re-stimulation, T cells isolated from these MLNs secrete significantly higher levels of TNF?, IFN?, IL2, IL-6 and IL-17A while down modulating IL-10 production.\n\n\nConclusions\nOur results demonstrate that CCL25/CCR9 interactions regulate inflammatory immune responses in the large intestinal mucosa by balancing different subsets of dendritic cells.\n\n These findings have important implications for the use of CCR9-inhibitors in therapy of human IBD as they indicate a potential risk for patients with large intestinal core gut microbiome in obese and lean twins","abstract":"id='P1'>The human distal gut harbors a vast ensemble of microbes (the microbiota) that provide us with important metabolic capabilities, including the ability to extract energy from otherwise indigestible dietary polysaccharides1–6.\n Studies of a small number of unrelated, healthy adults have revealed substantial diversity in their gut communities, as measured by sequencing 16S rRNA genes6–8, yet how this diversity relates to function and to the rest of the genes in the collective genomes of the microbiota (the gut microbiome) remains obscure.\n Studies of lean and obese mice suggest that the gut microbiota affects energy balance by influencing the efficiency of calorie harvest from the diet, and how this harvested energy is utilized and stored3–5.\n To address the question of how host genotype, environmental exposures, and host adiposity influence the gut microbiome, we have characterized the fecal microbial communities of adult female monozygotic and dizygotic twin pairs concordant for leanness or obesity, and their mothers.\n Analysis of 154 individuals yielded 9,920 near full-length and 1,937,461 partial bacterial 16S rRNA sequences, plus 2.14 gigabases from their microbiomes.\n The results reveal that the human gut microbiome is shared among family members, but that each person’s gut microbial community varies in the specific bacterial lineages present, with a comparable degree of co-variation between adult monozygotic and dizygotic twin pairs.\n However, there was a wide array of shared microbial genes among sampled individuals, comprising an extensive, identifiable ‘core microbiome’ at the gene, rather than at the organismal lineage level.\n Obesity is associated with phylum-level changes in the microbiota, reduced bacterial diversity, and altered representation of bacterial genes and metabolic pathways.\n These results demonstrate that a diversity of organismal assemblages can nonetheless yield a core microbiome at a functional level, and that deviations from this core are associated with different physiologic states (obese versus lean).\n","id":"PMC2677729","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Peter microbiome in shaping health and disease","abstract":"More than 300 years after Antonie van Leeuwenhoek gave the first description of microbes that colonize human body surfaces, the re-discovery of this multifaceted microbial world within our bodies has challenged our principal view on microbes.\n Novel sequencing techniques provide a plethora of (meta)genomic data, which elucidate the unique properties of mircobiota in different subjects.\n Moreover, the variety of metabolic and immunologic interactions between the mircobiota and the host's epithelial surfaces has challenged the paradigm of a unidirectional interplay between a given pathogen and the host's immune defense.\n The newly discovered mechanisms that underlie the symbiosis between the host, specific colonizers, and the mircobiota as a whole indicate that this colonization is more than a friendly coexistence.\n In fact, it represents a complex ecosystem with implications for the human metabolic homeostasis and immune tolerance.\n The resilience of the mircobiota and the capability to maintain a well-established equilibrium between symbionts and potential pathogens seem to be determining factors in shaping health or disease.\n","id":"PMC3914505","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Petra reported in adults, gastrointestinal symptoms have been associated with influenza in children, including abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.\n\n\nMethods\nFrom September 2005 and April 2008, pediatric patients in Indonesia presenting with concurrent diarrhea and influenza-like illness were enrolled in a study to determine the frequency of influenza virus infection in young patients presenting with symptoms less commonly associated with an upper respiratory tract infection (URTI).\n\n Stool specimens and upper respiratory swabs were assayed for the presence of influenza virus.\n\n\nResults\nSeasonal influenza A or influenza B viral RNA was detected in 85 (11.6%) upper respiratory specimens and 21 (2.9%) of stool specimens.\n\n Viable influenza B virus was isolated enrolled subjects, none had evidence of H5N1 virus infection.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe detection of influenza viral RNA and viable influenza virus from stool suggests that influenza virus may be Type II Cell Differentiation after Severe Lung Injury","abstract":"Regeneration of alveolar epithelia following severe pulmonary damage is critical for lung function.\n We and others have previously shown that Scgb1a1-expressing cells, most likely Clara cells, can give rise to newly generated alveolar type 2 cells (AT2s) in response to severe lung damage induced by either influenza virus infection or bleomycin treatment.\n In this study, we have investigated cellular pathway underlying the Clara cell to AT2 differentiation.\n We show that the initial intermediates are bronchiolar epithelial cells that exhibit Clara cell morphology and express Clara cell marker, Scgb1a1, as well as the AT2 cell marker, pro-surfactant protein C (pro-SPC).\n These cells, referred to as pro-SPC+ bronchiolar epithelial cells (or SBECs), gradually lose Scgb1a1 expression and give rise to pro-SPC+ cells in the ring structures in the damaged parenchyma, which appear to differentiate into AT2s via a process sharing some features with that observed during alveolar epithelial development in the embryonic lung.\n These findings suggest that SBECs are intermediates of Clara cell to AT2 differentiation during the repair of alveolar epithelia following severe pulmonary using its virulence factors to invade the intestinal epithelium and survive in mucosal macrophages.\n The inflammatory response enhances the transmission success of S.\n Typhimurium by promoting its outgrowth in the gut lumen through unknown mechanisms.\n Here we show that reactive oxygen species generated during inflammation reacted with endogenous, luminal sulphur compounds (thiosulfate) to form a new respiratory electron acceptor, tetrathionate.\n The genes conferring the ability to utilize tetrathionate as an electron acceptor produced a growth advantage for S.\n Typhimurium over the competing microbiota in the lumen of the inflamed gut.\n We conclude that S.\n Typhimurium virulence factors induce host-driven production of a new electron acceptor that allows the pathogen to use respiration to compete with fermenting gut microbes.\n Thus, the ability to trigger intestinal inflammation is crucial for the biology of this diarrhoeal by Gram-Positive Bacteria","abstract":"Secondary bacterial pneumonias are a frequent complication of influenza and other respiratory viral infections, but the mechanisms underlying viral-induced susceptibility to bacterial infections are poorly understood.\n In particular, it is unclear whether the host's response against the viral infection, independent of the injury caused by the virus, results in impairment of antibacterial host defense.\n Here, we sought to determine whether the induction of an “antiviral” immune state using various viral recognition receptor ligands was sufficient to result in decreased ability to combat common bacterial pathogens of the lung.\n Using a mouse model, animals were administered polyinosine-polycytidylic acid (poly I:C) or Toll-like 7 ligand (imiquimod or gardiquimod) intranasally, followed by intratracheal challenge with Streptococcus pneumoniae.\n We found that animals pre-exposed to poly I:C displayed impaired bacterial clearance and increased mortality.\n Poly I:C-exposed animals also had decreased ability to clear methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.\n Furthermore, we showed that activation of Toll-like receptor (TLR)3 and Retinoic acid inducible gene (RIG-I)/Cardif pathways, which recognize viral nucleic acids in the form of dsRNA, both contribute to poly I:C mediated impairment of bacterial clearance.\n Finally, we determined that poly I:C administration resulted in significant induction of type I interferons (IFNs), whereas the elimination of type I IFN signaling improved clearance and survival following secondary bacterial pneumonia.\n Collectively, these results indicate that in the lung, poly I:C administration is sufficient to impair pulmonary host defense against clinically important tuberculosis), is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide and efforts to control TB are hampered by difficulties with diagnosis, prevention and treatment 1,2.\n Most people infected with M.\n tuberculosis remain asymptomatic, termed latent TB, with a 10% lifetime risk of developing active TB disease, but current tests cannot identify which individuals will develop disease 3.\n The immune response to M.\n tuberculosis is complex and incompletely characterized, hindering development of new diagnostics, therapies and vaccines 4,5.\n We identified a whole blood 393 transcript signature for active TB in intermediate and high burden settings, correlating with radiological extent of disease and reverting to that of healthy controls following treatment.\n A subset of latent TB patients had signatures similar to those in active TB patients.\n We also identified a specific 86-transcript signature that discriminated active TB from other inflammatory and infectious diseases.\n Modular and pathway analysis revealed that the TB signature was dominated by a neutrophil-driven interferon (IFN)-inducible gene profile, consisting of both IFN-? and Type I IFN?? signalling.\n Comparison with transcriptional signatures in purified cells and flow cytometric analysis, suggest that this TB signature reflects both changes in cellular composition and altered gene expression.\n Although an IFN signature was also observed in whole blood of patients with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), their complete modular signature differed from TB with increased abundance of plasma cell transcripts.\n Our studies demonstrate a hitherto under-appreciated role of Type I IFN?? signalling in TB pathogenesis, which has implications for vaccine and therapeutic development.\n Our study enteric pathogen","abstract":"The innate immune system provides the first line of defense against invading microorganisms by inducing a variety of inflammatory and antimicrobial responses.\n These responses are particularly important in the gastrointestinal tract, where the needs for efficient nutrient uptake and host defense collide.\n Many pathogens have evolved to specifically colonize the intestine, causing millions of cases of enteric infections a year.\n A paradigm of an enteric pathogen is Salmonella enterica, a gram-negative bacterium that causes a wide range of gastrointestinal and systemic diseases.\n Infections with Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium (S.\n typhimurium) lead to an acute intestinal inflammation in human and animal hosts, as a result of the bacterium invading the mucosa.\n A distinctive feature of Salmonella is that it has not only adapted to survive in a strong inflammatory environment, but it also uses this adaptation as a strategy to gain a growth advantage over the intestinal microbiota.\n We will use the model organism S.\n typhimurium to discuss the innate immune mechanisms employed by the mammalian gastrointestinal system and how the pathogen responds and subverts these mechanisms.\n In particular, we focus on the recognition of extra- and intra-cellular Salmonellae by germline-encoded pattern recognition receptors of the TLR and found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0009836","date":"2010-03-03","title":"Short-Term Antibiotic Treatment Has Differing Long-Term Impacts on the Human Throat and Gut Microbiome","abstract":"Antibiotic administration is the standard treatment for the bacterium Helicobacter pylori, the main causative agent of peptic ulcer disease and gastric cancer.\n However, the long-term consequences of this treatment on the human indigenous microbiota are relatively unexplored.\n Here we studied short- and long-term effects of clarithromycin and metronidazole treatment, a commonly used therapy regimen against H.\n pylori, on the indigenous microbiota in the throat and in the lower intestine.\n The bacterial compositions in samples collected over a four-year period were monitored by analyzing the 16S rRNA gene using 454-based pyrosequencing and terminal-restriction fragment length polymorphism (T-RFLP).\n While the microbial communities of untreated control subjects were relatively stable over time, dramatic shifts were observed one week after antibiotic treatment with reduced bacterial diversity in all treated subjects in both locations.\n While the microbiota of the different subjects responded uniquely to the antibiotic treatment some general trends could be observed; such as a dramatic decline in Actinobacteria in both throat and feces immediately after treatment.\n Although the diversity of the microbiota subsequently recovered to resemble the pre treatment states, the microbiota remained perturbed in some cases for up to four years post treatment.\n In addition, four years after treatment high levels of the macrolide resistance gene erm(B) were found, indicating that antibiotic resistance, once selected for, can persist for longer periods of time than previously recognized.\n This highlights the importance of a restrictive antibiotic usage in order to prevent subsequent treatment failure and potential spread of antibiotic resistance.\n","id":"PMC2844414","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Hedvig Infection","abstract":"The gut microbiota, the collection of all bacterial members in the intestinal tract, plays a key role in health.\n Disruption of the indigenous microbiota by a variety of stressors, including antibiotic therapy and intestinal infections, is associated with multiple health problems.\n We sought to determine if infection with Norovirus disrupts the gut microbiota.\n Barcoded pyrosequencing of the 16S rRNA-encoding gene was used to characterize the stool microbiota in Norovirus-infected human patients (n?=?38).\n While the microbiota in most infected patients (n?=?31) resembled that seen in uninfected healthy controls, a minority of patients (n?=?7) possessed a significantly altered microbiota characterized by reduced relative numbers of Bacteriodetes and a corresponding increase in Proteobacteria.\n In these patients, the increase in Proteobacteria was due to a single operational taxonomic unit (OTU) of Escherichia coli.\n We cultured E.\n coli from Norovirus-infected patients and characterized them using PCR-ribotyping and virulence factor analysis.\n Multiple ribotypes were encountered, but none possessed typical virulence factors commonly carried by enteropathogenic E.\n coli strains.\n Microbiota disruption and elevated Proteobacteria were not significantly correlated to patient age, gender, sampling time following illness onset, or overall gut inflammation.\n These results demonstrate that some patients have a disrupted microbiota following Norovirus infection, and therefore may be at elevated risk for long-term health complications.\n","id":"PMC3484122","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Adam M.","surname":"Nelson","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Seth system, leading to microbial translocation and systemic immune activation.\n We investigated the impact of HIV-1 infection on the intestinal microbiome and its association with mucosal T cell and colon biopsies and fecal samples from subjects with chronic, untreated HIV-1 infection and uninfected control subjects.\n Colon biopsies of HIV-1 infected subjects had increased abundances of Proteobacteria and decreased abundances of Firmicutes compared to uninfected donors.\n Furthermore at the genus level, a significant increase in Prevotella and decrease in Bacteroides was observed in burden of acute lower respiratory infections due to respiratory syncytial virus in young children: a systematic review and meta-analysis","abstract":"Background\nThe global burden of disease attributable to respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) remains unknown.\n\n We aimed to estimate the global incidence of and mortality from episodes of acute lower respiratory infection (ALRI) due to RSV in children younger than 5 years in 2005.\nMethods\nWe estimated the incidence of RSV-associated ALRI in children younger than 5 years, stratified by age, using data from a systematic review of studies published between January, 1995, and June, 2009, and ten unpublished population-based studies.\n\n We estimated possible boundaries for RSV-associated ALRI mortality by combining case fatality ratios with incidence estimates from hospital-based reports from published and unpublished studies and identifying studies with population-based data for RSV seasonality and monthly ALRI mortality.\n\n\nFindings\nIn 2005, an estimated 33·8 (95% CI 19·3–46·2) million new episodes of RSV-associated ALRI occurred worldwide in children younger than 5 years (22% of ALRI episodes), with at least 3·4 (2·8–4·3) million episodes representing severe RSV-associated ALRI necessitating hospital admission.\n\n We estimated that 66?000–199?000 children younger than 5 years died from RSV-associated ALRI in 2005, with 99% of these deaths occurring in developing countries.\n\n Incidence and mortality can vary substantially from year to year in any one setting.\n\n\nInterpretation\nGlobally, RSV is the most common cause of childhood ALRI and a major cause of admission to hospital as a result of severe ALRI.\n\n Mortality data suggest that RSV is an important cause of death in childhood from ALRI, after pneumococcal pneumonia and Haemophilus influenzae type b.\n\n The development of novel prevention and treatment strategies should be accelerated as a priority.\n\n\nFunding\nWHO; Bill &amp; Melinda Gates A virus infection","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1136/gutjnl-2015-309728","date":"2015-08-20","title":"The gut microbiota plays a protective role in the host defence against pneumococcal pneumonia","abstract":"Objective\nPneumonia accounts for more deaths than any other infectious disease worldwide.\n\n The intestinal microbiota supports local mucosal immunity and is increasingly recognised as an important modulator of the systemic immune system.\n\n The precise role of the gut microbiota in bacterial pneumonia, however, is unknown.\n\n Here, we investigate the function of the gut microbiota in the host defence against Streptococcus pneumoniae infections.\n\n\nDesign\nWe depleted the gut microbiota in C57BL/6 mice and subsequently infected them intranasally with S.\n\n pneumoniae.\n\n We then performed survival and faecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) experiments and measured parameters of inflammation and alveolar macrophage whole-genome responses.\n\n\nResults\nWe found that the gut microbiota protects the host during pneumococcal pneumonia, as reflected by increased bacterial dissemination, inflammation, organ damage and mortality in microbiota-depleted mice compared with controls.\n\n FMT in gut microbiota-depleted mice led to a normalisation of pulmonary bacterial counts and tumour necrosis factor-? and interleukin-10 levels 6?h after pneumococcal infection.\n\n Whole-genome mapping of alveolar macrophages showed upregulation of metabolic pathways in the absence of a healthy gut microbiota.\n\n This upregulation correlated with an altered cellular responsiveness, reflected by a reduced responsiveness to lipopolysaccharide and lipoteichoic acid.\n\n Compared with controls, alveolar macrophages derived from gut microbiota-depleted mice showed a diminished capacity to phagocytose S.\n\n pneumoniae.\n\n\nConclusions\nThis study identifies the intestinal microbiota as a protective mediator during pneumococcal pneumonia.\n\n The gut microbiota enhances primary alveolar macrophage function.\n\n Novel therapeutic strategies could exploit the gut–lung axis in bacterial infections.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4819612","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Tim on Inflammation-Coagulation Interaction during Influenza Virus Infection","abstract":"Influenza virus (IFV) is a major respiratory pathogen of global importance, and the cause of a high degree of morbidity and mortality, especially in high-risk populations such as infants, elderly, and immunocompromised hosts.\n Given its high capacity to change antigenically, acquired immunity is often not effective to limit IFV infection and therefore vaccination must be constantly redesigned to achieve effective protection.\n Improvement of respiratory and systemic innate immune mechanisms has been proposed to reduce the incidence and severity of IFV disease.\n In the last decade, several research works have demonstrated that microbes with the capacity to modulate the mucosal immune system (immunobiotics) are a potential alternative to beneficially modulate the outcome of IFV infection.\n This review provides an update of the current status on the modulation of respiratory immunity by orally and nasally administered immunobiotics, and their beneficial impact on IFV clearance and inflammatory-mediated lung tissue damage.\n In particular, we describe the research of our group that investigated the influence of immunobiotics on inflammation–coagulation interactions during IFV infection.\n Studies have clearly demonstrated that hostile inflammation is accompanied by dysfunctional coagulation in respiratory IFV disease, and our investigations have proved that some immunobiotic strains are able to reduce viral disease severity through their capacity to modulate the immune-coagulative responses in the respiratory of general 16S ribosomal RNA gene PCR primers for classical and next-generation sequencing-based diversity studies","abstract":"16S ribosomal RNA gene (rDNA) amplicon analysis remains the standard approach for the cultivation-independent investigation of microbial diversity.\n The accuracy of these analyses depends strongly on the choice of primers.\n The overall coverage and phylum spectrum of 175 primers and 512 primer pairs were evaluated in silico with respect to the SILVA 16S/18S rDNA non-redundant reference dataset (SSURef 108 NR).\n Based on this evaluation a selection of ‘best available’ primer pairs for Bacteria and Archaea for three amplicon size classes (100–400, 400–1000, ?1000 bp) is provided.\n The most promising bacterial primer pair (S-D-Bact-0341-b-S-17/S-D-Bact-0785-a-A-21), with an amplicon size of 464 bp, was experimentally evaluated by comparing the taxonomic distribution of the 16S rDNA amplicons with 16S rDNA fragments from directly sequenced metagenomes.\n The results of this study may be used as a guideline for selecting primer pairs with the best overall coverage and phylum spectrum for specific applications, therefore reducing the bias in PCR-based microbial diversity studies.\n","id":"PMC3592464","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Anna","surname":"Klindworth","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Elmar","surname":"Pruesse","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Timmy","surname":"Schweer","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Jörg","surname":"Peplies","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Christian","surname":"Quast","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Matthias","surname":"Horn","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Frank accurate read alignment programs.\n A first generation of hash table-based methods has been developed, including MAQ, which is accurate, feature rich and fast enough to align short reads from a single individual.\n However, MAQ does not support gapped alignment for single-end reads, which makes it unsuitable for alignment of longer reads where indels may occur frequently.\n The speed of MAQ is also web-based tools","abstract":"SILVA (from Latin silva, forest, http://www.\narb-silva.\nde) is a comprehensive web resource for up to date, quality-controlled databases of aligned ribosomal RNA (rRNA) gene sequences from the Bacteria, Archaea and Eukaryota domains and supplementary online services.\n The referred database release 111 (July 2012) contains 3 194 778 small subunit and 288 717 large subunit rRNA gene sequences.\n Since the initial description of the project, substantial new features have been introduced, including advanced quality control procedures, an improved rRNA gene aligner, online tools for probe and primer evaluation and optimized browsing, searching and downloading on the website.\n Furthermore, the extensively curated SILVA taxonomy and the new non-redundant http://rdp.\ncme.\nmsu.\nedu/) provides the research community with aligned and annotated rRNA gene sequence data, along with tools to allow researchers to analyze their own rRNA gene sequences in the RDP framework.\n RDP data and tools are utilized in fields as diverse as human health, microbial ecology, environmental microbiology, nucleic acid chemistry, taxonomy and phylogenetics.\n In addition to aligned and annotated collections of bacterial and archaeal small subunit rRNA genes, RDP now includes a collection of fungal large subunit rRNA genes.\n RDP tools, including Classifier and Aligner, have been updated to work with this new fungal collection.\n The use of high-throughput sequencing to characterize environmental microbial populations has exploded in the past several years, and as sequence technologies have improved, the sizes of environmental datasets have increased.\n With release 11, RDP is providing an expanded set of tools to facilitate analysis of high-throughput data, including both single-stranded and paired-end reads.\n In addition, most tools are now available as open source packages for download and local use by researchers with high-volume needs or who would like to develop custom analysis pipelines.\n","id":"PMC3965039","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"James R.","surname":"Cole","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Qiong","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jordan A.","surname":"Fish","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Benli","surname":"Chai","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Donna M.","surname":"McGarrell","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Yanni","surname":"Sun","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"C. R.","surname":"Kuske","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"James M.","surname":"Tiedje","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0009490","date":"2010-02-09","title":"FastTree 2 – Approximately Maximum-Likelihood Trees for Large Alignments","abstract":"Background\nWe recently described FastTree, a tool for inferring phylogenies for alignments with up to hundreds of thousands of sequences.\n\n Here, we describe improvements to FastTree that improve its accuracy without sacrificing scalability.\n\n\nMethodology/Principal Findings\nWhere FastTree 1 used nearest-neighbor interchanges (NNIs) and the minimum-evolution criterion to improve the tree, FastTree 2 adds minimum-evolution subtree-pruning-regrafting (SPRs) and maximum-likelihood NNIs.\n\n FastTree 2 uses heuristics to restrict the search for better trees and estimates a rate of evolution for each site (the “CAT” approximation).\n\n Nevertheless, for both simulated and genuine alignments, FastTree 2 is slightly more accurate than a standard implementation of maximum-likelihood NNIs (PhyML 3 with default settings).\n\n Although FastTree 2 is not quite as accurate as methods that use maximum-likelihood SPRs, most of the splits that disagree are poorly supported, and for large alignments, FastTree 2 is 100–1,000 times faster.\n\n FastTree 2 inferred a topology and likelihood-based local support values for 237,882 distinct 16S ribosomal RNAs on a desktop computer in 22 hours and 5.8 gigabytes of memory.\n\n\nConclusions/Significance\nFastTree 2 allows the inference of maximum-likelihood phylogenies for huge alignments.\n\n FastTree 2 is freely available at http://www.\n\nmicrobesonline.\n\norg/fasttree.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2835736","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Morgan Y.","surname":"Poon","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0061217","date":"2013-03-06","title":"phyloseq: An R Package for Reproducible Interactive Analysis and Graphics of Microbiome Census Data","abstract":"Background\nThe analysis of microbial communities through DNA sequencing brings many challenges: the integration of different types of data with methods from ecology, genetics, phylogenetics, multivariate statistics, visualization and testing.\n\n With the increased breadth of experimental designs now being pursued, project-specific statistical analyses are often needed, and these analyses are often difficult (or impossible) for peer researchers to independently reproduce.\n\n The vast majority of the requisite tools for performing these analyses reproducibly are already implemented in R and its extensions (packages), but with limited support for high throughput microbiome census data.\n\n\nResults\nHere we describe a software project, phyloseq, dedicated to the object-oriented representation and analysis of microbiome census data in R.\n\n It supports importing data from a variety of common formats, as well as many analysis techniques.\n\n These include calibration, filtering, subsetting, agglomeration, multi-table comparisons, diversity analysis, parallelized Fast UniFrac, ordination methods, and production of publication-quality graphics; all in a manner that is easy to document, share, and modify.\n\n We show how to apply functions from other R packages to phyloseq-represented data, illustrating the availability of a large number of open source analysis techniques.\n\n We discuss the use of phyloseq with tools for reproducible research, a practice common in other fields but still rare in the analysis of highly parallel microbiome census data.\n\n We have made available all of the materials necessary to completely reproduce the analysis and figures included in this article, an example of best practices for reproducible research.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe phyloseq project for R is a new open-source software package, freely available on the web from both GitHub and Bioconductor.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3632530","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Paul concepts required for the design, execution and interpretation of NGS experiments on microbiomes.\n We conducted a literature review and used our own data to determine which approaches work best.\n 2, a Sensitive and Broadly Dynamic Non-Invasive Biomarker for Intestinal Inflammation","abstract":"Inflammation has classically been defined histopathologically, especially by the presence of immune cell infiltrates.\n However, more recent studies suggest a role for 'low-grade' inflammation in a variety of disorders ranging from metabolic syndrome to cancer, which is defined by modest elevations in pro-inflammatory gene expression.\n Consequently, there is a need for cost-effective, non-invasive biomarkers that, ideally, would have the sensitivity to detect low-grade inflammation and have a dynamic range broad enough to reflect classic robust intestinal inflammation.\n Herein, we report that, for assessment of intestinal inflammation, fecal lipocalin 2 (Lcn-2), measured by ELISA, serves this purpose.\n Specifically, using a well-characterized mouse model of DSS colitis, we observed that fecal Lcn-2 and intestinal expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1?, CXCL1, TNF?) are modestly but significantly induced by very low concentrations of DSS (0.25 and 0.5%), and become markedly elevated at higher concentrations of DSS (1.0 and 4.0%).\n As expected, careful histopathologic analysis noted only modest immune infiltrates at low DSS concentration and robust colitis at higher DSS concentrations.\n In accordance, increased levels of the neutrophil product myeloperoxidase (MPO) was only detected in mice given 1.0 and 4.0% DSS.\n In addition, fecal Lcn-2 marks the severity of spontaneous colitis development in IL-10 deficient mice.\n Unlike histopathology, MPO, and q-RT-PCR, the assay of fecal Lcn-2 requires only a stool sample, permits measurement over time, and can detect inflammation as early as 1 day following DSS administration.\n Thus, assay of fecal Lcn-2 by ELISA can function as a non-invasive, sensitive, dynamic, stable and cost-effective means to monitor intestinal inflammation in and pathogen-induced inflammation disrupt the murine intestinal microbiome","abstract":"Background\n\nSalmonella is one of the most significant food-borne pathogens to affect humans and agriculture.\n\n While it is well documented that Salmonella infection triggers host inflammation, the impacts on the gut environment are largely unknown.\n\n A CBA/J mouse model was used to evaluate intestinal responses to Salmonella-induced inflammation.\n\n In parallel, we evaluated chemically induced inflammation by dextran sodium sulfate (DSS) and a non-inflammation control.\n\n We profiled gut microbial diversity by sequencing 16S ribosomal ribonucleic acid (rRNA) genes from fecal and cecal samples.\n\n These data were correlated to the inflammation marker lipocalin-2 and short-chain fatty acid concentrations.\n\n\nResults\nWe demonstrated that inflammation, chemically or biologically induced, restructures the chemical and microbial environment of the gut over a 16-day period.\n\n We observed that the ten mice within the Salmonella treatment group had a variable Salmonella relative abundance, with three high responding mice dominated by &gt;46% Salmonella at later time points and the remaining seven mice denoted as low responders.\n\n These low- and high-responding Salmonella groups, along with the chemical DSS treatment, established an inflammation gradient with chemical and low levels of Salmonella having at least 3 log-fold lower lipocalin-2 concentration than the high-responding Salmonella mice.\n\n Total short-chain fatty acid and individual butyrate concentrations each negatively correlated with inflammation levels.\n\n Microbial communities were also structured along this inflammation gradient.\n\n Low levels of inflammation, regardless of chemical or biological induction, enriched for Akkermansia spp.\n\n in the Verrucomicrobiaceae and members of the Bacteroidetes family S24-7. Relative to the control or low inflammation groups, high levels of Salmonella drastically decreased the overall microbial diversity, specifically driven by the reduction of Alistipes and Lachnospiraceae in the Bacteroidetes and Firmicutes phyla, respectively.\n\n Conversely, members of the Enterobacteriaceae and Lactobacillus were positively correlated to high levels of Salmonella-induced inflammation.\n\n\nConclusions\nOur results show that enteropathogenic infection and intestinal inflammation are interrelated factors modulating gut homeostasis.\n\n These findings may prove informative with regard to prophylactic or therapeutic strategies to prevent disruption of microbial communities, or promote their restoration.\n\n\nElectronic supplementary material\nThe online version of this article (doi:10.1186/s40168-017-0264-8) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5408407","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Mikayla A.","surname":"Borton","email":"borton.62@osu.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Anice","surname":"Sabag-Daigle","email":"anice.sabagdaigle@gmail.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jikang","surname":"Wu","email":"wu.2014@buckeyemail.osu.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lindsey M.","surname":"Solden","email":"solden.2@osu.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Bridget S.","surname":"O’Banion","email":"obanion.2@osu.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Rebecca A.","surname":"Daly","email":"daly.130@osu.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Richard A.","surname":"Wolfe","email":"wolfeerich@gmail.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Juan F.","surname":"Gonzalez","email":"jfgonzalezp@gmail.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Vicki H.","surname":"Wysocki","email":"wysocki.11@osu.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Brian M. stomach and small intestine, while a larger proportion of anaerobes such as Bacteroidaceae, Prevotellaceae, Rikenellaceae, Lachnospiraceae, and Ruminococcaceae were found in the large intestine and enterotypes, host genotype, cage and inter-individual effects drive gut microbiota variation in common laboratory mice","abstract":"Background\nMurine models are a crucial component of gut microbiome research.\n\n Unfortunately, a multitude of genetic backgrounds and experimental setups, together with inter-individual variation, complicates cross-study comparisons and a global understanding of the mouse microbiota landscape.\n\n Here, we investigate the variability of the healthy mouse microbiota of five common lab mouse strains using 16S rDNA pyrosequencing.\n\n\nResults\nWe find initial evidence for richness-driven, strain-independent murine enterotypes that show a striking resemblance to those in human, and which associate with calprotectin levels, a marker for intestinal inflammation.\n\n After enterotype stratification, we find that genetic, caging and inter-individual variation contribute on average 19%, 31.7% and 45.5%, respectively, to the variance in the murine gut microbiota composition.\n\n Genetic distance correlates positively to microbiota distance, so that genetically similar strains have more similar microbiota than genetically distant ones.\n\n Specific mouse strains are enriched for specific operational taxonomic units and taxonomic groups, while the 'cage effect' can occur across mouse strain boundaries and is mainly driven by Helicobacter infections.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe detection of enterotypes suggests a common ecological cause, possibly low-grade inflammation that might drive differences among gut microbiota composition in mammals.\n\n Furthermore, the observed environmental and genetic effects have important consequences for experimental design in mouse microbiome research.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4053703","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Falk","surname":"Hildebrand","email":"falk.hildebrand@vib-vub.be","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Thi found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1242/dmm.017400","date":"1970-01-01","title":"How informative is the mouse for human gut microbiota research?","abstract":"The microbiota of the human gut is gaining broad attention owing to its association with a wide range of diseases, ranging from metabolic disorders (e.\ng.\n obesity and type 2 diabetes) to autoimmune diseases (such as inflammatory bowel disease and type 1 diabetes), cancer and even neurodevelopmental disorders (e.\ng.\n autism).\n Having been increasingly used in biomedical research, mice have become the model of choice for most studies in this emerging field.\n Mouse models allow perturbations in gut microbiota to be studied in a controlled experimental setup, and thus help in assessing causality of the complex host-microbiota interactions and in developing mechanistic hypotheses.\n However, pitfalls should be considered when translating gut microbiome research results from mouse models to humans.\n In this Special Article, we discuss the intrinsic similarities and differences that exist between the two systems, and compare the human and murine core gut microbiota based on a meta-analysis of currently available datasets.\n Finally, we discuss the external factors that influence the capability of mouse models to recapitulate the gut microbiota shifts associated with human diseases, and investigate which alternative model systems exist for gut microbiota associated with the development of stress-induced despair behavior","abstract":"Depressive disorders often run in families, which, in addition to the genetic component, may point to the microbiome as a causative agent.\n Here, we employed a combination of behavioral, molecular and computational techniques to test the role of the microbiota in mediating despair behavior.\n In chronically stressed mice displaying despair behavior, we found that the microbiota composition and the metabolic signature dramatically change.\n Specifically, we observed reduced Lactobacillus and increased circulating kynurenine levels as the most prominent changes in stressed mice.\n Restoring intestinal Lactobacillus levels was sufficient to improve the metabolic alterations and behavioral abnormalities.\n Mechanistically, we identified that Lactobacillus-derived reactive oxygen species may suppress host kynurenine metabolism, by inhibiting the expression of the metabolizing enzyme, IDO1, in the intestine.\n Moreover, maintaining elevated kynurenine levels during Lactobacillus supplementation diminished the treatment benefits.\n Collectively, our data provide a mechanistic scenario for how a microbiota player (Lactobacillus) may contribute to regulating metabolism and resilience during of Age, Caloric Restriction, and Influenza Infection on Mouse Gut Microbiome: An Exploratory Study of the Role of Age-Related Microbiome Changes on Influenza Responses","abstract":"Immunosenescence refers to age-related declines in the capacity to respond to infections such as influenza (flu).\n Caloric restriction represents a known strategy to slow many aging processes, including those involving the immune system.\n More recently, some changes in the microbiome have been described with aging, while the gut microbiome appears to influence responses to flu vaccination and infection.\n With these considerations in mind, we used a well-established mouse model of flu infection to explore the impact of flu infection, aging, and caloric restriction on the gut microbiome.\n Young, middle-aged, and aged caloric restricted (CR) and ad lib fed (AL) mice were examined after a sublethal flu infection.\n All mice lost 10–20% body weight and, as expected for these early time points, losses were similar at different ages and between diet groups.\n Cytokine and chemokine levels were also similar with the notable exception of IL-1?, which rose more than fivefold in aged AL mouse serum, while it remained unchanged in aged CR serum.\n Fecal microbiome phyla abundance profiles were similar in young, middle-aged, and aged AL mice at baseline and at 4?days post flu infection, while increases in Proteobacteria were evident at 7?days post flu infection in all three age groups.\n CR mice, compared to AL mice in each age group, had increased abundance of Proteobacteria and Verrucomicrobia at all time points.\n Interestingly, principal coordinate analysis determined that diet exerts a greater effect on the microbiome than age or flu infection.\n Percentage body weight loss correlated with the relative abundance of Proteobacteria regardless of age, suggesting flu pathogenicity is related to Proteobacteria abundance.\n Further, several microbial Operational Taxonomic Units from the Bacteroidetes phyla correlated with serum chemokine/cytokines regardless of both diet and age suggesting an interplay between flu-induced systemic inflammation and gut microbiota.\n These exploratory studies highlight the impact of caloric restriction on fecal microbiome in both young and aged animals, as well as the many complex relationships between flu responses and gut microbiota.\n Thus, these preliminary studies provide the necessary groundwork to examine how gut microbiota alterations may be leveraged to influence declining immune responses with aging.\n","id":"PMC5611400","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jenna
