from wet market poultry: clinical analysis and characterisation of viral genome","abstract":"Background\nHuman infection with avian influenza A H7N9 virus emerged in eastern China in February, 2013, and has been associated with exposure to poultry.\n\n We report the clinical and microbiological features of patients infected with influenza A H7N9 virus and compare genomic features of the human virus with those of the virus in market poultry in Zhejiang, China.\n\n\nMethods\nBetween March 7 and April 8, 2013, we included hospital inpatients if they had new-onset respiratory symptoms, unexplained radiographic infiltrate, and laboratory-confirmed H7N9 virus infection.\n\n We recorded histories and results of haematological, biochemical, radiological, and microbiological investigations.\n\n We took throat and sputum samples, used RT-PCR to detect M, H7, and N9 genes, and cultured samples in Madin-Darby canine kidney cells.\n\n We tested for co-infections and monitored serum concentrations of six cytokines and chemokines.\n\n We collected cloacal swabs from 86 birds from epidemiologically linked wet markets and inoculated embryonated chicken eggs with the samples.\n\n We identified and subtyped isolates by RT-PCR sequencing.\n\n RNA extraction, complementary DNA synthesis, and PCR sequencing were done for one human and one chicken isolate.\n\n We characterised and phylogenetically analysed the eight gene segments of the viruses in the patient's and the chicken's isolates, and constructed phylogenetic trees of H, N, PB2, and NS genes.\n\n\nFindings\nWe identified four patients (mean age 56 years), all of whom had contact with poultry 3–8 days before disease onset.\n\n They presented with fever and rapidly progressive pneumonia that did not respond to antibiotics.\n\n Patients were leucopenic and lymphopenic, and had impaired liver or renal function, substantially increased serum cytokine or chemokine concentrations, and disseminated intravascular coagulation with disease progression.\n\n Two patients died.\n\n Sputum specimens were more likely to test positive for the H7N9 virus than were samples from throat swabs.\n\n The viral isolate from the patient was closely similar to that from an epidemiologically linked market chicken.\n\n All viral gene segments were of avian origin.\n\n The H7 of the isolated viruses was closest to that of the H7N3 virus from domestic ducks in Zhejiang, whereas the N9 was closest to that of the wild bird H7N9 virus in South Korea.\n\n We noted Gln226Leu and Gly186Val substitutions in human virus H7 (associated with increased affinity for ?-2,6-linked sialic acid receptors) and the PB2 Asp701Asn mutation (associated with mammalian adaptation).\n\n Ser31Asn mutation, which is associated with adamantane resistance, was noted in viral M2.\nInterpretation\nCross species poultry-to-person transmission of this new reassortant H7N9 virus is associated with severe pneumonia and multiorgan dysfunction in human beings.\n\n Monitoring of the viral evolution and further study of disease pathogenesis will improve disease management, epidemic control, and produced at the site of inflammation and plays a key role in the acute phase response as defined by a variety of clinical and biological features such as the production of acute phase proteins.\n IL-6 in combination with its soluble receptor sIL-6R?, dictates the transition from acute to chonic inflammation by changing the nature of leucocyte infiltrate (from polymorphonuclear neutrophils to monocyte/macrophages).\n In addition, IL-6 exerts stimulatory effects on T- and B-cells, thus favoring chronic inflammatory responses.\n Strategies targeting IL-6 and IL-6 signaling led to effective prevention and treatment of models of rheumatoid arthritis and other chronic inflammatory diseases.\n","id":"PMC3226076","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Cem","surname":"Gabay","email":"cem.gabay@hcuge.ch","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1038/s41577-018-0066-7","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Recent found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1136/annrheumdis-2015-207628","date":"2015-10-03","title":"Tocilizumab in early progressive rheumatoid arthritis: FUNCTION, a randomised controlled trial","abstract":"Objectives\nThe efficacy of tocilizumab (TCZ), an anti-interleukin-6 receptor antibody, has not previously been evaluated in a population consisting exclusively of patients with early rheumatoid arthritis (RA).\n\n\nMethods\nIn a double-blind randomised controlled trial (FUNCTION), 1162 methotrexate (MTX)-naive patients with early progressive RA were randomly assigned (1:1:1:1) to one of four treatment groups: 4?mg/kg TCZ+MTX, 8?mg/kg TCZ+MTX, 8?mg/kg TCZ+placebo and placebo+MTX (comparator group).\n\n The primary outcome was remission according to Disease Activity Score using 28 joints (DAS28–erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) &lt;2.6) at week 24. Radiographic and physical function outcomes were also evaluated.\n\n We report results through week 52.\nResults\nThe intent-to-treat population included 1157 patients.\n\n Significantly more patients receiving 8?mg/kg TCZ+MTX and 8?mg/kg TCZ+placebo than receiving placebo+MTX achieved DAS28-ESR remission at week 24 (45% and 39% vs 15%; p&lt;0.0001).\n\n The 8?mg/kg TCZ+MTX group also achieved significantly greater improvement in radiographic disease progression and physical function at week 52 than did patients treated with placebo+MTX (mean change from baseline in van der Heijde–modified total Sharp score, 0.08 vs 1.14 (p=0.0001); mean reduction in Health Assessment Disability Index, ?0.81 vs ?0.64 (p=0.0024)).\n\n In addition, the 8?mg/kg TCZ+placebo and 4?mg/kg TCZ+MTX groups demonstrated clinical efficacy that was at least as effective as MTX for these key secondary endpoints.\n\n Serious adverse events were similar among treatment groups.\n\n Adverse events resulting in premature withdrawal occurred in 20% of patients in the 8?mg/kg TCZ+MTX group.\n\n\nConclusions\nTCZ is effective in combination with MTX and as monotherapy for the treatment of patients with early RA.\n\n\nTrial registration number\nClinicalTrials.\n\ngov, number NCT01007435\n","id":"PMC4893095","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Gerd in systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis in a real-world clinical setting: results from 1 year of postmarketing surveillance follow-up of 417 patients in Japan","abstract":"Objectives\nTo evaluate the safety and effectiveness of tocilizumab (TCZ) in patients with systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA) in real-world clinical settings in Japan.\n\n\nMethods\nPaediatric patients with sJIA initiating TCZ between April 2008 and February 2012 and those previously enrolled in clinical trials who initiated TCZ before April 2008 were enrolled in a Japanese registry surveillance programme.\n\n Safety and effectiveness parameters were collected for 52?weeks.\n\n\nResults\nOf 417 patients enrolled, mean age was 11.2?years and 48.0% were female.\n\n TCZ exposure was 407.0 patient-years (PYs).\n\n Baseline corticosteroid use was higher than in clinical trials.\n\n Rates of total adverse events (AEs) and serious AEs (SAEs) were 224.3/100 PYs and 54.5/100 PYs, respectively, with SAEs higher than previously reported.\n\n The most frequent AEs and SAEs were infections and infestations (69.8/100 PYs and 18.2/100 PYs, respectively).\n\n 74 serious infections occurred in 55 patients (18.2/100 PYs); higher than previously reported.\n\n 26 macrophage activation syndrome events were reported in 24 patients (6.4/100 PYs).\n\n Fever and rash symptoms improved from baseline to week 52 (54.6% to 5.6% and 43.0% to 5.6%, respectively).\n\n At 4 weeks, 8 weeks and 52?weeks, 90.5%, 96.2% and 99.0% of patients achieved normal C reactive protein levels (&lt;0.3?mg/dL), respectively.\n\n\nConclusions\nThese first real-world data demonstrated that TCZ was well tolerated, with acceptable safety and effectiveness in patients with sJIA.\n\n Higher production is drastically increased in mice persistently infected with lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus.\n In vivo blockade of the IL-10 receptor (IL-10R) with a neutralizing antibody resulted in found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1128/mBio.00322-16","date":"2016-02-29","title":"Transfer of Viral Communities between Human Individuals during Fecal Microbiota Transplantation","abstract":"Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is a highly effective treatment for refractory Clostridium difficile infections.\n However, concerns persist about unwanted cotransfer of pathogenic microbes such as viruses.\n Here we studed FMT from a single healthy human donor to three pediatric ulcerative colitis patients, each of whom received a course of 22 to 30 FMT treatments.\n Viral particles were purified from donor and recipient stool samples and sequenced; the reads were then assembled into contigs corresponding to viral genomes or partial genomes.\n Transfer of selected viruses was confirmed by quantitative PCR.\n Viral contigs present in the donor could be readily detected in recipients, with up to 32 different donor viral contigs appearing in a recipient sample.\n Reassuringly, none of these were viruses are known to replicate on human cells.\n Instead, viral contigs either scored as bacteriophage or could not be attributed taxonomically, suggestive of unstudied phage.\n The two most frequently transferred gene types were associated with temperate-phage replication.\n In addition, members of Siphoviridae, the group of typically temperate phages that includes phage lambda, were found to be transferred with significantly greater efficiency than other groups.\n On the basis of these findings, we propose that the temperate-phage replication style may promote efficient phage transfer between human individuals.\n In summary, we documented transfer of multiple viral lineages between human individuals through FMT, but in this case series, none were from viral groups known to infect human cells.\n","id":"PMC4817255","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Christel","surname":"Chehoud","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Anatoly","surname":"Dryga","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Young","surname":"Hwang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Dorottya","surname":"Nagy-Szakal","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Emily D.","surname":"Bushman","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1101/mcs.a000448","date":"2015-08-27","title":"Long-term changes of bacterial and viral compositions in the intestine of a recovered <italic>Clostridium difficile</italic> patient after fecal microbiota transplantation","abstract":"Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is an effective treatment for recurrent Clostridium difficile infections (RCDIs).\n However, long-term effects on the patients’ gut microbiota and the role of viruses remain to be elucidated.\n Here, we characterized bacterial and viral microbiota in the feces of a cured RCDI patient at various time points until 4.5 yr post-FMT compared with the stool donor.\n Feces were subjected to DNA sequencing to characterize bacteria and double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) viruses including phages.\n The patient's microbial communities varied over time and showed little overall similarity to the donor until 7 mo post-FMT, indicating ongoing gut microbiota adaption in this time period.\n After 4.5 yr, the patient's bacteria attained donor-like compositions at phylum, class, and order levels with similar bacterial diversity.\n Differences in the bacterial communities between donor and patient after 4.5 yr were seen at lower taxonomic levels.\n C.\n difficile remained undetectable throughout the entire timespan.\n This demonstrated sustainable donor feces engraftment and verified long-term therapeutic success of FMT on the molecular level.\n Full engraftment apparently required longer than previously acknowledged, suggesting the implementation of year-long patient follow-up periods into clinical practice.\n The identified dsDNA viruses were mainly Caudovirales phages.\n Unexpectedly, sequences related to giant algae–infecting Chlorella viruses were also detected.\n Our findings indicate that intestinal viruses may be implicated in the establishment of gut microbiota.\n Therefore, virome analyses should be included in gut microbiota studies to determine the roles of phages and other viruses—such as Chlorella viruses—in human health and disease, particularly during RCDI.\n","id":"PMC4849847","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Felix","surname":"Broecker","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jochen","surname":"Klumpp","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Markus","surname":"Schuppler","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Giancarlo","surname":"Russo","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Luc","surname":"Biedermann","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Michael","surname":"Hombach","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Gerhard","surname":"Rogler","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Karin","surname":"Moelling","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.chom.2017.07.002","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Commensal found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0071806","date":"2013-07-03","title":"Fungi of the Murine Gut: Episodic Variation and Proliferation during Antibiotic Treatment","abstract":"Antibiotic use in humans has been associated with outgrowth of fungi.\n Here we used a murine model to investigate the gut microbiome over 76 days of treatment with vancomycin, ampicillin, neomycin, and metronidazole and subsequent recovery.\n Mouse stool was studied as a surrogate for the microbiota of the lower gastrointestinal tract.\n The abundance of fungi and bacteria was measured using quantitative PCR, and the proportional composition of the communities quantified using 454/Roche pyrosequencing of rRNA gene tags.\n Prior to treatment, bacteria outnumbered fungi by &gt;3 orders of magnitude.\n Upon antibiotic treatment, bacteria dropped in abundance &gt;3 orders of magnitude, so that the predominant 16S sequences detected became transients derived from food.\n Upon cessation of treatment, bacterial communities mostly returned to their previous numbers and types after 8 weeks, though communities remained detectably different from untreated controls.\n Fungal communities varied substantially over time, even in the untreated controls.\n Separate cages within the same treatment group showed radical differences, but mice within a cage generally behaved similarly.\n Fungi increased ?40-fold in abundance upon antibiotic treatment but declined back to their original abundance after cessation of treatment.\n At the last time point, Candida remained more abundant than prior to treatment.\n These data show that 1) gut fungal populations change radically during normal mouse husbandry, 2) fungi grow out in the gut upon suppression of bacterial communities with antibiotics, and 3) perturbations due to antibiotics persist long term in both the fungal and bacterial microbiota.\n","id":"PMC3747063","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Serena","surname":"Dollive","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Ying-Yu","surname":"Chen","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Stephanie","surname":"Grunberg","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Kyle","surname":"Bittinger","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Christian","surname":"Hoffmann","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Lee","surname":"Vandivier","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Christopher","surname":"Cuff","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"James found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1136/gutjnl-2015-310746","date":"2016-01-14","title":"Fungal microbiota dysbiosis in IBD","abstract":"Objective\nThe bacterial intestinal microbiota plays major roles in human physiology and IBDs.\n\n Although some data suggest a role of the fungal microbiota in IBD pathogenesis, the available data are scarce.\n\n The aim of our study was to characterise the faecal fungal microbiota in patients with IBD.\n\n\nDesign\nBacterial and fungal composition of the faecal microbiota of 235 patients with IBD and 38 healthy subjects (HS) was determined using 16S and ITS2 sequencing, respectively.\n\n The obtained sequences were analysed using the Qiime pipeline to assess composition and diversity.\n\n Bacterial and fungal taxa associated with clinical parameters were identified using multivariate association with linear models.\n\n Correlation between bacterial and fungal microbiota was investigated using Spearman's test and distance correlation.\n\n\nResults\nWe observed that fungal microbiota is skewed in IBD, with an increased Basidiomycota/Ascomycota ratio, a decreased proportion of Saccharomyces cerevisiae and an increased proportion of Candida albicans compared with HS.\n\n We also identified disease-specific alterations in diversity, indicating that a Crohn's disease-specific gut environment may favour fungi at the expense of bacteria.\n\n The concomitant analysis of bacterial and fungal microbiota showed a dense and homogenous correlation network in HS but a dramatically unbalanced network in IBD, suggesting the existence of disease-specific inter-kingdom alterations.\n\n\nConclusions\nBesides bacterial dysbiosis, our study identifies a distinct fungal microbiota dysbiosis in IBD characterised by alterations in biodiversity and composition.\n\n Moreover, we unravel here disease-specific inter-kingdom network alterations in IBD, suggesting that, beyond bacteria, fungi might also play a role in IBD pathogenesis.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5532459","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Harry","surname":"Sokol","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Valentin","surname":"Leducq","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Hugues","surname":"Aschard","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Hang-Phuong","surname":"Pham","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sarah","surname":"Jegou","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Cecilia","surname":"Landman","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"David","surname":"Cohen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Giuseppina","surname":"Liguori","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Anne","surname":"Bourrier","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Isabelle","surname":"Nion-Larmurier","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jacques","surname":"Cosnes","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Philippe","surname":"Seksik","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Philippe","surname":"Langella","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"David","surname":"Skurnik","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Mathias A broad-coverage fungal quantitative real-time PCR assay","abstract":"Background\nFungal load quantification is a critical component of fungal community analyses.\n\n Limitation of current approaches for quantifying the fungal component in the human microbiome suggests the need for new broad-coverage techniques.\n\n\nMethods\nWe analyzed 2,085 18S rRNA gene sequences from the SILVA database for assay design.\n\n We generated and quantified plasmid standards using a qPCR-based approach.\n\n We evaluated assay coverage against 4,968 sequences and performed assay validation following the Minimum Information for Publication of Quantitative Real-Time PCR Experiments (MIQE) guidelines.\n\n\nResults\nWe designed FungiQuant, a TaqMan® qPCR assay targeting a 351 bp region in the fungal 18S rRNA gene.\n\n Our in silico analysis showed that FungiQuant is a perfect sequence match to 90.0% of the 2,617 fungal species analyzed.\n\n We showed that FungiQuant’s is 100% sensitive and its amplification efficiencies ranged from 76.3% to 114.5%, with r2-values of &gt;0.99 against the 69 fungal species tested.\n\n Additionally, FungiQuant inter- and intra-run coefficients of variance ranged from &lt;10% and &lt;20%, respectively.\n\n We further showed that FungiQuant has a limit of quantification 25 copies and a limit of detection at 5 copies.\n\n Lastly, by comparing results from human-only background DNA with low-level fungal DNA, we showed that amplification in two or three of a FungiQuant performed in triplicate is statistically significant for true positive fungal detection.\n\n\nConclusions\nFungiQuant has comprehensive coverage against diverse fungi and is a robust quantification and detection tool for delineating between true fungal detection and non-target human DNA.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3565980","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Cindy evolutionary analyses of bacteria and archaea","abstract":"Reference phylogenies are crucial for providing a taxonomic framework for interpretation of marker gene and metagenomic surveys, which continue to reveal novel species at a remarkable rate.\n Greengenes is a dedicated full-length 16S rRNA gene database that provides users with a curated taxonomy based on de novo tree inference.\n We developed a ‘taxonomy to tree' approach for transferring group names from an existing taxonomy to a tree topology, and used it to apply the Greengenes, National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) and cyanoDB (Cyanobacteria only) taxonomies to a de novo tree comprising 408?315 sequences.\n We also incorporated explicit rank information provided by the NCBI taxonomy to group names (by prefixing rank designations) for better user orientation and classification consistency.\n The resulting merged taxonomy improved the classification of 75% of the sequences by one or more ranks relative to the original NCBI taxonomy with the most pronounced improvements occurring in under-classified environmental sequences.\n We also assessed candidate phyla (divisions) currently defined by NCBI and present recommendations for consolidation of 34 redundantly named groups.\n All intermediate results from the pipeline, which includes tree inference, jackknifing and transfer of a donor taxonomy to a recipient tree (tax2tree) are available for download.\n The improved Greengenes taxonomy should provide important infrastructure for a wide range of megasequencing projects studying ecosystems on scales ranging from our own bodies (the Human Microbiome Project) to the entire planet (the Earth Microbiome Project).\n The implementation of the software can be obtained from <italic>Candida</italic>-Specific Real-Time PCR Assays for the Detection and Identification of Eight Medically Important <italic>Candida</italic> Species","abstract":"Culture-based identification methods have been the gold standard for the diagnosis of fungal infection.\n Currently, molecular technologies such as real-time PCR assays with short turnaround time can provide desirable alternatives for the rapid detection of Candida microbes.\n However, most of the published PCR primer sets are not Candida specific and likely to amplify DNA from common environmental contaminants, such as Aspergillus microbes.\n In this study, we designed pan-Candida primer sets based on the ribosomal DNA-coding regions conserved within Candida but distinct from those of Aspergillus and Penicillium.\n We demonstrate that the final two selected pan-Candida primer sets would not amplify Aspergillus DNA and could be used to differentiate eight medically important Candida pathogens in real-time PCR assays based on their melting profiles, with a sensitivity of detection as low as 10 fg of Candida genomic DNA.\n Moreover, we further evaluated and selected species-specific primer sets covering Candida albicans, Candida glabrata, Candida tropicalis, and Candida dubliniensis and show that they had high sensitivity and specificity.\n These real-time PCR primer sets could potentially clade within the subgenus sarbecovirus, Orthocoronavirinae subfamily.\n Different from both MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV, 2019-nCoV is the seventh member of the family of coronaviruses that infect humans.\n 2":[{"doi":"10.1056/NEJMoa2001316","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Early Transmission Dynamics in Wuhan, China, of Novel Coronavirus–Infected Pneumonia","abstract":"Background\nThe initial cases of novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV)–infected pneumonia (NCIP) occurred in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China, in December 2019 and January 2020. We analyzed data on the first 425 confirmed cases in Wuhan to determine the epidemiologic characteristics of NCIP.\n\n\nMethods\nWe collected information on demographic characteristics, exposure history, and illness timelines of laboratory-confirmed cases of NCIP that had been reported by January 22, 2020. We described characteristics of the cases and estimated the key epidemiologic time-delay distributions.\n\n In the early period of exponential growth, we estimated the epidemic doubling time and the basic reproductive number.\n\n\nResults\nAmong the first 425 patients with confirmed NCIP, the median age was 59 years and 56% were male.\n\n The majority of cases (55%) with onset before January 1, 2020, were linked to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, as compared with 8.6% of the subsequent cases.\n\n The mean incubation period was 5.2 days (95% confidence interval [CI], 4.1 to 7.0), with the 95th percentile of the distribution at 12.5 days.\n\n In its early stages, the epidemic doubled in size every 7.4 days.\n\n With a mean serial interval of 7.5 days (95% CI, 5.3 to 19), the basic reproductive number was estimated to be 2.2 (95% CI, 1.4 to 3.9).\n\n\nConclusions\nOn the basis of this information, there is evidence that human-to-human transmission has occurred among close contacts since the middle of December 2019. Considerable efforts to reduce transmission will be required to control outbreaks if similar dynamics apply elsewhere.\n\n Measures to prevent or reduce transmission should be implemented in populations at risk.\n\n (Funded by the Ministry of Science and Technology of China and Hong","surname":"Nguyen","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/s13054-014-0722-7","date":"2014-12-15","title":"Epidemiology of invasive aspergillosis in critically ill patients: clinical presentation, underlying conditions, and outcomes","abstract":"Introduction\nInvasive aspergillosis (IA) is a fungal infection that particularly affects immunocompromised hosts.\n\n Recently, several studies have indicated a high incidence of IA in intensive care unit (ICU) patients.\n\n However, few data are available on the epidemiology and outcome of patients with IA in this setting.\n\n\nMethods\nAn observational study including all patients with a positive Aspergillus culture during ICU stay was performed in 30 ICUs in 8 countries.\n\n Cases were classified as proven IA, putative IA or Aspergillus colonization according to recently validated criteria.\n\n Demographic, microbiologic and diagnostic data were collected.\n\n Outcome was recorded 12 weeks after Aspergillus isolation.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 563 patients were included, of whom 266 were colonized (47%), 203 had putative IA (36%) and 94 had proven IA (17%).\n\n The lung was the most frequent site of infection (94%), and Aspergillus fumigatus the most commonly isolated species (92%).\n\n Patients with IA had higher incidences of cancer and organ transplantation than those with colonization.\n\n Compared with other patients, they were more frequently diagnosed with sepsis on ICU admission and more frequently received vasopressors and renal replacement therapy (RRT) during the ICU stay.\n\n Mortality was 38% among colonized patients, 67% in those with putative IA and 79% in those with proven IA (P?&lt;?0.001).\n\n Independent risk factors for death among patients with IA included older age, history of bone marrow transplantation, and mechanical ventilation, RRT and higher Sequential Organ Failure Assessment score at diagnosis.\n\n\nConclusions\nIA among critically ill patients is associated with high mortality.\n\n Patients diagnosed with proven or putative IA had greater severity of illness and more frequently needed organ support than those with Aspergillus spp colonization.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4344741","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Fabio found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3390/jof7121067","date":"2021-12-09","title":"A Visual and Comprehensive Review on COVID-19-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis (CAPA)","abstract":"Coronavirus disease 19 (COVID-19)-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) is a severe fungal infection complicating critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n Numerous retrospective and prospective studies have been performed to get a better grasp on this lethal co-infection.\n We performed a qualitative review and summarized data from 48 studies in which 7047 patients had been included, of whom 820 had CAPA.\n The pooled incidence of proven, probable or putative CAPA was 15.1% among 2953 ICU-admitted COVID-19 patients included in 18 prospective studies.\n Incidences showed great variability due to multiple factors such as discrepancies in the rate and depth of the fungal work-up.\n The pathophysiology and risk factors for CAPA are ill-defined, but therapy with corticosteroids and anti-interleukin-6 therapy potentially confer the biggest risk.\n Sampling for mycological work-up using bronchoscopy is the cornerstone for diagnosis, as imaging is often aspecific.\n CAPA is associated with an increased mortality, but we do not have conclusive data whether therapy contributes to an increased survival in these patients.\n We conclude our review with a comparison between influenza-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (IAPA) and CAPA.\n risk factors and mortality of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in patients with influenza: A systematic review and meta?analysis","abstract":"Background\nAn increasing number of cases of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) complicating influenza have been described.\n\n We performed a meta?analysis to estimate the incidence, risk factors and outcomes of IPA in patients with influenza.\n\n\nMethods\nA systematic search was conducted in the PubMed, EMBASE and Cochrane Library databases from their inception to 31 August 2021 for eligible studies.\n\n Data on the incidence and risk factors of and mortality due to IPA in influenza patients were pooled using a random?effects model.\n\n Sensitivity analyses restricted to severe influenza requiring intensive care unit (ICU) support and multiple subgroup analyses were performed.\n\n\nResults\nFourteen studies involving 6024 hospitalised patients with influenza were included.\n\n IPA was estimated to occur in 10% of influenza patients, with a mortality rate of 52%.\n\n Similar incidence (11%) and mortality (54%) estimates for IPA were observed in the sensitivity analysis including severe cases requiring ICU support.\n\n Subgroup analysis by geographical location showed a similar IPA rate between European (10%) and non?European (11%) studies.\n\n The IPA rate in the subset of nine studies using the modified AspICU criteria was 13%.\n\n Most subgroup analyses showed ?50% mortality in IPA patients.\n\n Several predictors for IPA susceptibility were identified, including male sex, smoking history, chronic lung disease, influenza A (H1N1), severe conditions requiring supportive therapy, corticosteroid use before admission, solid organ transplant and haematological malignancy.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe IPA is common in individuals with severe influenza, and the prognosis is particularly poor.\n\n Influenza patients, especially those with high?risk factors, should be thoroughly screened for IPA.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9306612","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Changcheng","surname":"Shi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Qiyuan","surname":"Shan","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Qiyuan","surname":"Shan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Junbo","surname":"Xia","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Junbo","surname":"Xia","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Liusheng","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Linling","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lei","surname":"Qiu","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Yaping","surname":"Xie","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Nengming","surname":"Lin","email":"lnm1013@zju.edu.cn","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Limin","surname":"Wang","email":"lnm1013@zju.edu.cn","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Limin","surname":"Wang","email":"lnm1013@zju.edu.cn","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Influenza: Diagnosis and treatment","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3390/v13020202","date":"2020-11-27","title":"COVID-19: A Review on the Novel Coronavirus Disease Evolution, Transmission, Detection, Control and Prevention","abstract":"Three major outbreaks of the coronavirus, a zoonotic virus known to cause respiratory disease, have been reported since 2002, including SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and the most recent 2019-nCoV, or more recently known as SARS-CoV-2. Bats are known to be the primary animal reservoir for coronaviruses.\n However, in the past few decades, the virus has been able to mutate and adapt to infect humans, resulting in an animal-to-human species barrier jump.\n The emergence of a novel coronavirus poses a serious global public health threat and possibly carries the potential of causing a major pandemic outbreak in the naïve human population.\n The recent outbreak of COVID-19, the disease caused by SARS-CoV-2, in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China has infected over 36.5 million individuals and claimed over one million lives worldwide, as of 8 October 2020. The novel virus is rapidly spreading across China and has been transmitted to 213 other countries/territories across the globe.\n Researchers have reported that the virus is constantly evolving and spreading through asymptomatic carriers, further suggesting a high global health threat.\n To this end, current up-to-date information on the coronavirus evolution and SARS-CoV-2 modes of transmission, detection techniques and current control and prevention strategies are summarized in this review.\n","id":"PMC7911532","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Anshika","surname":"Sharma","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Isra","surname":"Ahmad patients: a prospective study","abstract":"Background\nIn this study we evaluated the incidence of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis among intubated patients with critical coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and evaluated different case definitions of invasive aspergillosis.\n\n\nMethods\nProspective, multicentre study on adult patients with microbiologically confirmed COVID-19 receiving mechanical ventilation.\n\n All included participants underwent screening protocol for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis with bronchoalveolar lavage galactomannan and cultures performed on admission at 7 days and in case of clinical deterioration.\n\n Cases were classified as coronavirus associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) according to previous consensus definitions.\n\n The new definition was compared with putative invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (PIPA).\n\n\nResults\nA total of 108 patients were enrolled.\n\n Probable CAPA was diagnosed in 30 (27.7%) of patients after a median of 4 (2-8) days from intensive care unit (ICU) admission.\n\n Kaplan-Meier curves showed a significant higher 30-day mortality rate from ICU admission among patients with either CAPA (44% vs 19%, p= 0.002) or PIPA (74% vs 26%, p&lt;0.001) when compared with patients not fulfilling criteria for aspergillosis.\n\n The association between CAPA [OR 3.53 (95%CI 1.29-9.67), P=0.014] or PIPA [OR 11.60 (95%CI 3.24-41.29) p&lt;0.001] with 30-day mortality from ICU admission was confirmed even after adjustment for confounders with a logistic regression model.\n\n Among patients with CAPA receiving voriconazole treatment (13 patients, 43%) A trend toward lower mortality (46% vs 59% p=0.30) and reduction of galactomannan index in consecutive samples was observed.\n\n\nConclusion\nWe found a high COVID-19–associated pulmonary aspergillosis: systematic review and meta-analysis","abstract":"Background\nPulmonary aspergillosis may complicate coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and contribute to excess mortality in intensive care unit (ICU) patients.\n\n The disease is poorly understood, in part due to discordant definitions across studies.\n\n\nObjectives\nWe sought to review the prevalence, diagnosis, treatment, and outcomes of COVID-19–associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) and compare research definitions.\n\n\nData sources\nPubMed, Embase, Web of Science, and MedRxiv were searched from inception to October 12, 2021.\nStudy eligibility criteria\nICU cohort studies and CAPA case series including ?3 patients were included.\n\n\nParticipants\nAdult patients in ICUs with COVID-19.\nInterventions\nPatients were reclassified according to four research definitions.\n\n We assessed risk of bias with an adaptation of the Joanna Briggs Institute cohort checklist tool for systematic reviews.\n\n\nMethods\nWe calculated CAPA prevalence using the Freeman-Tukey random effects method.\n\n Correlations between definitions were assessed with Spearman's rank test.\n\n Associations between antifungals and outcome were assessed with random effects meta-analysis.\n\n\nResults\nFifty-one studies were included.\n\n Among 3297 COVID-19 patients in ICU cohort studies, 313 were diagnosed with CAPA (prevalence 10%; 95% CI 8%–13%).\n\n Two hundred seventy-seven patients had patient-level data allowing reclassification.\n\n Definitions had limited correlation with one another (? = 0.268–0.447; p &lt; 0.001), with the exception of Koehler and Verweij (? = 0.893; p &lt; 0.001); 33.9% of patients reported to have CAPA did not fulfill any research definitions.\n\n Patients were diagnosed after a median of 8 days (interquartile range 5–14) in ICUs.\n\n Tracheobronchitis occurred in 3% of patients examined with bronchoscopy.\n\n The mortality rate was high (59.2%).\n\n Applying CAPA research definitions did not strengthen the association between mould-active antifungals and survival.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe reported prevalence of CAPA is significant but may be exaggerated by nonstandard definitions.\n\n\n","id":"PMC8828380","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Ruwandi S.","surname":"Schwartz","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.jhin.2021.04.012","date":"2021-04-13","title":"Incidence, diagnosis and outcomes of COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA): a systematic review","abstract":"COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) is defined as invasive pulmonary aspergillosis occurring in COVID-19 patients.\n The purpose of this review was to discuss the incidence, characteristics, diagnostic criteria, biomarkers, and outcomes of hospitalized patients diagnosed with CAPA.\n A literature search was performed through Pubmed and Web of Science databases for articles published up to 20th March 2021. In 1421 COVID-19 patients, the overall CAPA incidence was 13.5% (range 2.5–35.0%).\n The majority required invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV).\n The time to CAPA diagnosis from illness onset varied between 8.0 and 16.0 days.\n However, the time to CAPA diagnosis from intensive care unit (ICU) admission and IMV initiation ranged between 4.0–15.0 days and 3.0–8.0 days.\n The most common diagnostic criteria were the modified AspICU–Dutch/Belgian Mycosis Study Group and IAPA-Verweij et al.\n A total of 77.6% of patients had positive lower respiratory tract cultures, other fungal biomarkers of bronchoalveolar lavage and serum galactomannan were positive in 45.3% and 18.2% of patients.\n The CAPA mortality rate was high at 48.4%, despite the widespread use of antifungals.\n Lengthy hospital and ICU stays ranging between 16.0–37.5 days and 10.5–37.0 days were observed.\n CAPA patients had prolonged IMV duration of 13.0–20.0 days.\n The true incidence of CAPA likely remains unknown as the diagnosis is limited by the lack of standardized diagnostic criteria that rely solely on microbiological data with direct or indirect detection of Aspergillus in respiratory specimens, particularly in clinical conditions with a low pretest probability.\n A well-designed, multi-centre study to determine the optimal diagnostic approach for CAPA is required.\n","id":"PMC8057923","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"W.H.","surname":"Chong","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"K.P.","surname":"Neu","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1111/myc.13328","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Mortality aspergillosis: the 2020 ECMM/ISHAM consensus criteria for research and clinical guidance","abstract":"Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 causes direct damage to the airway epithelium, enabling aspergillus invasion.\n Reports of COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis have raised concerns about it worsening the disease course of COVID-19 and increasing mortality.\n Additionally, the first cases of COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis caused by azole-resistant aspergillus have been reported.\n This article constitutes a consensus statement on defining and managing COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis, prepared by experts and endorsed by medical mycology societies.\n COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis is proposed to be defined as possible, probable, or proven on the basis of sample validity and thus diagnostic certainty.\n Recommended first-line therapy is either voriconazole or isavuconazole.\n If azole resistance is a concern, then liposomal amphotericin B is the drug of choice.\n Our aim is to provide definitions for clinical research and up-to-date recommendations for clinical management of the diagnosis and treatment of COVID-19-associated pulmonary pneumonia.\n\n\nMethods\nWe prospectively screened 32 critically ill patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia for a time period of 28 days using a standardized study protocol for oberservation of developement of COVID-19 associated invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA).\n\n We collected laboratory, microbiological, virological and clinical parameters at defined timepoints in combination with galactomannan-antigen-detection from nondirected bronchial lavage (NBL).\n\n We used logistic regression analyses to assess if COVID-19 was independently associated with IPA and compared it with matched controls.\n\n\nFindings\nCAPA was diagnosed at a median of 4 days after ICU admission in 11/32 (34%) of critically ill patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia as compared to 8% in the control cohort.\n\n In the COVID-19 cohort, mean age, APACHE II score and ICU mortality were higher in patients with CAPA than in patients without CAPA (36% versus 9.5%; p&lt;0.001).\n\n ICU stay (21 versus 17 days; p = 0.340) and days of mechanical ventilation (20 versus 15 days; p = 0.570) were not different between both groups.\n\n In regression analysis COVID-19 and APACHE II score were independently associated with IPA.\n\n\nInterpretation\nCAPA is highly prevalent and associated with a high mortality rate.\n\n COVID-19 is independently associated with invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.\n\n A Invasive Pulmonary Aspergillosis in the Intensive Care Unit: A Case Series in a Portuguese Hospital","abstract":"Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) has become a recognizable complication in coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) patients admitted to intensive care units (ICUs).\n Alveolar damage in the context of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) appears to be the culprit in facilitating fungal invasion in COVID-19 patients, leading to a COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) phenomenon.\n From November 2020 to 15 February 2021, 248 COVID-19 patients were admitted to our ICUs, of whom ten patients (4% incidence) were classified as either probable (six) or possible (four) CAPA cases.\n Seven patients had positive cultural results: Aspergillus fumigatus sensu stricto (five), A.\n terreus sensu stricto (one), and A.\n welwitschiae (one).\n Five patients had positive bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) and galactomannan (GM), and two patients had both positive cultural and GM criteria.\n All but two patients received voriconazole.\n Mortality rate was 30%.\n Strict interpretation of classic IPA definition would have resulted in eight overlooked CAPA cases.\n Broader diagnostic criteria are essential in this context, even though differentiation between Aspergillus colonization and invasive disease might be more challenging.\n Herein, we aim to raise awareness of CAPA in view of its potential detrimental outcome, emphasizing the relevance of a low threshold for screening and early antifungal treatment in ARDS found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3390/jof8020096","date":"2022-01-14","title":"Regional Impact of COVID-19-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis (CAPA) during the First Wave","abstract":"Background: Critically ill COVID-19 patients have proven to be at risk for developing invasive fungal infections.\n However, the incidence and impact of possible/probable COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) in severe COVID-19 patients varies between cohorts.\n We aimed to assess the incidence, risk factors, and clinical outcome of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in a regional cohort of COVID-19 intensive care patients.\n Methods: We performed a regional, multicentre, retrospective cohort study in the intensive care units (ICUs) in North Brabant, The Netherlands.\n We included adult patients with rt-PCR-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection (COVID-19), requiring mechanical ventilation for acute respiratory distress syndrome.\n Demographics, clinical course, biomarker value, and treatment outcomes were compared between the groups with possible/probable CAPA from the main study centre and the regional centres, and without signs of CAPA from the main study centre as controls.\n The primary aim was to assess the regional impact of possible/probable CAPA in COVID-19 ICU patients, measured as all-cause mortality at 30 days after ICU admission.\n Secondary outcomes were risk factors for developing CAPA, based on underlying host factors and to identify the value of the mycological arguments for the diagnosing of CAPA.\n Results: Between 1 March and 30 April 2020, we included 123 patients with severe COVID-19: 29 patients (30.9%) in the main ICU with possible/probable CAPA, and 65 (69.1%) with no signs of CAPA; 29 patients in the regional ICUs with signs of CAPA.\n Patients’ characteristics and risk factors did not differ for CAPA and non-CAPA patients.\n Patients with COPD and/or chronic steroid medication developed CAPA more frequently, although this was not statistically significant.\n CAPA patients were admitted to the ICU earlier, had lower PF-ratios, and more often required renal replacement therapy.\n All-cause 30-day mortality was significantly higher in mechanically ventilated COVID-19 patients with possible/probable CAPA 39.7% (23/58) compared to patients without evidence for CAPA 16.9% (11/65) (OR 3.2 [95% CI 1.4–7.4] p = 0.005).\n Conclusion: The high incidence of possible and probable CAPA in critically ill COVID-19 patients is alarming.\n The increase in 30-day mortality in CAPA highlights the need for active surveillance and management strategies in critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n","id":"PMC8875881","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Robbert study was to evaluate diagnostic means, host factors, delay of occurrence, and outcome of patients with COVID-19 pneumonia and fungal coinfections in the intensive care unit (ICU).\n From 1 February to 31 May 2020, we anonymously recorded COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA), fungemia (CA-fungemia), and pneumocystosis (CA-PCP) from 36 centers, including results on fungal biomarkers in respiratory specimens and serum.\n We collected data from 154 episodes of CAPA, 81 of CA-fungemia, 17 of CA-PCP, and 5 of other mold infections from 244 patients (male/female [M/F] ratio?=?3.5; mean age, 64.7?±?10.8?years).\n CA-PCP occurred first after ICU admission (median, 1?day; interquartile range [IQR], 0 to 3 days), followed by CAPA (9?days; IQR, 5 to 13 days), and then CA-fungemia (16?days; IQR, 12 to 23 days) (P &lt; 10?4).\n For CAPA, the presence of several mycological criteria was associated with death (P &lt; 10?4).\n Serum galactomannan was rarely positive (&lt;20%).\n The mortality rates were 76.7% (23/30) in patients with host factors for invasive fungal disease, 45.2% (14/31) in those with a preexisting pulmonary condition, and 36.6% (34/93) in the remaining patients (P = 0.001).\n Antimold treatment did not alter prognosis (P = 0.370).\n Candida albicans was responsible for 59.3% of CA-fungemias, with a global mortality of 45.7%.\n For CA-PCP, 58.8% of the episodes occurred in patients with known host factors of PCP, and the mortality rate was 29.5%.\n CAPA may be in part hospital acquired and could benefit from antifungal prescription at the first positive biomarker result.\n CA-fungemia appeared linked to ICU stay without COVID-19 specificity, while CA-PCP may not really be a concern in the ICU.\n Improved diagnostic strategy for fungal markers in ICU patients with COVID-19 should support these hypotheses.\n","id":"PMC8528108","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Stéphane","surname":"Bretagne","email":"NULL","contributions":"3"},{"firstname":"Karine","surname":"Sitbon","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Karine","surname":"Sitbon","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Françoise","surname":"Botterel","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Sarah","surname":"Dellière","email":"NULL","contributions":"4"},{"firstname":"Valérie","surname":"Letscher-Bru","email":"NULL","contributions":"3"},{"firstname":"Valérie","surname":"Letscher-Bru","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Taieb","surname":"Chouaki","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Anne-Pauline","surname":"Bellanger","email":"NULL","contributions":"3"},{"firstname":"Christine","surname":"Bonnal","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Arnault","surname":"Fekkar","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Florence","surname":"Persat","email":"NULL","contributions":"4"},{"firstname":"Florence","surname":"Persat","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Damien","surname":"Costa","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Nathalie","surname":"Bourgeois","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Frédéric","surname":"Dalle","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Florian","surname":"Lussac-Sorton","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"André","surname":"Paugam","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sophie","surname":"Cassaing","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lilia","surname":"Hasseine","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Antoine","surname":"Huguenin","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Nadia","surname":"Guennouni","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Edith","surname":"Mazars","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Solène","surname":"Le pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA): Risk factors and development of a predictive score for critically ill COVID?19 patients","abstract":"Background\nCOVID?19?associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) is a major complication of critically ill COVID?19 patients, with a high mortality rate and potentially preventable.\n\n Thus, identifying patients at high risk of CAPA would be of great interest.\n\n We intended to develop a clinical prediction score capable of stratifying patients according to the risk for CAPA at ICU admission.\n\n\nMethods\nSingle centre retrospective case–control study.\n\n A case was defined as a patient diagnosed with CAPA according to 2020 ECMM/ISHAM consensus criteria.\n\n 2 controls were selected for each case among critically ill COVID?19 patients.\n\n\nResults\n28 CAPA patients and 56?matched controls were included.\n\n Factors associated with CAPA included old age (68 years vs.\n\n 62, p = .\n\n033), active smoking (17.9% vs.\n\n 1.8%, p = .\n\n014), chronic respiratory diseases (48.1% vs.\n\n 26.3%, p = .\n\n043), chronic renal failure (25.0% vs.\n\n 3.6%, p = .\n\n005), chronic corticosteroid treatment (28.6% vs.\n\n 1.8%, p &lt; .\n\n001), tocilizumab therapy (92.9% vs.\n\n 66.1%, p = .\n\n008) and high APACHE II at ICU admission (median 13 vs.\n\n 10 points, p = .\n\n026).\n\n A score was created including these variables, which showed an area under the receiver operator curve of 0.854 (95% CI 0.77?0.92).\n\n A punctuation below 6 had a negative predictive value of 99.6%.\n\n A punctuation of 10 or higher had a positive predictive value of 27.9%.\n\n\nConclusion\nWe present a clinical prediction score that allowed to stratify critically ill COVID?19 patients according to the risk for developing CAPA.\n\n This CAPA score would allow to target preventive measures.\n\n Further evaluation of the score, as well as the utility of these targeted preventive measures, is needed.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9115267","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jorge","surname":"Calderón?Parra","email":"jorge050390@gmail.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Patricia","surname":"Mills?Sanchez","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Patricia","surname":"Mills?Sanchez","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Victor","surname":"Moreno?Torres","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sandra","surname":"Tejado?Bravo","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Isabel","surname":"Romero?Sánchez","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Bárbara","surname":"Balandin?Moreno","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Marina","surname":"Calvo?Salvador","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Francisca","surname":"Portero?Azorín","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sarela","surname":"García?Masedo","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Elena","surname":"Muñez?Rubio","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Antonio","surname":"Ramos?Martinez","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Ana","surname":"Fernández?Cruz","email":"anafcruz999@gmail.com","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Ana","surname":"Fernández?Cruz","email":"anafcruz999@gmail.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"NULL","surname":"NULL","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"NULL","surname":"NULL","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3390/jof8090894","date":"2022-08-22","title":"Challenges develop invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA).\n Considering the weaknesses of diagnostic tests/case definitions, as well as the results from autoptic studies, there is a debate on the real burden of aspergillosis in COVID-19 patients.\n We performed a retrospective observational study on mechanically ventilated critically ill COVID-19 patients in an intensive care unit (ICU).\n The primary objective was to determine the burden of CAPA by comparing clinical diagnosis (through case definitions/diagnostic algorithms) with autopsy results.\n Twenty patients out of 168 (11.9%) developed probable CAPA.\n Seven (35%) were females, and the median age was 66 [IQR 59–72] years.\n Thirteen CAPA patients (65%) died and, for six, an autopsy was performed providing a proven diagnosis in four cases.\n Histopathology findings suggest a focal pattern, rather than invasive and diffuse fungal disease, in the context of prominent viral pneumonia.\n In a cohort of mechanically ventilated outcomes","abstract":"Background\nCOVID?19 patients on mechanical ventilation are at risk to develop invasive aspergillosis.\n\n To provide additional data regarding this intriguing entity, we conducted a retrospective study describing risk factors, radiology and prognosis of this emerging entity in a Brazilian referral centre.\n\n\nMethods\nThis retrospective study included intubated (?18 years) patients with COVID?19 admitted from April 2020 until July 2021 that had bronchoscopy to investigate pulmonary co?infections.\n\n COVID?19?associated aspergillosis (CAPA) was defined according to the 2020 European Confederation of Medical Mycology/International Society of Human and Animal Mycosis consensus criteria.\n\n The performance of tracheal aspirate (TA) cultures to diagnose CAPA were described, as well as the radiological findings, risk factors and outcomes.\n\n\nResults\nFourteen patients (14/87, 16%) had probable CAPA (0.9 cases per 100 ICU admissions).\n\n The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value and negative predictive value of TA for the diagnosis of CAPA were 85.7%, 73.1%, 46.2% and 95% respectively.\n\n Most of the radiological findings of CAPA were classified as typical of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (64.3%).\n\n The overall mortality rate of probable CAPA was 71.4%.\n\n Age was the only independent risk factor for CAPA [p = .\n\n03; odds ratio (OR) 1.072].\n\n CAPA patients under renal replacement therapy (RRT) may have a higher risk for a fatal outcome (p = .\n\n053, hazard ratio 8.047).\n\n\nConclusions\nCAPA was a prevalent co?infection in our cohort of patients under mechanical ventilation.\n\n Older patients had a higher risk to develop CAPA, and a poor prognosis may be associated with aspergillosis in ICU patients: a French multicentric retrospective cohort","abstract":"Objectives\nThe main objective of this study was to determine the incidence of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) in patients with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU), and to describe the patient characteristics associated with IPA occurrence and to evaluate its impact on prognosis.\n\n\nMethods\nWe conducted a retrospective cohort study including all successive COVID-19 patients, hospitalized in four ICUs, with secondary deterioration and one or more respiratory samples sent to the mycology department.\n\n We used a strengthened IPA testing strategy including seven mycological criteria.\n\n Patients were classified as probable IPA according to the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC)/Mycoses Study Group Education and Research Consortium (MSGERC) classification if immunocompromised, and according to the recent COVID-19-associated IPA classification otherwise.\n\n\nResults\nProbable IPA was diagnosed in 21 out of the 366 COVID-19 patients (5.7%) admitted to the ICU and in the 108 patients (19.4%) who underwent respiratory sampling for deterioration.\n\n No significant differences were observed between patients with and without IPA regarding age, gender, medical history and severity on admission and during hospitalization.\n\n Treatment with azithromycin for ?3 days was associated with the diagnosis of probable IPA (odds ratio 3.1, 95% confidence interval 1.1–8.5, p = 0.02).\n\n A trend was observed with high-dose dexamethasone and the occurrence of IPA.\n\n Overall mortality was higher in the IPA patients (15/21, 71.4% versus 32/87, 36.8%, p &lt; 0.01).\n\n\nConclusion\nIPA is a relatively frequent complication in severe COVID-19 patients and is responsible for increased mortality.\n\n Azithromycin, known to have immunomodulatory properties, may contribute to increase COVID-19 patient's susceptibility to IPA.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7733556","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Sarah","surname":"Dellière","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Emmanuel","surname":"Dudoignon","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sofiane","surname":"Fodil","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sebastian","surname":"Voicu","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Magalie","surname":"Collet","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Pierre-Antoine","surname":"Oillic","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Maud","surname":"Salmona","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"François","surname":"Dépret","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Théo","surname":"Ghelfenstein-Ferreira","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Benoit","surname":"Plaud","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Benjamin","surname":"Chousterman","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Stéphane","surname":"Bretagne","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Elie","surname":"Azoulay","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Alexandre","surname":"Mebazaa","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Bruno","surname":"Megarbane","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Alexandre","surname":"Alanio","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1093/mmy/myaa078","date":"2020-08-11","title":"Pulmonary pandemic","abstract":"Background\nCOVID?19?associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) has been reported as an important cause of mortality in critically ill patients with an incidence rate ranging from 5% to 35% during the first and second pandemic waves.\n\n\nObjectives\nWe aimed to evaluate the incidence, risk factors for CAPA by a screening protocol and outcome in the critically ill patients during the third wave of the pandemic.\n\n\nPatients/Methods\nThis prospective cohort study was conducted in two intensive care units (ICU) designated for patients with COVID?19 in a tertiary care university hospital between 18 November 2020 and 24 April 2021. SARS?CoV?2 PCR?positive adult patients admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure were included in the study.\n\n Serum and respiratory samples were collected periodically from ICU admission up to CAPA diagnosis, patient discharge or death.\n\n ECMM/ISHAM consensus criteria were used to diagnose and classify CAPA cases.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 302 patients were admitted to the two ICUs during pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) in Iranian patients admitted with severe COVID-19 pneumonia","abstract":"Purpose\nid='Par1'>Bacterial or virus co-infections with SARS-CoV-2 have been reported in many studies; however, the knowledge on Aspergillus co-infection among patients with COVID-19 was limited.\n\n This study was conducted to identify and isolate fungal agents and to evaluate the prevalence of pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) as well as antifungal susceptibility patterns of Aspergillus species in patients with COVID-19 admitted to Shahid Beheshti Hospital, Kashan, Iran.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>The study involved 119 patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia referred to the Shahid Beheshti Hospital, Kashan, Iran.\n\n A total of 17 Aspergillus spp.\n\n that were isolated from COVID-19 patients suspected of CAPA were enrolled in the study.\n\n CAPA was defined using ECMM/ISHAM consensus criteria.\n\n The PCR amplification of the ?-tubulin gene was used to identify the species.\n\n The antifungal activities of fluconazole, itraconazole, voriconazole, amphotericin B against Aspergillus spp.\n\n were evaluated according to the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute manual (M38-A3).\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>From the 119 patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia, CAPA was confirmed in 17 cases (14.3%).\n\n Of these, 12 (70.6%) were males and 5 (29.4%) were females; the mean age at presentation was 73.8 years (range: 45–88 years; median?=?77; IQR?=?18).\n\n Aspergillus fumigatus (9/17; 52.9%), Aspergillus flavus (5/17; 29.4%), Aspergillus oryzae (3/17, 17.6%), were identified as etiologic agents of CAPA, using the molecular techniques.\n\n Voriconazole and amphotericin B showed more activity against all isolates.\n\n Moreover, the MIC of fluconazole, itraconazole varied with the tested isolates.\n\n For 3 clinical isolates of A.\n\n fumigatus, 2 isolate of A.\n\n flavus and 3 A.\n\n oryzae, the MIC of fluconazole and itraconazole were???16 µg/mL.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>We observed a high incidence (14.3%) of probable aspergillosis in 119 patients with COVID-19, which might indicate the risk for developing IPA in COVID-19 patients.\n\n When comparing patients with and without CAPA regarding baseline characteristics, CAPA patients were older (p?=0?.\n\n024), had received more frequent systemic corticosteroids (p?=?0.024), and had a higher mortality rate (p?=?0.018).\n\n The outcome of CAPA is usually poor, thus emphasis shall be given to screening and/or prophylaxis in COVID-19 patients with any risk of developing CAPA.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9476444","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Mahzad","surname":"Erami","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Seyed content-type='genus-species'>Aspergillus</named-content> Test Profiles and Mortality in Critically Ill COVID-19 Patients","abstract":"The literature regarding COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) has shown conflicting observations, including survival of CAPA patients not receiving antifungal therapy and discrepancy between CAPA diagnosis and autopsy findings.\n To gain insight into the pathophysiology of CAPA, we performed a case-control study in which we compared Aspergillus test profiles in CAPA patients and controls in relation to intensive care unit (ICU) mortality.\n This was a multinational case-control study in which Aspergillus test results, use of antifungal therapy, and mortality were collected from critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n Patients were classified using the 2020 European Confederation for Medical Mycology and the International Society for Human and Animal Mycology (ECMM/ISHAM) consensus case definitions.\n We analyzed 219 critically ill COVID-19 cases, including 1 proven, 38 probable, 19 possible CAPA cases, 21 Aspergillus-colonized patients, 7 patients only positive for serum (1,3)-?-d-glucan (BDG), and 133 cases with no evidence of CAPA.\n Mortality was 53.8% in CAPA patients compared to 24.1% in patients without CAPA (P?=?0.001).\n Positive serum galactomannan (GM) and BDG were associated with increased mortality compared to serum biomarker-negative CAPA patients (87.5% versus 41.7%, P?=?0.046; 90.0% versus 42.1%, P?=?0.029, respectively).\n For each point increase in GM or 10-point BDG serum concentration, the odds of death increased (GM, odds ratio [OR] 10.208, 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.621 to 64.291, P?=?0.013; BDG, OR, 1.247, 95% CI, 1.029 to 1.511, P?=?0.024).\n CAPA is a complex disease, probably involving a continuum of respiratory colonization, tissue invasion, and angioinvasion.\n Serum biomarkers are useful for staging CAPA disease progression and, if positive, indicate angioinvasion and a high probability of mortality.\n There is need for a biomarker that distinguishes between respiratory tract colonization and tissue-invasive CAPA disease.\n","id":"PMC8601217","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Mehmet","surname":"Ergün","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Roger J. E.","surname":"Hanson","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3390/diagnostics12051201","date":"2022-05-09","title":"Clinical and Imaging Features of COVID-19-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis","abstract":"Background: COVID-19 superinfection by Aspergillus (COVID-19-associated aspergillosis, CAPA) is increasingly observed due to increased awareness and use of corticosteroids.\n The aim of this study is to compare clinical and imaging features between COVID-19 patients with and without associated pulmonary aspergillosis.\n Material and Methods: In this case–control study, hospitalized patients between March 2020 and March 2021 were evaluated.\n Two observers independently compared 105 chest CTs of 52 COVID-19 patients without pulmonary aspergillosis to 40 chest CTs of 13 CAPA patients.\n The following features were evaluated: lung involvement, predominant main pattern (ground glass opacity, crazy paving, consolidation) and additional lung and chest findings.\n Chronological changes in the abnormal extent upon CT and chronological changes in the main patterns were compared with mixed models.\n Patient-wise comparisons of additional features and demographic and clinical data were performed using Student’s t-test, Chi-squared test, Fisher’s exact tests and Wilcoxon rank-sum tests.\n Results: Compared to COVID-19 patients without pulmonary aspergillosis, CAPA patients were older (mean age (±SD): 70.3 (±7.8) versus 63.5 (±9.5) years (p = 0.01).\n The time-dependent evolution rates for consolidation (p = 0.02) and ground glass (p = 0.006) differed.\n In early COVID-19 disease, consolidation was associated with CAPA, whereas ground glass was less common.\n Chronological changes in the abnormal extent upon CT did not differ (p = 0.29).\n Regardless of the time point, bronchial wall thickening was observed more frequently in CAPA patients (p = 0.03).\n Conclusions: CAPA patients showed a tendency for consolidation in early COVID-19 disease.\n Bronchial wall thickening and higher patient age were associated with CAPA.\n The overall lung involvement was similar between both groups.\n","id":"PMC9140144","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Tim","surname":"Fischer","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Yassir","surname":"El Pulmonary Aspergillosis in Patients with and without SARS-CoV-2 Infection","abstract":"The recent European Confederation of Medical Mycology (ECMM) and the International Society for Human and Animal Mycology (ISHAM) 2020 consensus classification proposes criteria to define coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19)-associated invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA), including mycological evidence obtained via non-bronchoscopic lavage.\n Given the low specificity of radiological findings in patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection, this criterion makes it difficult to differentiate between invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) and colonization.\n This unicenter and retrospective study includes 240 patients with isolates of any Aspergillus species in any respiratory samples during a 20-month study (140 IPA and 100 colonization).\n Mortality was high in the IPA and colonization groups (37.1% and 34.0%, respectively; p = 0.61), especially in patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection, where mortality was higher in colonized patients (40.7% vs.\n 66.6.%; p: 0.021).\n Multivariate analysis confirmed the following variables to be independently associated with increased mortality: age &gt; 65 years, acute or chronic renal failure at diagnosis, thrombocytopenia (&lt;100,000 platelets/µL) at admission, inotrope requirement, and SARS-CoV-2 infection, but not the presence of IPA.\n This series shows that the isolation of Aspergillus spp.\n in respiratory samples, whether associated with disease criteria or not, is associated with high mortality, especially in patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection, and suggests an early initiation of treatment given its high mortality rate.\n","id":"PMC9968193","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jesús","surname":"Fortún","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"María","surname":"Mateos","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"María","surname":"Mateos","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Elia S.","surname":"Perlin","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/S2213-2600(21)00442-2","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Fungal infections in mechanically ventilated patients with COVID-19 during the first wave: the French multicentre MYCOVID study","abstract":"Background\nPatients with severe COVID-19 have emerged as a population at high risk of invasive fungal infections (IFIs).\n\n However, to our knowledge, the prevalence of IFIs has not yet been assessed in large populations of mechanically ventilated patients.\n\n We aimed to identify the prevalence, risk factors, and mortality associated with IFIs in mechanically ventilated patients with COVID-19 under intensive care.\n\n\nMethods\nWe performed a national, multicentre, observational cohort study in 18 French intensive care units (ICUs).\n\n We retrospectively and prospectively enrolled adult patients (aged ?18 years) with RT-PCR-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection and requiring mechanical ventilation for acute respiratory distress syndrome, with all demographic and clinical and biological follow-up data anonymised and collected from electronic case report forms.\n\n Patients were systematically screened for respiratory fungal microorganisms once or twice a week during the period of mechanical ventilation up to ICU discharge.\n\n The primary outcome was the prevalence of IFIs in all eligible participants with a minimum of three microbiological samples screened during ICU admission, with proven or probable (pr/pb) COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) classified according to the recent ECMM/ISHAM definitions.\n\n Secondary outcomes were risk factors of pr/pb CAPA, ICU mortality between the pr/pb CAPA and non-pr/pb CAPA groups, and associations of pr/pb CAPA and related variables with ICU mortality, identified by regression models.\n\n The MYCOVID study is registered with ClinicalTrials.\n\ngov, NCT04368221.\n\n\nFindings\nBetween Feb 29 and July 9, 2020, we enrolled 565 mechanically ventilated patients with COVID-19. 509 patients with at least three screening samples were analysed (mean age 59·4 years [SD 12·5], 400 [79%] men).\n\n 128 (25%) patients had 138 episodes of pr/pb or possible IFIs.\n\n 76 (15%) patients fulfilled the criteria for pr/pb CAPA.\n\n According to multivariate analysis, age older than 62 years (odds ratio [OR] 2·34 [95% CI 1·39–3·92], p=0·0013), treatment with dexamethasone and anti-IL-6 (OR 2·71 [1·12–6·56], p=0·027), and long duration of mechanical ventilation (&gt;14 days; OR 2·16 [1·14–4·09], p=0·019) were independently associated with pr/pb CAPA.\n\n 38 (7%) patients had one or more other pr/pb IFIs: 32 (6%) had candidaemia, six (1%) had invasive mucormycosis, and one (&lt;1%) had invasive fusariosis.\n\n Multivariate analysis of associations with death, adjusted for candidaemia, for the 509 patients identified three significant factors: age older than 62 years (hazard ratio [HR] 1·71 [95% CI 1·26–2·32], p=0·0005), solid organ transplantation (HR 2·46 [1·53–3·95], p=0·0002), and pr/pb CAPA (HR 1·45 [95% CI 1·03–2·03], p=0·033).\n\n At time of ICU discharge, survival curves showed that overall ICU mortality was significantly higher in patients with pr/pb CAPA than in those without, at 61·8% (95% CI 50·0–72·8) versus 32·1% (27·7–36·7; p&lt;0·0001).\n\n\nInterpretation\nThis study shows the high prevalence of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis and candidaemia and high mortality associated with pr/pb CAPA in mechanically ventilated patients with COVID-19. These findings highlight the need for active surveillance of fungal pathogens in patients with severe COVID-19.\nFunding\nPfizer.\n\n\n","id":"PMC8626095","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jean-Pierre","surname":"Gangneux","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Eric","surname":"Dannaoui","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Arnaud","surname":"Fekkar","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Charles-Edouard","surname":"Luyt","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Françoise","surname":"Botterel","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Nicolas","surname":"De patients","abstract":"Background\nCOVID?19?associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) has been widely reported but homogenous large cohort studies are needed to gain real?world insights about the disease.\n\n\nMethods\nWe collected clinical and laboratory data of 1161 patients hospitalised at our Institute from March 2020 to August 2021, defined their CAPA pathology, and analysed the data of CAPA/non?CAPA and deceased/survived CAPA patients using univariable and multivariable models.\n\n\nResults\nThe overall prevalence and mortality of CAPA in our homogenous cohort of 1161 patients were 6.4% and 47.3%, respectively.\n\n The mortality of CAPA was higher than that of non?CAPA patients (hazard ratio: 1.8 [95% confidence interval: 1.1–2.8]).\n\n Diabetes (odds ratio [OR] 1.92 [1.15–3.21]); persistent fever (2.54 [1.17–5.53]); hemoptysis (7.91 [4.45–14.06]); and lung lesions of cavitation (8.78 [2.27–34.03]), consolidation (9.06 [2.03–40.39]), and nodules (8.26 [1.08–1.29]; p?&lt;?.\n\n001), and pulse glucocorticoid treatment (HR 4.0 [1.3–9.2]) were associated with mortality of the disease.\n\n Whereas neutrophilic leukocytosis (development: 1.09 [1.03–1.15] and mortality: 1.17 [1.08–1.28]) and lymphopenia (development: 0.68 [0.51–0.91] and mortality: 0.40 [0.20–0.83]) were associated with the development as well as mortality of CAPA.\n\n\nConclusion\nWe observed a low but likely underestimated prevalence of CAPA in our study.\n\n CAPA is a disease with high mortality and diabetes is a significant factor for its development while ARDS and pulse glucocorticoid treatment are significant factors for its mortality.\n\n Cellular immune dysregulation may have a central role in CAPA from its development to
