COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis in critically ill patients: an observational study","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Coronavirus disease 19 (COVID-19)-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) emerged as important fungal complications in patients with COVID-19-associated severe acute respiratory failure (ARF).\n\n Whether mould active antifungal prophylaxis (MAFP) can prevent CAPA remains elusive so far.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>In this observational study, we included all consecutive patients admitted to intensive care units with COVID-19-associated ARF between September 1, 2020, and May 1, 2021. We compared patients with versus without antifungal prophylaxis with respect to CAPA incidence (primary outcome) and mortality (secondary outcome).\n\n Propensity score adjustment was performed to account for any imbalances in baseline characteristics.\n\n CAPA cases were classified according to European Confederation of Medical Mycology (ECMM)/International Society of Human and Animal Mycoses (ISHAM) consensus criteria.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>We included 132 patients, of whom 75 (57%) received antifungal prophylaxis (98% posaconazole).\n\n Ten CAPA cases were diagnosed, after a median of 6 days following ICU admission.\n\n Of those, 9 CAPA cases were recorded in the non-prophylaxis group and one in the prophylaxis group, respectively.\n\n However, no difference in 30-day ICU mortality could be observed.\n\n Thirty-day CAPA incidence estimates were 1.4% (95% CI 0.2–9.7) in the MAFP group and 17.5% (95% CI 9.6–31.4) in the group without MAFP (p?=?0.002).\n\n The respective subdistributional hazard ratio (sHR) for CAPA incidence comparing the MAFP versus no MAFP group was of 0.08 (95% CI 0.01–0.63; p?=?0.017).\n\n\nConclusion\nid='Par4'>In ICU patients with COVID-19 ARF, antifungal prophylaxis was associated with significantly reduced CAPA incidence, but this did not translate into improved survival.\n\n Randomized controlled trials are warranted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of MAFP with respect to CAPA incidence and clinical outcomes.\n\n\nSupplementary Information\nThe online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s13054-021-03753-9.\n","id":"PMC8441945","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Stefan","surname":"Hatzl","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Alexander R.","surname":"Rosenkranz","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Thomas","surname":"Valentin","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Robert","surname":"Krause","email":"robert.krause@medunigraz.at","contributions":"4"},{"firstname":"Martin","surname":"Hoenigl","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Gernot","surname":"Schilcher","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.jfma.2022.07.006","date":"2022-07-18","title":"COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis is associated with increased in-hospital mortality and prolonged SARS-CoV-2 viral shedding","abstract":"Background/Purpose\nCoronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) is common in critically ill patients with COVID-19 and is associated with worse outcomes.\n\n However, reports on CAPA and its impact on treatment outcomes in Asian populations are limited.\n\n\nMethods\nPatients with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction-confirmed COVID-19 admitted to intensive care units (ICUs) were retrospectively enrolled in this observational study.\n\n The incidence rate of CAPA during ICU admission was investigated.\n\n The clinical factors associated with CAPA, including corticosteroid exposure, were analyzed.\n\n The impact of CAPA on the treatment outcomes and SARS-CoV-2 viral shedding were explored.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 72 ICU-admitted patients with COVID-19 were included in the analysis.\n\n The incidence rate of CAPA was 15.3% (11/72) in all patients and 23% (11/48) in the mechanically ventilated patients.\n\n The median time from ICU admission to CAPA diagnosis was 15 days.\n\n A lower fibrinogen level (adjusted odds ratio [aOR], 0.983; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.967–0.999) was independently associated with CAPA.\n\n The patients with CAPA had a higher in-hospital mortality rate (55% vs.\n\n 13%, p = 0.001) and a longer SARS-CoV-2 viral shedding time (22 days vs.\n\n 16 days, p = 0.037) than those without CAPA.\n\n\nConclusion\nLower serum fibrinogen levels was independently associated with CAPA among the ICU-admitted patients with COVID-19. The patients with CAPA had a higher in-hospital mortality rate and a longer SARS-CoV-2 viral shedding time than those without CAPA.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9359693","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jhong-Ru","surname":"Huang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Hsiao-Chin","surname":"Shen","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Chuan-Yen","surname":"Sun","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Wei-Chih","surname":"Chen","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Yuh-Min","surname":"Chen","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jia-Yih","surname":"Feng","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Kuang-Yao","surname":"Yang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.3201/eid2711.211174","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Multinational E.","surname":"Verweij","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3346/jkms.2022.37.e134","date":"2022-03-29","title":"Risk Factors for Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis in Critically Ill Patients: A Nationwide, Multicenter, Retrospective Cohort Study","abstract":"Background\nCoronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is often accompanied by secondary infections, such as invasive aspergillosis.\n\n In this study, risk factors for developing COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) and their clinical outcomes were evaluated.\n\n\nMethods\nThis multicenter retrospective cohort study included critically ill COVID-19 patients from July 2020 through March 2021. Critically ill patients were defined as patients requiring high-flow respiratory support or mechanical ventilation.\n\n CAPA was defined based on the 2020 European Confederation of Medical Mycology and the International Society for Human and Animal Mycology consensus criteria.\n\n Factors associated with CAPA were analyzed, and their clinical outcomes were adjusted by a propensity score-matched model.\n\n\nResults\nAmong 187 eligible patients, 17 (9.1%) developed CAPA, which is equal to 33.10 per 10,000 patient-days.\n\n Sixteen patients received voriconazole-based antifungal treatment.\n\n In addition, 82.4% and 53.5% of patients with CAPA and without CAPA, respectively, received early high-dose corticosteroids (P = 0.022).\n\n In multivariable analysis, initial 10-day cumulative steroid dose &gt; 60 mg of dexamethasone or dexamethasone equivalent dose) (adjusted odds ratio [OR], 3.77; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.03–13.79) and chronic pulmonary disease (adjusted OR, 4.20; 95% CI, 1.26–14.02) were independently associated with CAPA.\n\n Tendencies of higher 90-day overall mortality (54.3% vs.\n\n 35.2%, P = 0.346) and lower respiratory support-free rate were observed in patients with CAPA (76.3% vs.\n\n 54.9%, P = 0.089).\n\n\nConclusion\nOur study showed that the dose of corticosteroid use might be a risk factor for CAPA development and the possibility of CAPA contributing to adverse outcomes in critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9091428","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Si-Ho","surname":"Kim","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jin Analysis of 178 Patients","abstract":"Background: COVID-19-associated fungal infections seem to be a concerning issue.\n The aim of this study was to assess the incidence of fungal infections, the possible risk factors, and their effect on outcomes of critically ill patients with COVID-19. Methods: A retrospective observational study was conducted in the COVID-19 ICU of the First Respiratory Department of National and Kapodistrian University of Athens in Sotiria Chest Diseases Hospital between 27 August 2020 and 10 November 2021. Results: Here, 178 patients were included in the study.\n Nineteen patients (10.7%) developed fungal infection, of which five had COVID-19 associated candidemia, thirteen had COVID-19 associated pulmonary aspergillosis, and one had both.\n Patients with fungal infection were younger, had a lower Charlson Comorbidity Index, and had a lower PaO2/FiO2 ratio upon admission.\n Regarding health-care factors, patients with fungal infections were treated more frequently with Tocilizumab, a high regimen of dexamethasone, continuous renal replacement treatment, and were supported more with ECMO.\n They also had more complications, especially infections, and subsequently developed septic shock more frequently.\n Finally, patients with fungal infections had a longer length of ICU stay, as well as length of mechanical ventilation, although no statistically significant difference was reported on 28-day and 90-day mortality.\n Conclusions: Fungal infections seem to have a high incidence in COVID-19 critically ill patients and specific risk factors are identified.\n However, fungal infections do not seem to burden on mortality.\n","id":"PMC9410292","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Evangelia","surname":"Koukaki","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Nikoletta","surname":"Rovina","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Nikoletta","surname":"Rovina","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kimon","surname":"Tzannis","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Kimon","surname":"Tzannis","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Zoi","surname":"Sotiropoulou","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Konstantinos","surname":"Loverdos","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Antonia","surname":"Koutsoukou","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"George","surname":"Dimopoulos","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"David S.","surname":"Perlin","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3904/kjim.2022.069","date":"2022-03-30","title":"Risk factors and clinical impact of COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis: Multicenter retrospective cohort study","abstract":"Background/Aims\nThe risk factors and clinical impacts of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) remain controversial, and no data have been reported in Korea.\n\n This study aimed to investigate the epidemiology and importance of CAPA diagnostic efforts and to identify the predictors of CAPA and the impacts on clinical outcomes.\n\n\nMethods\nBetween January 2020 and May 2021, data of severely to critically ill COVID-19 patients were extracted from seven hospitals of the Catholic Medical Center through a clinical data warehouse.\n\n Corticosteroid use was subcategorized into total cumulative dose, early 7-day dose, mean daily dose, and duration of use.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 2,427 patients were screened, and 218 patients were included.\n\n CAPA was diagnosed in 4.6% (10/218) of all hospitalized and 11.2% (10/89) of intensive care unit patients.\n\n Total cumulative dose (over 1,000 mg as methylprednisolone) and daily high-dose corticosteroid use (over 60 mg/day) were independent predictors but not early 7-day high-dose corticosteroid use (over 420 mg/week) (odds ratio [OR], 1.731; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.350 to 8.571) nor prolonged use (OR, 2.794; 95% CI, 0.635 to 13.928).\n\n In-hospital overall mortality was 11.9% (26 of 218).\n\n CAPA itself did not affect the outcome; rather, daily high-dose steroid use significantly increased the 30-day mortality (hazard ratio, 5.645; 95% CI, 1.225 to 26.091).\n\n\nConclusions\nCAPA was not uncommon, especially in critically ill patients.\n\n Daily high-dose corticosteroid use was the predictor of CAPA and associated with high mortality rates.\n\n High-dose corticosteroids use after early inflammatory phase should be avoided, and active surveillance methods for CAPA are essential for those high-risk patients.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9271713","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Raeseok","surname":"Lee","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sung-Yeon","surname":"Cho","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Dong-Gun","surname":"Lee","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Hyojin","surname":"Ahn","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Hyojin","surname":"Ahn","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hyeah","surname":"Choi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Su-Mi","surname":"Choi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jae-Ki","surname":"Choi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jung-Hyun","surname":"Choi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Shin Jeong","surname":"Kim","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Hyo-Jin","surname":"Lee","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/s13054-022-03902-8","date":"2022-01-16","title":"Corticosteroids as risk factor for COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis in intensive care patients","abstract":"Purpose\nid='Par1'>Corticosteroids, in particular dexamethasone, are one of the primary treatment options for critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n\n However, there are a growing number of cases that involve COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA), and it is unclear whether dexamethasone represents a risk factor for CAPA.\n\n Our aim was to investigate a possible association of the recommended dexamethasone therapy with a risk of CAPA.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>We performed a study based on a cohort of COVID-19 patients treated in 2020 in our 13 intensive care units at Charité Universitätsmedizin Berlin.\n\n We used ECMM/ISHM criteria for the CAPA diagnosis and performed univariate and multivariable analyses of clinical parameters to identify risk factors that could result in a diagnosis of CAPA.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>Altogether, among the n?=?522 intensive care patients analyzed, n?=?47 (9%) patients developed CAPA.\n\n CAPA patients had a higher simplified acute physiology score (SAPS) (64 vs.\n\n 53, p?&lt;?0.001) and higher levels of IL-6 (1,005 vs.\n\n 461, p?&lt;?0.008).\n\n They more often had severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) (60% vs.\n\n 41%, p?=?0.024), renal replacement therapy (60% vs.\n\n 41%, p?=?0.024), and they were more likely to die (64% vs.\n\n 48%, p?=?0.049).\n\n The multivariable analysis showed dexamethasone (OR 3.110, CI95 1.112–8.697) and SAPS (OR 1.063, CI95 1.028–1.098) to be independent risk factors for CAPA.\n\n\nConclusion\nid='Par4'>In our study, dexamethasone therapy as recommended for COVID-19 was associated with a significant three times increase in the risk of CAPA.\n\n\n\nTrial registration\n\nid='Par5'>Registration number DRKS00024578, Date of registration March 3rd, 2021.\nSupplementary Information\nThe online version contains supplementary material available at Pulmonary Aspergillosis in a Tertiary Hospital","abstract":"Our study aims to assess the prevalence of CAPA (COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis) and describe the associated risk factors and their impact on mortality.\n A prospective study was conducted.\n We included patients with COVID-19 disease who were admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of respiratory failur.\n Mycological culture and other biomarkers (calcofluor staining, LFD, LFA, PCR, GM, and B-D-glucan) were performed.\n A total of 300 patients were included in the study.\n Thirty-five patients were diagnosed with CAPA (prevalence 11.7%).\n During admission, 57 patients died (19%), and, in the group of CAPA patients, mortality was 31.4%.\n In multivariate analysis, independent risk factors associated with CAPA diagnosis were age (OR: 1.05; 95% CI 1.01–1.09; p = 0.037), chronic lung disease (OR: 3.85; 95% CI 1.02–14.9; p = 0.049) and treatment with tocilizumab during admission (OR: 14.5; 95% 6.1–34.9; p = 0.001).\n Factors independently associated with mortality were age (OR: 1.06; 95% CI 1.01–1.11; p = 0.014) and CAPA diagnosis during admission (OR: 3.34; 95% CI 1.38–8.08; p = 0.007).\n CAPA is an infection that appears in many patients with COVID-19 disease.\n CAPA is associated with high mortality rates, which may be reduced by early diagnosis and initiation of appropriate antifungal therapy, so screening of COVID-19 ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome) patients for CAPA is Amphotericin B in Mechanically Ventilated COVID-19 Patients to Prevent Invasive Pulmonary Aspergillosis: A Retrospective Cohort Study","abstract":"OBJECTIVES:\nTo assess the CAPA incidence in COVID-19 patients on IMV treated with and without nebulized c-AmB as antifungal prophylaxis.\n\n\nDESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS:\nRetrospective cohort study of consecutive COVID-19 patients admitted to our adult 17-bed ICU in a university-affiliated general hospital in Ede, The Netherlands, between January 25, 2021, and July 9, 2021. Patients not requiring IMV or transferred from or to another ICU were excluded.\n\n From April 9, 2021, daily nebulized amphotericin B in all patients on IMV was initiated.\n\n\nMAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES:\nBronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) was performed in case of positive cultures for Aspergillus from the respiratory tract and/or unexplained respiratory deterioration.\n\n Incidence of probable and proven CAPA was compared between patients treated with and without nebulized antifungal prophylaxis using Pearson chi-square test.\n\n\nRESULTS:\nA total of 39 intubated COVID-19 patients could be analyzed, of which 16 were treated with antifungal prophylaxis and 23 were not.\n\n Twenty-six patients underwent bronchoscopy with BAL.\n\n In patients treated with antifungal prophylaxis, the incidence of probable/proven CAPA was significantly lower when compared with no antifungal prophylaxis (27% vs 67%; p = 0.047).\n\n Incidence of tracheobronchial lesions and positive Aspergillus cultures and BAL-galactomannan was significantly lower in patients treated with antifungal prophylaxis (9% vs 47%; p = 0.040, 9% vs 53%; p = 0.044, and 20% vs 60%; p = 0.047, respectively).\n\n No treatment-related adverse events and no case of proven CAPA were encountered in patients receiving antifungal prophylaxis.\n\n\nCONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE:\nNebulization of c-AmB in critically ill COVID-19 patients on IMV is safe and may be considered as antifungal prophylaxis to prevent CAPA.\n\n However, a randomized controlled trial to confirm this is warranted.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9088229","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Max","surname":"Melchers","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Arthur R. W.","surname":"van Bree","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1093/cid/ciab223","date":"1970-01-01","title":"COVID-19 Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis in Mechanically Ventilated Patients","abstract":"Background\nCOVID-19 associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) occurs in critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n\n Risks and outcomes remain poorly understood.\n\n\nMethods\nA retrospective cohort study of adult mechanically ventilated COVID-19 patients admitted to five Johns Hopkins hospitals was conducted between March and August 2020. CAPA was defined using composite clinical criteria.\n\n Fine and Gray competing risks regression was used to analyze clinical outcomes and multilevel mixed-effects ordinal logistic regression was used to compare longitudinal disease severity scores.\n\n\nResults\nAmongst the cohort of 396 people, 39 met criteria for CAPA.\n\n Compared to those without, patients with CAPA were more likely to have underlying pulmonary vascular disease (41% vs 21.6%, p=0.01), liver disease (35.9% vs 18.2%, p=0.02), coagulopathy (51.3% vs 33.1%, p=0.03), solid tumors (25.6% vs 10.9%, p=0.017), multiple myeloma (5.1% vs 0.3%, p=0.027), corticosteroid exposure during index admission (66.7% vs 42.6%, p=0.005), and had a lower BMI (median 26.6 vs 29.9, p=0.04).\n\n People with CAPA had worse outcomes as measured by ordinal severity of disease scores, requiring longer time to improvement (adjusted odds ratio 1.081.091.1, p&lt;0.001), and advancing in severity almost twice as fast (subhazard ratio, sHR 1.31.82.5, p&lt;0.001).\n\n People with CAPA were intubated twice as long as those without (sHR) 0.40.50.6, p&lt;0.001) and had a longer hospital length of stay [median (IQR) 41.1 (20.5, 72.4) vs 18.5 (10.7, 31.8), p&lt;0.001].\n\n\nConclusion\nCAPA is associated with poor outcomes.\n\n Attention towards preventative measures (screening and/or prophylaxis) is warranted in people with high risk of developing CAPA.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7989534","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Nitipong","surname":"Permpalung","email":"npermpa1@jhmi.edu","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Teresa A","surname":"Marr","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.cmi.2021.08.014","date":"2021-08-16","title":"Risk factors and outcome of pulmonary aspergillosis in critically ill coronavirus disease 2019 patients—a multinational observational study by the European Confederation of Medical Mycology","abstract":"Objectives\nCoronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) -associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) has emerged as a complication in critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n\n The objectives of this multinational study were to determine the prevalence of CAPA in patients with COVID-19 in intensive care units (ICU) and to investigate risk factors for CAPA as well as outcome.\n\n\nMethods\nThe European Confederation of Medical Mycology (ECMM) conducted a multinational study including 20 centres from nine countries to assess epidemiology, risk factors and outcome of CAPA.\n\n CAPA was defined according to the 2020 ECMM/ISHAM consensus definitions.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 592 patients were included in this study, including 11 (1.9%) patients with histologically proven CAPA, 80 (13.5%) with probable CAPA, 18 (3%) with possible CAPA and 483 (81.6%) without CAPA.\n\n CAPA was diagnosed a median of 8 days (range 0–31 days) after ICU admission predominantly in older patients (adjusted hazard ratio (aHR) 1.04 per year; 95% CI 1.02–1.06) with any form of invasive respiratory support (HR 3.4; 95% CI 1.84–6.25) and receiving tocilizumab (HR 2.45; 95% CI 1.41–4.25).\n\n Median prevalence of CAPA per centre was 10.7% (range 1.7%–26.8%).\n\n CAPA was associated with significantly lower 90-day ICU survival rate (29% in patients with CAPA versus 57% in patients without CAPA; Mantel–Byar p &lt; 0.001) and remained an independent negative prognostic variable after adjusting for other predictors of survival (HR 2.14; 95% CI 1.59–2.87, p ? 0.001).\n\n\nConclusion\nPrevalence of CAPA varied between centres.\n\n CAPA was significantly more prevalent among older patients, patients receiving invasive ventilation and patients receiving tocilizumab, and was an independent strong predictor of ICU mortality.\n\n\n","id":"PMC8387556","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Juergen","surname":"Prattes","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Joost","surname":"Wauters","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Daniele pulmonary aspergillosis among intubated patients with SARS-CoV-2 or influenza pneumonia: a European multicenter comparative cohort study","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Recent multicenter studies identified COVID-19 as a risk factor for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA).\n\n However, no large multicenter study has compared the incidence of IPA between COVID-19 and influenza patients.\n\n\nObjectives\nid='Par2'>To determine the incidence of putative IPA in critically ill SARS-CoV-2 patients, compared with influenza patients.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par3'>This study was a planned ancillary analysis of the coVAPid multicenter retrospective European cohort.\n\n Consecutive adult patients requiring invasive mechanical ventilation for?&gt;?48 h for SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia or influenza pneumonia were included.\n\n The 28-day cumulative incidence of putative IPA, based on Blot definition, was the primary outcome.\n\n IPA incidence was estimated using the Kalbfleisch and Prentice method, considering extubation (dead or alive) within 28 days as competing event.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par4'>A total of 1047 patients were included (566 in the SARS-CoV-2 group and 481 in the influenza group).\n\n The incidence of putative IPA was lower in SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia group (14, 2.5%) than in influenza pneumonia group (29, 6%), adjusted cause-specific hazard ratio (cHR) 3.29 (95% CI 1.53–7.02, p?=?0.0006).\n\n When putative IPA and Aspergillus respiratory tract colonization were combined, the incidence was also significantly lower in the SARS-CoV-2 group, as compared to influenza group (4.1% vs.\n\n 10.2%), adjusted cHR 3.21 (95% CI 1.88–5.46, p?&lt;?0.0001).\n\n In the whole study population, putative IPA was associated with significant increase in 28-day mortality rate, and length of ICU stay, compared with colonized patients, or those with no IPA or Aspergillus colonization.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par5'>Overall, the incidence of putative IPA was low.\n\n Its incidence was significantly lower in patients with SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia than in those with influenza pneumonia.\n\n\nSupplementary Information\nThe online version contains supplementary material invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in a tertiary care center in Mexico City","abstract":"NULL\nInvasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) is a severe infection caused by aspergillus sp.\n\n that usually develops in patients with severe immunosuppression.\n\n IPA has been recently described in critically ill COVID-19 patients (termed as COVID-associated pulmonary aspergillosis, or CAPA) that are otherwise immunocompetent.\n\n In order to describe the characteristics of patients with CAPA, we conducted a retrospective cohort study in a tertiary care center in Mexico City.\n\n We included all patients with confirmed COVID-19 admitted to the intensive care unit that had serum or bronchoalveolar lavage galactomannan measurements.\n\n We used the criteria proposed by Koehler et al.\n\n to establish the diagnosis of CAPA.\n\n Main outcomes were the need for invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV) and in-hospital mortality.\n\n Out of a total of 83 hospitalized patients with COVID-19 in the ICU, 16 (19.3%) met the criteria for CAPA.\n\n All patients diagnosed with CAPA required IMV whereas only 84% of the patients in the non-IPA group needed this intervention (P = 0.09).\n\n In the IPA group, 31% (n = 5) of the patients died, compared to 13% (n = 9) in the non-CAPA group (P = 0.08).\n\n We conclude that CAPA is a frequent co-infection in critically ill COVID-19 patients and is associated with a high mortality rate.\n\n The timely diagnosis and treatment of IPA in these patients is likely to improve their outcome.\n\n\nLay Summary\nWe studied the characteristics of patients with COVID-19-associated invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA).\n\n Patients with CAPA tended to need invasive mechanical ventilation more frequently and to have a higher mortality rate.\n\n Adequate resources for its management can improve their outcome\n","id":"PMC7989422","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Mariana","surname":"Vélez national strategy to diagnose COVID-19 associated invasive fungal disease in the ICU","abstract":"Background\nFungal co-infection is a recognised complication of respiratory virus infections, increasing morbidity and mortality, but can be readily treated if diagnosed early.\n\n An increasing number of small studies describing aspergillosis in COVID-19 patients with severe respiratory distress are being reported, but comprehensive data is lacking.\n\n The aim of this study was to determine the incidence, risk factors and impact of invasive fungal disease in adult COVID-19 patients with severe respiratory distress.\n\n\nMethods\nAn evaluation of a national, multi-centre, prospective cohort evaluation of an enhanced testing strategy to diagnose invasive fungal disease in COVID-19 intensive care patients.\n\n Results were used to generate a mechanism to define aspergillosis in future COVID-19 patients.\n\n\nResults\nOne-hundred and thirty-five adults (median age: 57, M/F: 2·2/1) were screened.\n\n The incidence was 26.7% (14.1% aspergillosis, 12·6% yeast infections).\n\n The overall mortality rate was 38%; 53% and 31% in patients with and without fungal disease, respectively (P: 0.0387).\n\n The mortality rate was reduced by the use of antifungal therapy (Mortality: 38·5% in patients receiving therapy versus 90% in patients not receiving therapy (P: 0.008).\n\n The use of corticosteroids (P: 0.007) and history of chronic respiratory disease (P: 0.05) increased the likelihood of aspergillosis.\n\n\nConclusions\nFungal disease occurs frequently in critically ill, mechanically ventilated COVID-19 patients.\n\n The survival benefit observed in patients receiving antifungal therapy implies that the proposed diagnostic and defining criteria are appropriate.\n\n Screening using a strategic diagnostic approach and antifungal prophylaxis of patients with risk factors will likely enhance the management of COVID-19 patients.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7499527","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"P (COVID-19) Treated With Remdesivir and Dexamethasone. A Nationwide Population-Based Cohort Study","abstract":"Background\nThere are limited data on outcomes of moderate to severe coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) among patients treated with remdesivir and dexamethasone in a real-world setting.\n\n We sought to compare the effectiveness of standard of care (SOC) alone versus SOC plus remdesivir and dexamethasone.\n\n\nMethods\nTwo population-based nationwide cohorts of individuals hospitalized with COVID-19 during February through December 2020 were studied.\n\n Death within 30 days and need of mechanical ventilation (MV) were compared by inverse probability of treatment weighted (ITPW) logistic regression analysis and shown as odds ratio (OR) with 95% confidence interval (CI).\n\n\nResults\nThe 30-days mortality rate of 1694 individuals treated with remdesivir and dexamethasone in addition to SOC was 12.6% compared to 19.7% for 1053 individuals receiving SOC alone.\n\n This corresponded to a weighted OR of 30-day mortality of 0.47 (95% CI: .\n\n38–.\n\n57) for patients treated with remdesivir and dexamethasone compared to patients receiving SOC alone.\n\n Similarly, progression to MV was reduced (OR 0.36; 95% CI: .\n\n29–.\n\n46).\n\n\nConclusions\nTreatment of moderate to severe COVID-19 during June through December that included remdesivir and dexamethasone was associated with reduced 30-day mortality and need of MV compared to treatment in February through May.\n\n\n","id":"PMC8344480","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Thomas","surname":"Benfield","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jacob","surname":"Bodilsen","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Jacob","surname":"Bodilsen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Christian","surname":"Brieghel","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Zitta Without Remdesivir Treatment in Hospitalized Patients With COVID-19","abstract":"Question\nDoes time to clinical improvement or time to death differ among hospitalized patients treated with vs without remdesivir (alone or with corticosteroids) for coronavirus disease 2019 outside of a clinical trial?\nFindings\nIn this multicenter comparative effectiveness research study that included 2483 consecutive admissions with a high proportion of non-White individuals, treatment with remdesivir was associated with more rapid clinical improvement than no remdesivir receipt in propensity score–matched controls.\n\n The addition of corticosteroids to remdesivir was not associated with improved time to death.\n\n\nMeaning\nRemdesivir administration is associated with more rapid clinical Caleb","surname":"Alexander","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Amita","surname":"Gupta","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Robert","surname":"Bollinger","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Yanxun","surname":"Xu","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1056/NEJMoa2100433","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Interleukin-6 Receptor Antagonists in Critically Ill Patients with Covid-19","abstract":"Background\nThe efficacy of interleukin-6 receptor antagonists in critically ill patients with coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) is unclear.\n\n\nMethods\nWe evaluated tocilizumab and sarilumab in an ongoing international, multifactorial, adaptive platform trial.\n\n Adult patients with Covid-19, within 24 hours after starting organ support in the intensive care unit (ICU), were randomly assigned to receive tocilizumab (8 mg per kilogram of body weight), sarilumab (400 mg), or standard care (control).\n\n The primary outcome was respiratory and cardiovascular organ support–free days, on an ordinal scale combining in-hospital death (assigned a value of ?1) and days free of organ support to day 21. The trial uses a Bayesian statistical model with predefined criteria for superiority, efficacy, equivalence, or futility.\n\n An odds ratio greater than 1 represented improved survival, more organ support–free days, or both.\n\n\nResults\nBoth tocilizumab and sarilumab met the predefined criteria for efficacy.\n\n At that time, 353 patients had been assigned to tocilizumab, 48 to sarilumab, and 402 to control.\n\n The median number of organ support–free days was 10 (interquartile range, ?1 to 16) in the tocilizumab group, 11 (interquartile range, 0 to 16) in the sarilumab group, and 0 (interquartile range, ?1 to 15) in the control group.\n\n The median adjusted cumulative odds ratios were 1.64 (95% credible interval, 1.25 to 2.14) for tocilizumab and 1.76 (95% credible interval, 1.17 to 2.91) for sarilumab as compared with control, yielding posterior probabilities of superiority to control of more than 99.9% and of 99.5%, respectively.\n\n An analysis of 90-day survival showed improved survival in the pooled interleukin-6 receptor antagonist groups, yielding a hazard ratio for the comparison with the control group of 1.61 (95% credible interval, 1.25 to 2.08) and a posterior probability of superiority of more than 99.9%.\n\n All secondary analyses supported efficacy of these interleukin-6 receptor antagonists.\n\n\nConclusions\nIn critically ill patients with Covid-19 receiving organ support in ICUs, treatment with the interleukin-6 receptor antagonists tocilizumab and sarilumab improved outcomes, including survival.\n\n (REMAP-CAP ClinicalTrials.\n\ngov number, NCT02735707.\n\n)\n","id":"PMC7953461","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"NULL","surname":"NULL","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.eclinm.2022.101489","date":"2022-05-16","title":"Baricitinib in hospitalised patients with COVID-19: A meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials","abstract":"Background\nTo date, only dexamethasone and tocilizumab have been shown to reduce mortality in patients with COVID-19. Baricitinib is a Janus kinase 1/2 inhibitor with known anti-inflammatory and anti-viral properties.\n\n We performed a meta-analysis of RCTs assessing the role of baricitinib in hospitalised patients with COVID-19.\nMethods\nElectronic databases such as MEDLINE, EMBASE, and Cochrane Central were searched up until March 31, 2022, for RCTs evaluating the efficacy of baricitinib in hospitalised patients with COVID-19. The outcomes assessed were 28-day mortality, progression to invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV) or ECMO, progression to respiratory failure needing positive pressure ventilation, IMV or death, duration of hospitalisation and time to discharge.\n\n The meta-analysis was registered in the PROSPERO database (CRD42022314579).\n\n\nFindings\nFour studies (with 10,815 patients) were included in the analysis.\n\n Pooled analysis using random-effects model showed a statistically significant reduction in 28-day mortality (OR 0.69, 95% CI 0.50-0.94; p=0.04, I2=65%) and composite outcome of progression to severe disease needing positive pressure ventilation, IMV or death (OR 0.89, 95% CI 0.80-0.99, p= 0.03, I2=0%).\n\n There was a favorable trend towards reduced progression to IMV or ECMO (OR 0.76, 95% CI 0.58-1.01; p=0.06, I2=49%) in the baricitinib arm compared to standard therapy, even though it was not statistically significant.\n\n Statistical significance was achieved for all outcomes with fixed-effects model analysis.\n\n\nInterpretation\nIn hospitalised patients with COVID-19, baricitinib was associated with reduced 28-day mortality although there was not a statistically significant reduction in progression to IMV or ECMO.\n\n Baricitinib used in conjunction with standard of care treatments is associated with improved mortality in hospitalised patients with COVID-19 disease.\n\n\nFunding\nNone.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9163705","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Vijairam","surname":"Selvaraj","email":"vijairam.selvaraj@lifespan.org","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Arkadiy","surname":"Finn","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Amos","surname":"Lal","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Mohammad Saud","surname":"Khan","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Kwame","surname":"Dapaah-Afriyie","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Gerardo P.","surname":"Carino","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/S2213-2600(22)00297-1","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Anti-C5a antibody (vilobelimab) therapy for critically ill, invasively mechanically ventilated patients with COVID-19 (PANAMO): a multicentre, double-blind, randomised, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial","abstract":"Background\nVilobelimab, an anti-C5a monoclonal antibody, was shown to be safe in a phase 2 trial of invasively mechanically ventilated patients with COVID-19. Here, we aimed to determine whether vilobelimab in addition to standard of care improves survival outcomes in this patient population.\n\n\nMethods\nThis randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multicentre phase 3 trial was performed at 46 hospitals in the Netherlands, Germany, France, Belgium, Russia, Brazil, Peru, Mexico, and South Africa.\n\n Participants aged 18 years or older who were receiving invasive mechanical ventilation, but not more than 48 h after intubation at time of first infusion, had a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 60–200 mm Hg, and a confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection with any variant in the past 14 days were eligible for this study.\n\n Eligible patients were randomly assigned (1:1) to receive standard of care and vilobelimab at a dose of 800 mg intravenously for a maximum of six doses (days 1, 2, 4, 8, 15, and 22) or standard of care and a matching placebo using permuted block randomisation.\n\n Treatment was not continued after hospital discharge.\n\n Participants, caregivers, and assessors were masked to group assignment.\n\n The primary outcome was defined as all-cause mortality at 28 days in the full analysis set (defined as all randomly assigned participants regardless of whether a patient started treatment, excluding patients randomly assigned in error) and measured using Kaplan-Meier analysis.\n\n Safety analyses included all patients who had received at least one infusion of either vilobelimab or placebo.\n\n This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.\n\ngov, NCT04333420.\n\n\nFindings\nFrom Oct 1, 2020, to Oct 4, 2021, we included 368 patients in the ITT analysis (full analysis set; 177 in the vilobelimab group and 191 in the placebo group).\n\n One patient in the vilobelimab group was excluded from the primary analysis due to random assignment in error without treatment.\n\n At least one dose of study treatment was given to 364 (99%) patients (safety analysis set).\n\n 54 patients (31%) of 177 in the vilobelimab group and 77 patients (40%) of 191 in the placebo group died in the first 28 days.\n\n The all-cause mortality rate at 28 days was 32% (95% CI 25–39) in the vilobelimab group and 42% (35–49) in the placebo group (hazard ratio 0·73, 95% CI 0·50–1·06; p=0·094).\n\n In the predefined analysis without site-stratification, vilobelimab significantly reduced all-cause mortality at 28 days (HR 0·67, 95% CI 0·48–0·96; p=0·027).\n\n The most common TEAEs were acute kidney injury (35 [20%] of 175 in the vilobelimab group vs 40 [21%] of 189 in the placebo), pneumonia (38 [22%] vs 26 [14%]), and septic shock (24 [14%] vs 31 [16%]).\n\n Serious treatment-emergent adverse events were reported in 103 (59%) of 175 patients in the vilobelimab group versus 120 (63%) of 189 in the placebo group.\n\n\nInterpretation\nIn addition to standard of care, vilobelimab improves survival of invasive mechanically ventilated patients with COVID-19 and leads to a significant decrease in mortality.\n\n Vilobelimab could be considered as an additional therapy for patients in this setting and further research is needed on the role of vilobelimab and C5a in other acute respiratory distress syndrome-causing viral infections.\n\n\nFunding\nInflaRx and the German Federal Government.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9451499","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Alexander P Care and Organ Support Related Mortality in Patients With COVID-19: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis","abstract":"DATA SOURCES:\nA systematic search of PubMed, Embase, and the Cochrane databases was conducted up to December 31, 2021.\nSTUDY SELECTION:\nPreviously peer-reviewed observational studies that reported ICU, mechanical ventilation (MV), renal replacement therapy (RRT) or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)-related mortality among greater than or equal to 100 individual patients.\n\n\nDATA EXTRACTION:\nRandom-effects meta-analysis was used to generate pooled estimates of case fatality rates (CFRs) for in-hospital, ICU, MV, RRT, and ECMO-related mortality.\n\n ICU-related mortality was additionally analyzed by the study country of origin.\n\n Sensitivity analyses of CFR were assessed based on completeness of follow-up data, by year, and when only studies judged to be of high quality were included.\n\n\nDATA SYNTHESIS:\nOne hundred fifty-seven studies evaluating 948,309 patients were included.\n\n The CFR for in-hospital mortality, ICU mortality, MV, RRT, and ECMO were 25.9% (95% CI: 24.0–27.8%), 37.3% (95% CI: 34.6–40.1%), 51.6% (95% CI: 46.1–57.0%), 66.1% (95% CI: 59.7–72.2%), and 58.0% (95% CI: 46.9–68.9%), respectively.\n\n MV (52.7%, 95% CI: 47.5–58.0% vs 31.3%, 95% CI: 16.1–48.9%; p = 0.023) and RRT-related mortality (66.7%, 95% CI: 60.1–73.0% vs 50.3%, 95% CI: 42.4–58.2%; p = 0.003) decreased from 2020 to 2021.\nCONCLUSIONS:\nWe present updated estimates of CFR for patients hospitalized and requiring intensive care for the management of COVID-19. Although mortality remain high and varies considerably worldwide, we found the CFR in patients supported with MV significantly improved since 2020.\n","id":"PMC9988289","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Abhimanyu","surname":"Chandel","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sahar","surname":"Leazer","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Karl found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1038/s41564-022-01172-2","date":"2022-06-13","title":"COVID-19-associated fungal infections","abstract":"id='Par1'>Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)-associated invasive fungal infections are an important complication in a substantial number of critically ill, hospitalized patients with COVID-19. fungal infections caused by these fungi in low-, middle- and high-income countries.\n By evaluating the epidemiology, clinical risk factors, predisposing features of the host environment and and outcomes of co-infection and superinfection with SARS-CoV-2 and other pathogens: A systematic review and meta-analysis","abstract":"Introduction\nThe recovery of other pathogens in patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection has been reported, either at the time of a SARS-CoV-2 infection diagnosis (co-infection) or subsequently (superinfection).\n\n However, data on the prevalence, microbiology, and outcomes of co-infection and superinfection are limited.\n\n The purpose of this study was to examine the occurrence of co-infections and superinfections and their outcomes among patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection.\n\n\nPatients and methods\nWe searched literature databases for studies published from October 1, 2019, through February 8, 2021. We included studies that reported clinical features and outcomes of co-infection or superinfection of SARS-CoV-2 and other pathogens in hospitalized and non-hospitalized patients.\n\n We followed PRISMA guidelines, and we registered the protocol with PROSPERO as: CRD42020189763.\nResults\nOf 6639 articles screened, 118 were included in the random effects meta-analysis.\n\n The pooled prevalence of co-infection was 19% (95% confidence interval [CI]: 14%-25%, I2 = 98%) and that of superinfection was 24% (95% CI: 19%-30%).\n\n Pooled prevalence of pathogen type stratified by co- or superinfection were: viral co-infections, 10% (95% CI: 6%-14%); viral superinfections, 4% (95% CI: 0%-10%); bacterial co-infections, 8% (95% CI: 5%-11%); bacterial superinfections, 20% (95% CI: 13%-28%); fungal co-infections, 4% (95% CI: 2%-7%); and fungal superinfections, 8% (95% CI: 4%-13%).\n\n Patients with a co-infection or superinfection had higher odds of dying than those who only had SARS-CoV-2 infection (odds ratio = 3.31, 95% CI: 1.82–5.99).\n\n Compared to those with co-infections, patients with superinfections had a higher prevalence of mechanical ventilation (45% [95% CI: 33%-58%] vs.\n\n 10% [95% CI: 5%-16%]), but patients with co-infections had a greater average length of hospital stay than those with superinfections (mean = 29.0 days, standard deviation [SD] = 6.7 vs.\n\n mean = 16 days, SD = 6.2, respectively).\n\n\nConclusions\nOur study showed that as many as 19% of patients with COVID-19 have co-infections and 24% have superinfections.\n\n The presence of either co-infection or superinfection was associated with poor outcomes, including increased mortality.\n\n Our findings support the need for diagnostic testing to identify and treat co-occurring respiratory infections among patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection.\n\n\n","id":"PMC8101968","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jackson C","surname":"Huber","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.jointm.2021.07.001","date":"2021-07-07","title":"COVID-19-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis (CAPA)","abstract":"Invasive Pulmonary Aspergillosis (IPA) has been recognized as a possible secondary infection complicating Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and increasing mortality.\n The aim of this review was to report and summarize the available data in the literature concerning the incidence, pathophysiology, diagnosis, and treatment of COVID-19-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis (CAPA).\n Currently, the incidence of CAPA is unclear due to different definitions and diagnostic criteria used among the studies.\n It was estimated that approximately 8.6% (206/2383) of mechanically ventilated patients were diagnosed with either proven, probable, or putative CAPA.\n Classical host factors of invasive aspergillosis are rarely recognized in patients with CAPA, who are mainly immuno-competent presenting with comorbidities, while the role of steroids warrants further investigation.\n Direct epithelial injury and diffuse pulmonary micro thrombi in combination with immune dysregulation, hyper inflammatory response, and immunosuppressive treatment may be implicated.\n Discrimination between two forms of CAPA (e.\ng.\n, tracheobronchial and parenchymal) is required, whereas radiological signs of aspergillosis are not typically evident in patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia.\n In previous studies, the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer/Mycoses Study Group (EORTC/MSG) criteria, a clinical algorithm to diagnose Invasive Pulmonary Aspergillosis in intensive care unit patients (AspICU algorithm), and influenza-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (IAPA) criteria were used for the diagnosis of proven/probable and putative CAPA, as well as the differentiation from colonization, which can be challenging.\n Aspergillus fumigatus is the most commonly isolated pathogen in respiratory cultures.\n Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) and serum galactomannan (GM), ?-d-glucan (with limited specificity), polymerase chain reaction (PCR), and Aspergillus-specific lateral-flow device test can be included in the diagnostic work-up; however, these approaches are characterized by low sensitivity.\n Early treatment of CAPA is necessary, and 71.4% (135/189) of patients received antifungal therapy, mainly with voriconazole, isavuconazole, and liposomal amphotericin B .\n Given the high mortality rate among patients with Aspergillus infection, the administration of prophylactic treatment is debated.\n In conclusion, different diagnostic strategies are necessary to differentiate colonization from bronchial or parenchymal infection in intubated COVID-19 patients with Aspergillus spp.\n in their respiratory specimens vs.\n those not infected with severe acute respiratory syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).\n Following confirmation, voriconazole or isavuconazole should be used for the treatment of CAPA.\n","id":"PMC8346330","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"George","surname":"Dimopoulos","email":"gdimop@med.uoa.gr","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Maria-Panagiota","surname":"Almyroudi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Pavlos","surname":"Myrianthefs","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jordi","surname":"Rello","email":"jrello@crips.es","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1111/myc.13183","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Bronchoscopy overtreated infection?","abstract":"Recent findings\nThe incidence of CAPA ranges 3--28% of critically ill patients, depending on the definition used, study design, and systematic or triggered screening.\n\n COVID-19 is associated with direct damage of the respiratory epithelium, immune dysregulation, and common use of immunosuppressive drugs which might promote Aspergillus respiratory tract colonization and invasion.\n\n Positive Aspergillus tests among COVID-19 critically patients might reflect colonization rather than invasive disease.\n\n CAPA usually appears during the second week after starting invasive mechanical ventilation and is independently associated with ICU mortality.\n\n\nSummary\nFurther studies are needed to validate CAPA case definitions, to determine the accurate incidence of CAPA in comparison to adequate controls, and its evolution during the pandemic.\n\n A pro-active diagnostic strategy, based on risk stratification, clinical assessment, and bronchoalveolar lavage could be recommended to provide early antifungal treatment in patients with high probability of CAPA and clinical deterioration.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9593325","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Anahita","surname":"Rouzé","email":"anahita.rouze@chru-lille.fr","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ignacio","surname":"Martin-Loeches","email":"drmartinloeches@gmail.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Saad","surname":"Nseir","email":"saadalla.nseir@chu-lille.fr","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1007/s00134-021-06449-4","date":"2021-05-28","title":"Taskforce report on the diagnosis and clinical management of COVID-19 associated pulmonary aspergillosis","abstract":"Purpose\nid='Par1'>Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) is increasingly reported in patients with severe coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU).\n\n Diagnosis and management of COVID-19 associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) are challenging and our aim was to develop practical guidance.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>A group of 28 international experts reviewed current insights in the epidemiology, diagnosis and management of CAPA and developed recommendations using GRADE methodology.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>The prevalence of CAPA varied between 0 and 33%, which may be partly due to variable case definitions, but likely represents true variation.\n\n Bronchoscopy and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) remain the cornerstone of CAPA diagnosis, allowing for diagnosis of invasive Aspergillus tracheobronchitis and collection of the best validated specimen for Aspergillus diagnostics.\n\n Most patients diagnosed with CAPA lack traditional host factors, but pre-existing structural lung disease and immunomodulating therapy may predispose to CAPA risk.\n\n Computed tomography seems to be of limited value to rule CAPA in or out, and serum biomarkers are negative in 85% of patients.\n\n As the mortality of CAPA is around 50%, antifungal therapy is recommended for BAL positive patients, but the decision to treat depends on the patients’ clinical condition and the institutional incidence of CAPA.\n\n We recommend against routinely stopping concomitant corticosteroid or IL-6 blocking therapy in CAPA patients.\n\n\nConclusion\nid='Par4'>CAPA is a complex disease involving a continuum of respiratory colonization, tissue invasion and angioinvasive disease.\n\n Knowledge gaps including true epidemiology, optimal diagnostic work-up, management strategies and role of host-directed therapy require further study.\n\n\nSupplementary Information\nThe online version contains supplementary material available at found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1177/08850666211047166","date":"2021-09-01","title":"Practice Guidelines for the Diagnosis of COVID-19-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis in an Intensive Care Setting","abstract":"Coronavirus disease-2019 (COVID-19)-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) is a new disease characterized by secondary Aspergillus mold infection in patients with COVID-19. It primarily affects patients with COVID-19 in critical state with acute respiratory distress syndrome, requiring intensive care and mechanical ventilation.\n CAPA has a higher mortality rate than COVID-19, posing a serious threat to affected individuals.\n COVID-19 is a potential risk factor for CAPA and has already claimed a massive death toll worldwide since its outbreak in December 2019. Its second wave is currently progressing towards a peak, while the third wave of this devastating pandemic is expected to follow.\n Therefore, an early and accurate diagnosis of CAPA is of utmost importance for effective clinical management of this highly fatal disease.\n However, there are no uniform criteria for diagnosing CAPA in an intensive care setting.\n Therefore, based on a review of existing information and our own experience, we have proposed new criteria in the form of practice guidelines for diagnosing CAPA, focusing on the points relevant for intensivists and pulmonary and critical care physicians.\n The main highlights of these guidelines include the role of CAPA-appropriate test specimens, clinical risk factors, computed tomography of the thorax, and non-culture-based indirect and direct mycological evidence for diagnosing CAPA in the intensive care unit.\n These guidelines classify the diagnosis of CAPA into suspected, possible, and probable categories to facilitate clinical decision-making.\n We hope that these practice guidelines will adequately address the diagnostic challenges of CAPA, providing an easy-to-use and practical algorithm to clinicians for rapid diagnosis and clinical management of the disease.\n","id":"PMC9353310","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Zia","surname":"Hashim","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Zafar","surname":"Neyaz","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Rungmei K.","surname":"Tripathy","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1093/ofid/ofad062","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Risk of Coronavirus Disease 2019–Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis Based on Corticosteroid Duration in Intensive Care Patients","abstract":"Background\nCoronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)–associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) is a potential complication in critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n\n Corticosteroids are standard of care for hospitalized COVID-19 patients but carry an increased risk of secondary infections including CAPA.\n\n The objective of this study was to evaluate if duration of corticosteroid therapy ?10?days versus &gt;10?days affects the risk of developing CAPA.\n\n\nMethods\nThis was a retrospective cohort study of adult patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia requiring mechanical ventilation who received at least 3?days of corticosteroid treatment.\n\n Incidence of CAPA and secondary outcomes were compared using appropriate bivariable analyses.\n\n Steroid duration was evaluated as an independent predictor in a logistic regression model.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 278 patients were included (n = 169 for ?10?days’ steroid duration; n = 109 for &gt;10?days).\n\n CAPA developed in 20 of 278 (7.2%) patients.\n\n Patients treated with &gt;10?days of corticosteroid therapy had significantly higher incidence of CAPA (11.9% vs 4.1%; P = .\n\n0156), and steroid duration &gt;10?days was independently associated with CAPA (odds ratio, 3.17 [95% confidence interval, 1.02–9.83]).\n\n Secondary outcomes including inpatient mortality (77.1% vs 43.2%; P &lt; .\n\n0001), mechanical ventilation–free days at 28 days (0 vs 1.5; P &lt; .\n\n0001), and secondary infections (44.9% vs 28.4% P = .\n\n0220) were worse in the &gt;10?days cohort.\n\n\nConclusions\nCorticosteroid treatment &gt;10?days in critically ill COVID-19 patients is associated with an increased risk of CAPA.\n\n Patients may require corticosteroids for reasons beyond COVID-19 and clinicians should be cognizant of risk of CAPA with prolonged courses.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9984984","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Meera","surname":"Shah","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Kelly","surname":"Reveles","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Kelly","surname":"Reveles","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Rebecca","surname":"Moote","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Elizabeth","surname":"Hand","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Dean","surname":"Kellogg Recommendations and Future Considerations","abstract":"Invasive mold diseases are devastating systemic infections which demand meticulous care in selection, dosing, and therapy monitoring of antifungal drugs.\n Various circumstances regarding PK/PD properties of the applied drug, resistance/tolerance of the causative pathogen or host intolerability can lead to failure of the initial antifungal therapy.\n This necessitates treatment adaption in the sense of switching antifungal drug class or potentially adding another drug for a combination therapy approach.\n In the current state of drastically limited options of antifungal drug classes adaption of therapy remains challenging.\n Current guidelines provide restricted recommendations only and emphasize individual approaches.\n However, novel antifungals, incorporating innovative mechanisms of action, show promising results in late stage clinical development.\n These will expand options for salvage therapy in the future potentially as monotherapy or in combination with conventional or other novel antifungals.\n We outline current recommendations for salvage therapy including PK/PD considerations as well as elucidate possible future treatment options for invasive aspergillosis and drugs TDM: Trends and update","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12941-017-0235-8","date":"2017-08-31","title":"Voriconazole and posaconazole therapeutic drug monitoring: a retrospective study","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) aims to minimize the clinical impact of posaconazole and voriconazole pharmacokinetic variability.\n\n However, its benefits on clinical outcomes are still being defined.\n\n Additionally, TDM data are limited for posaconazole IV and delayed-release tablet formulations among specific patient populations, including critically ill.\n\n The aim of this study was to determine the percentage of therapeutic posaconazole and voriconazole drug levels across all formulations in a real-world clinical setting and elucidate factors affecting attainment of target concentrations.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>This study was a retrospective cohort study conducted at the University of Colorado Hospital between September 2006 and June 2015 that evaluated patients who received posaconazole or voriconazole TDM as part of routine care.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>Voriconazole (n = 250) and posaconazole (n = 100) levels were analyzed from 151 patients.\n\n Of these, 54% of voriconazole and 69% of posaconazole levels were therapeutic.\n\n For posaconazole, 14/38 (37%), 28/29 (97%) and 27/33 (82%) levels were therapeutic for the oral suspension, IV, and delayed-release tablet, respectively.\n\n Intravenous and delayed-release tablet posaconazole were 20 fold (p &lt; 0.01) and sevenfold (p = 0.002) more likely than the oral suspension to achieve a therapeutic level.\n\n Subsequent levels were more likely to be therapeutic after dose adjustments (OR 3.31; 95% CI 1.3–8.6; p = 0.02), regardless of timing of initial non-therapeutic level.\n\n In a multivariable logistic regression analysis, no characteristics were independently predictive of therapeutic voriconazole levels and only absence of H2RA/PPI use was independently predictive of therapeutic posaconazole levels.\n\n There was no correlation between survival and therapeutic drug levels for either voriconazole (p = 0.67) or posaconazole (p = 0.50).\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>A high percentage of drug levels did not achieve TDM targets for voriconazole and posaconazole oral suspension, supporting the need for routine TDM for those formulations.\n\n The utility of TDM for the IV and delayed-release tablet formulations of posaconazole is less apparent.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5594434","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Whitley clinical algorithm including fungal biomarkers to better diagnose probable invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in ICU","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>The classification of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) issued by the European Organization for the Research and Treatment of Cancer/Mycoses Study Group Education and Research Consortium (EORTC/MSGERC) is used for immunocompromised patients.\n\n An alternative algorithm adapted to the intensive care unit (ICU) population has been proposed (AspICU), but this algorithm did not include microbial biomarkers such as the galactomannan antigen and the Aspergillus quantitative PCR.\n\n The objective of the present pilot study was to evaluate a new algorithm that includes fungal biomarkers (BM-AspICU) for the diagnosis of probable IPA in an ICU population.\n\n\nPatients and methods\nid='Par3'>Data from 35 patients with pathology-proven IPA according to European Organization for the Research and Treatment of Cancer/Mycosis Study Group (EORTC/MSGERC)-2008 criteria were extracted from the French multicenter database of the Invasive Fungal Infections Surveillance Network (RESSIF).\n\n The patients were investigated according to the AspICU algorithm, and the BM-AspICU algorithm in analyzing the clinical, imaging, and biomarker data available in the records, without taking into account the pathology findings.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par4'>Eight patients had to be excluded because no imaging data were recorded in the database.\n\n Among the 27 proven IPAs with complete data, 16 would have been considered as putative IPA with the AspICU algorithm and 24 would have been considered as probable IPA using the new algorithm BM-AspICU.\n\n Seven out of the 8 patients with probable BM-AspICU IPA (and not classified with the AspICU algorithm) had no host factors and no Aspergillus-positive broncho-alveolar lavage fluid (BALF) culture.\n\n Three patients were non-classifiable with any of the two algorithms, because they did not have any microbial criteria during the course of the infection, and diagnosis of proven aspergillosis was done using autopsy samples.\n\n\nConclusion\nid='Par5'>Inclusion of biomarkers could be effective to identify probable IPA in the ICU population.\n\n A prospective study is needed to validate the routine application of the BM-AspICU algorithm in the ICU population.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7938267","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Joffrey","surname":"Hamam","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jean-Christophe","surname":"Navellou","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Anne-Pauline","surname":"Bellanger","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Stéphane","surname":"Bretagne","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hadrien","surname":"Winiszewski","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Emeline","surname":"Scherer","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Gael","surname":"Piton","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Laurence","surname":"Millon","email":"lmillon@chu-besancon.fr","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"NULL","surname":"NULL","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"NULL","surname":"NULL","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]}]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Prevalence found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1016/S1473-3099(20)30200-0","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Clinical and virological data of the first cases of COVID-19 in Europe: a case series","abstract":"Background\nOn Dec 31, 2019, China reported a cluster of cases of pneumonia in people at Wuhan, Hubei Province.\n\n The responsible pathogen is a novel coronavirus, named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).\n\n We report the relevant features of the first cases in Europe of confirmed infection, named coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), with the first patient diagnosed with the disease on Jan 24, 2020.\nMethods\nIn this case series, we followed five patients admitted to Bichat-Claude Bernard University Hospital (Paris, France) and Pellegrin University Hospital (Bordeaux, France) and diagnosed with COVID-19 by semi-quantitative RT-PCR on nasopharyngeal swabs.\n\n We assessed patterns of clinical disease and viral load from different samples (nasopharyngeal and blood, urine, and stool samples), which were obtained once daily for 3 days from hospital admission, and once every 2 or 3 days until patient discharge.\n\n All samples were refrigerated and shipped to laboratories in the National Reference Center for Respiratory Viruses (The Institut Pasteur, Paris, and Hospices Civils de Lyon, Lyon, France), where RNA extraction, real-time RT-PCR, and virus isolation and titration procedures were done.\n\n\nFindings\nThe patients were three men (aged 31 years, 48 years, and 80 years) and two women (aged 30 years and 46 years), all of Chinese origin, who had travelled to France from China around mid-January, 2020. Three different clinical evolutions are described: (1) two paucisymptomatic women diagnosed within a day of exhibiting symptoms, with high nasopharyngeal titres of SARS-CoV-2 within the first 24 h of the illness onset (5·2 and 7·4 log10 copies per 1000 cells, respectively) and viral RNA detection in stools; (2) a two-step disease progression in two young men, with a secondary worsening around 10 days after disease onset despite a decreasing viral load in nasopharyngeal samples; and (3) an 80-year-old man with a rapid evolution towards multiple organ failure and a persistent high viral load in lower and upper respiratory tract with systemic virus dissemination and virus detection in plasma.\n\n The 80-year-old patient died on day 14 of illness (Feb 14, 2020); all other patients had recovered and been discharged by Feb 19, 2020.\nInterpretation\nWe illustrated three different clinical and biological types of evolution in five patients infected with SARS-CoV-2 with detailed and comprehensive viral sampling strategy.\n\n We believe that these findings will contribute to a better understanding of the natural history of the disease and will contribute to advances in the implementation of more efficient infection control strategies.\n\n\nFunding\nREACTing (Research &amp; Action Emerging Infectious Diseases).\n\n\n","id":"PMC7156120","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Francois-Xavier","surname":"Lescure","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Lila","surname":"Bouadma","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Duc","surname":"Nguyen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Marion","surname":"Parisey","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Paul-Henri","surname":"Wicky","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Sylvie","surname":"Behillil","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Alexandre","surname":"Gaymard","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Maude","surname":"Bouscambert-Duchamp","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Flora","surname":"Donati","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Quentin","surname":"Le found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1093/cid/ciz1008","date":"2019-10-08","title":"Revision and Update of the Consensus Definitions of Invasive Fungal Disease From the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer and the Mycoses Study Group Education and Research Consortium","abstract":"Background\nInvasive fungal diseases (IFDs) remain important causes of morbidity and mortality.\n\n The consensus definitions of the Infectious Diseases Group of the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer and the Mycoses Study Group have been of immense value to researchers who conduct clinical trials of antifungals, assess diagnostic tests, and undertake epidemiologic studies.\n\n However, their utility has not extended beyond patients with cancer or recipients of stem cell or solid organ transplants.\n\n With newer diagnostic techniques available, it was clear that an update of these definitions was essential.\n\n\nMethods\nTo achieve this, 10 working groups looked closely at imaging, laboratory diagnosis, and special populations at risk of IFD.\n\n A final version of the manuscript was agreed upon after the groups’ findings were presented at a scientific symposium and after a 3-month period for public comment.\n\n There were several rounds of discussion before a final version of the manuscript was approved.\n\n\nResults\nThere is no change in the classifications of “proven,” “probable,” and “possible” IFD, although the definition of “probable” has been expanded and the scope of the category “possible” has been diminished.\n\n The category of proven IFD can apply to any patient, regardless of whether the patient is immunocompromised.\n\n The probable and possible categories are proposed for immunocompromised patients only, except for endemic mycoses.\n\n\nConclusions\nThese updated definitions of IFDs should prove applicable in clinical, diagnostic, and epidemiologic research of a broader range of patients at high-risk.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7486838","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"J clinical presentation, underlying conditions, and outcomes","abstract":"Introduction\nInvasive aspergillosis (IA) is a fungal infection that particularly affects immunocompromised hosts.\n\n Recently, several studies have indicated a high incidence of IA in intensive care unit (ICU) patients.\n\n However, few data are available on the epidemiology and outcome of patients with IA in this setting.\n\n\nMethods\nAn observational study including all patients with a positive Aspergillus culture during ICU stay was performed in 30 ICUs in 8 countries.\n\n Cases were classified as proven IA, putative IA or Aspergillus colonization according to recently validated criteria.\n\n Demographic, microbiologic and diagnostic data were collected.\n\n Outcome was recorded 12 weeks after Aspergillus isolation.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 563 patients were included, of whom 266 were colonized (47%), 203 had putative IA (36%) and 94 had proven IA (17%).\n\n The lung was the most frequent site of infection (94%), and Aspergillus fumigatus the most commonly isolated species (92%).\n\n Patients with IA had higher incidences of cancer and organ transplantation than those with colonization.\n\n Compared with other patients, they were more frequently diagnosed with sepsis on ICU admission and more frequently received vasopressors and renal replacement therapy (RRT) during the ICU stay.\n\n Mortality was 38% among colonized patients, 67% in those with putative IA and 79% in those with proven IA (P?&lt;?0.001).\n\n Independent risk factors for death among patients with IA included older age, history of bone marrow transplantation, and mechanical ventilation, RRT and higher Sequential Organ Failure Assessment score at diagnosis.\n\n\nConclusions\nIA among critically ill patients is associated with high mortality.\n\n Patients diagnosed with proven or putative IA had greater severity of illness and more frequently needed organ support than those with Aspergillus spp colonization.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4344741","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Fabio found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3390/jof7121067","date":"2021-12-09","title":"A Visual and Comprehensive Review on COVID-19-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis (CAPA)","abstract":"Coronavirus disease 19 (COVID-19)-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) is a severe fungal infection complicating critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n Numerous retrospective and prospective studies have been performed to get a better grasp on this lethal co-infection.\n We performed a qualitative review and summarized data from 48 studies in which 7047 patients had been included, of whom 820 had CAPA.\n The pooled incidence of proven, probable or putative CAPA was 15.1% among 2953 ICU-admitted COVID-19 patients included in 18 prospective studies.\n Incidences showed great variability due to multiple factors such as discrepancies in the rate and depth of the fungal work-up.\n The pathophysiology and risk factors for CAPA are ill-defined, but therapy with corticosteroids and anti-interleukin-6 therapy potentially confer the biggest risk.\n Sampling for mycological work-up using bronchoscopy is the cornerstone for diagnosis, as imaging is often aspecific.\n CAPA is associated with an increased mortality, but we do not have conclusive data whether therapy contributes to an increased survival in these patients.\n We conclude our review with a comparison between influenza-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (IAPA) and CAPA.\n risk factors and mortality of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in patients with influenza: A systematic review and meta?analysis","abstract":"Background\nAn increasing number of cases of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) complicating influenza have been described.\n\n We performed a meta?analysis to estimate the incidence, risk factors and outcomes of IPA in patients with influenza.\n\n\nMethods\nA systematic search was conducted in the PubMed, EMBASE and Cochrane Library databases from their inception to 31 August 2021 for eligible studies.\n\n Data on the incidence and risk factors of and mortality due to IPA in influenza patients were pooled using a random?effects model.\n\n Sensitivity analyses restricted to severe influenza requiring intensive care unit (ICU) support and multiple subgroup analyses were performed.\n\n\nResults\nFourteen studies involving 6024 hospitalised patients with influenza were included.\n\n IPA was estimated to occur in 10% of influenza patients, with a mortality rate of 52%.\n\n Similar incidence (11%) and mortality (54%) estimates for IPA were observed in the sensitivity analysis including severe cases requiring ICU support.\n\n Subgroup analysis by geographical location showed a similar IPA rate between European (10%) and non?European (11%) studies.\n\n The IPA rate in the subset of nine studies using the modified AspICU criteria was 13%.\n\n Most subgroup analyses showed ?50% mortality in IPA patients.\n\n Several predictors for IPA susceptibility were identified, including male sex, smoking history, chronic lung disease, influenza A (H1N1), severe conditions requiring supportive therapy, corticosteroid use before admission, solid organ transplant and haematological malignancy.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe IPA is common in individuals with severe influenza, and the prognosis is particularly poor.\n\n Influenza patients, especially those with high?risk factors, should be thoroughly screened for Review on the Novel Coronavirus Disease Evolution, Transmission, Detection, Control and Prevention","abstract":"Three major outbreaks of the coronavirus, a zoonotic virus known to cause respiratory disease, have been reported since 2002, including SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and the most recent 2019-nCoV, or more recently known as SARS-CoV-2. Bats are known to be the primary animal reservoir for coronaviruses.\n However, in the past few decades, the virus has been able to mutate and adapt to infect humans, resulting in an animal-to-human species barrier jump.\n The emergence of a novel coronavirus poses a serious global public health threat and possibly carries the potential of causing a major pandemic outbreak in the naïve human population.\n The recent outbreak of COVID-19, the disease caused by SARS-CoV-2, in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China has infected over 36.5 million individuals and claimed over one million lives worldwide, as of 8 October 2020. The novel virus is rapidly spreading across China and has been transmitted to 213 other countries/territories across the globe.\n Researchers have reported that the virus is constantly evolving and spreading through asymptomatic carriers, further suggesting a high global health threat.\n To this end, current up-to-date information on the coronavirus evolution and SARS-CoV-2 modes of
