patients: a prospective study","abstract":"Background\nIn this study we evaluated the incidence of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis among intubated patients with critical coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and evaluated different case definitions of invasive aspergillosis.\n\n\nMethods\nProspective, multicentre study on adult patients with microbiologically confirmed COVID-19 receiving mechanical ventilation.\n\n All included participants underwent screening protocol for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis with bronchoalveolar lavage galactomannan and cultures performed on admission at 7 days and in case of clinical deterioration.\n\n Cases were classified as coronavirus associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) according to previous consensus definitions.\n\n The new definition was compared with putative invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (PIPA).\n\n\nResults\nA total of 108 patients were enrolled.\n\n Probable CAPA was diagnosed in 30 (27.7%) of patients after a median of 4 (2-8) days from intensive care unit (ICU) admission.\n\n Kaplan-Meier curves showed a significant higher 30-day mortality rate from ICU admission among patients with either CAPA (44% vs 19%, p= 0.002) or PIPA (74% vs 26%, p&lt;0.001) when compared with patients not fulfilling criteria for aspergillosis.\n\n The association between CAPA [OR 3.53 (95%CI 1.29-9.67), P=0.014] or PIPA [OR 11.60 (95%CI 3.24-41.29) p&lt;0.001] with 30-day mortality from ICU admission was confirmed even after adjustment for confounders with a logistic regression model.\n\n Among patients with CAPA receiving voriconazole treatment (13 patients, 43%) A trend toward lower mortality (46% vs 59% p=0.30) and reduction of galactomannan index in consecutive samples was observed.\n\n\nConclusion\nWe found a high COVID-19–associated pulmonary aspergillosis: systematic review and meta-analysis","abstract":"Background\nPulmonary aspergillosis may complicate coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and contribute to excess mortality in intensive care unit (ICU) patients.\n\n The disease is poorly understood, in part due to discordant definitions across studies.\n\n\nObjectives\nWe sought to review the prevalence, diagnosis, treatment, and outcomes of COVID-19–associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) and compare research definitions.\n\n\nData sources\nPubMed, Embase, Web of Science, and MedRxiv were searched from inception to October 12, 2021.\nStudy eligibility criteria\nICU cohort studies and CAPA case series including ?3 patients were included.\n\n\nParticipants\nAdult patients in ICUs with COVID-19.\nInterventions\nPatients were reclassified according to four research definitions.\n\n We assessed risk of bias with an adaptation of the Joanna Briggs Institute cohort checklist tool for systematic reviews.\n\n\nMethods\nWe calculated CAPA prevalence using the Freeman-Tukey random effects method.\n\n Correlations between definitions were assessed with Spearman's rank test.\n\n Associations between antifungals and outcome were assessed with random effects meta-analysis.\n\n\nResults\nFifty-one studies were included.\n\n Among 3297 COVID-19 patients in ICU cohort studies, 313 were diagnosed with CAPA (prevalence 10%; 95% CI 8%–13%).\n\n Two hundred seventy-seven patients had patient-level data allowing reclassification.\n\n Definitions had limited correlation with one another (? = 0.268–0.447; p &lt; 0.001), with the exception of Koehler and Verweij (? = 0.893; p &lt; 0.001); 33.9% of patients reported to have CAPA did not fulfill any research definitions.\n\n Patients were diagnosed after a median of 8 days (interquartile range 5–14) in ICUs.\n\n Tracheobronchitis occurred in 3% of patients examined with bronchoscopy.\n\n The mortality rate was high (59.2%).\n\n Applying CAPA research definitions did not strengthen the association between mould-active antifungals and survival.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe reported prevalence of CAPA is significant but may be exaggerated by nonstandard definitions.\n\n\n","id":"PMC8828380","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Ruwandi I.","surname":"Sligl","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ilan S.","surname":"Schwartz","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.jhin.2021.04.012","date":"2021-04-13","title":"Incidence, diagnosis and outcomes of COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA): a systematic review","abstract":"COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) is defined as invasive pulmonary aspergillosis occurring in COVID-19 patients.\n The purpose of this review was to discuss the incidence, characteristics, diagnostic criteria, biomarkers, and outcomes of hospitalized patients diagnosed with CAPA.\n A literature search was performed through Pubmed and Web of Science databases for articles published up to 20th March 2021. In 1421 COVID-19 patients, the overall CAPA incidence was 13.5% (range 2.5–35.0%).\n The majority required invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV).\n The time to CAPA diagnosis from illness onset varied between 8.0 and 16.0 days.\n However, the time to CAPA diagnosis from intensive care unit (ICU) admission and IMV initiation ranged between 4.0–15.0 days and 3.0–8.0 days.\n The most common diagnostic criteria were the modified AspICU–Dutch/Belgian Mycosis Study Group and IAPA-Verweij et al.\n A total of 77.6% of patients had positive lower respiratory tract cultures, other fungal biomarkers of bronchoalveolar lavage and serum galactomannan were positive in 45.3% and 18.2% of patients.\n The CAPA mortality rate was high at 48.4%, despite the widespread use of antifungals.\n Lengthy hospital and ICU stays ranging between 16.0–37.5 days and 10.5–37.0 days were observed.\n CAPA patients had prolonged IMV duration of 13.0–20.0 days.\n The true incidence of CAPA likely remains unknown as the diagnosis is limited by the lack of standardized diagnostic criteria that rely solely on microbiological data with direct or indirect detection of Aspergillus in respiratory specimens, particularly in clinical conditions with a low pretest probability.\n A well-designed, multi-centre study to determine the optimal diagnostic approach for CAPA is required.\n","id":"PMC8057923","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"W.H.","surname":"Chong","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"K.P.","surname":"Neu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1111/myc.13328","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Mortality found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1016/S1473-3099(20)30847-1","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Defining and managing COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis: the 2020 ECMM/ISHAM consensus criteria for research and clinical guidance","abstract":"Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 causes direct damage to the airway epithelium, enabling aspergillus invasion.\n Reports of COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis have raised concerns about it worsening the disease course of COVID-19 and increasing mortality.\n Additionally, the first cases of COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis caused by azole-resistant aspergillus have been reported.\n This article constitutes a consensus statement on defining and managing COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis, prepared by experts and endorsed by medical mycology societies.\n COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis is proposed to be defined as possible, probable, or proven on the basis of sample validity and thus diagnostic certainty.\n Recommended first-line therapy is either voriconazole or isavuconazole.\n If azole resistance is a concern, then liposomal amphotericin B is the drug of choice.\n Our aim is to provide definitions for clinical research and up-to-date recommendations for clinical management of the diagnosis and treatment of COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis.\n","id":"PMC7833078","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Philipp","surname":"Koehler","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Matteo","surname":"Bassetti","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Arunaloke","surname":"Chakrabarti","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Sharon found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0238825","date":"2021-02-17","title":"Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in critically ill patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia: Results from the prospective AspCOVID-19 study","abstract":"Background\nSuperinfections, including invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA), are well-known complications of critically ill patients with severe viral pneumonia.\n\n Aim of this study was to evaluate the incidence, risk factors and outcome of IPA in critically ill patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia.\n\n\nMethods\nWe prospectively screened 32 critically ill patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia for a time period of 28 days using a standardized study protocol for oberservation of developement of COVID-19 associated invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA).\n\n We collected laboratory, microbiological, virological and clinical parameters at defined timepoints in combination with galactomannan-antigen-detection from nondirected bronchial lavage (NBL).\n\n We used logistic regression analyses to assess if COVID-19 was independently associated with IPA and compared it with matched controls.\n\n\nFindings\nCAPA was diagnosed at a median of 4 days after ICU admission in 11/32 (34%) of critically ill patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia as compared to 8% in the control cohort.\n\n In the COVID-19 cohort, mean age, APACHE II score and ICU mortality were higher in patients with CAPA than in patients without CAPA (36% versus 9.5%; p&lt;0.001).\n\n ICU stay (21 versus 17 days; p = 0.340) and days of mechanical ventilation (20 versus 15 days; p = 0.570) were not different between both groups.\n\n In regression analysis COVID-19 and APACHE II score were independently associated with IPA.\n\n\nInterpretation\nCAPA is highly prevalent and associated with a high mortality rate.\n\n COVID-19 is independently associated with invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.\n\n A standardized screening and diagnostic approach as presented in our study can help to identify affected patients at an early stage.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7968651","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Tobias","surname":"Lahmer","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Silja","surname":"Kriescher","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Silja","surname":"Kriescher","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Alexander","surname":"Herner","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kathrin","surname":"Rothe","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Christoph Invasive Pulmonary Aspergillosis in the Intensive Care Unit: A Case Series in a Portuguese Hospital","abstract":"Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) has become a recognizable complication in coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) patients admitted to intensive care units (ICUs).\n Alveolar damage in the context of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) appears to be the culprit in facilitating fungal invasion in COVID-19 patients, leading to a COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) phenomenon.\n From November 2020 to 15 February 2021, 248 COVID-19 patients were admitted to our ICUs, of whom ten patients (4% incidence) were classified as either probable (six) or possible (four) CAPA cases.\n Seven patients had positive cultural results: Aspergillus fumigatus sensu stricto (five), A.\n terreus sensu stricto (one), and A.\n welwitschiae (one).\n Five patients had positive bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) and galactomannan (GM), and two patients had both positive cultural and GM criteria.\n All but two patients received voriconazole.\n Mortality rate was 30%.\n Strict interpretation of classic IPA definition would have resulted in eight overlooked CAPA cases.\n Broader diagnostic criteria are essential in this context, even though differentiation between Aspergillus colonization and invasive disease might be more challenging.\n Herein, we aim to raise awareness of CAPA in view of its potential detrimental outcome, emphasizing the relevance of a low threshold for screening and early antifungal treatment in ARDS the First Wave","abstract":"Background: Critically ill COVID-19 patients have proven to be at risk for developing invasive fungal infections.\n However, the incidence and impact of possible/probable COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) in severe COVID-19 patients varies between cohorts.\n We aimed to assess the incidence, risk factors, and clinical outcome of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in a regional cohort of COVID-19 intensive care patients.\n Methods: We performed a regional, multicentre, retrospective cohort study in the intensive care units (ICUs) in North Brabant, The Netherlands.\n We included adult patients with rt-PCR-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection (COVID-19), requiring mechanical ventilation for acute respiratory distress syndrome.\n Demographics, clinical course, biomarker value, and treatment outcomes were compared between the groups with possible/probable CAPA from the main study centre and the regional centres, and without signs of CAPA from the main study centre as controls.\n The primary aim was to assess the regional impact of possible/probable CAPA in COVID-19 ICU patients, measured as all-cause mortality at 30 days after ICU admission.\n Secondary outcomes were risk factors for developing CAPA, based on underlying host factors and to identify the value of the mycological arguments for the diagnosing of CAPA.\n Results: Between 1 March and 30 April 2020, we included 123 patients with severe COVID-19: 29 patients (30.9%) in the main ICU with possible/probable CAPA, and 65 (69.1%) with no signs of CAPA; 29 patients in the regional ICUs with signs of CAPA.\n Patients’ characteristics and risk factors did not differ for CAPA and non-CAPA patients.\n Patients with COPD and/or chronic steroid medication developed CAPA more frequently, although this was not statistically significant.\n CAPA patients were admitted to the ICU earlier, had lower PF-ratios, and more often required renal replacement therapy.\n All-cause 30-day mortality was significantly higher in mechanically ventilated COVID-19 patients with possible/probable CAPA 39.7% (23/58) compared to patients without evidence for CAPA 16.9% (11/65) (OR 3.2 [95% CI 1.4–7.4] p = 0.005).\n Conclusion: The high incidence of possible and probable CAPA in critically ill COVID-19 patients is alarming.\n The increase in 30-day mortality in CAPA highlights the study was to evaluate diagnostic means, host factors, delay of occurrence, and outcome of patients with COVID-19 pneumonia and fungal coinfections in the intensive care unit (ICU).\n From 1 February to 31 May 2020, we anonymously recorded COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA), fungemia (CA-fungemia), and pneumocystosis (CA-PCP) from 36 centers, including results on fungal biomarkers in respiratory specimens and serum.\n We collected data from 154 episodes of CAPA, 81 of CA-fungemia, 17 of CA-PCP, and 5 of other mold infections from 244 patients (male/female [M/F] ratio?=?3.5; mean age, 64.7?±?10.8?years).\n CA-PCP occurred first after ICU admission (median, 1?day; interquartile range [IQR], 0 to 3 days), followed by CAPA (9?days; IQR, 5 to 13 days), and then CA-fungemia (16?days; IQR, 12 to 23 days) (P &lt; 10?4).\n For CAPA, the presence of several mycological criteria was associated with death (P &lt; 10?4).\n Serum galactomannan was rarely positive (&lt;20%).\n The mortality rates were 76.7% (23/30) in patients with host factors for invasive fungal disease, 45.2% (14/31) in those with a preexisting pulmonary condition, and 36.6% (34/93) in the remaining patients (P = 0.001).\n Antimold treatment did not alter prognosis (P = 0.370).\n Candida albicans was responsible for 59.3% of CA-fungemias, with a global mortality of 45.7%.\n For CA-PCP, 58.8% of the episodes occurred in patients with known host factors of PCP, and the mortality rate was 29.5%.\n CAPA may be in part hospital acquired and could benefit from antifungal prescription at the first positive biomarker result.\n CA-fungemia appeared linked to ICU stay without COVID-19 specificity, while CA-PCP may not really be a concern in the ICU.\n Improved diagnostic strategy for fungal markers in ICU patients with COVID-19 should support these pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA): Risk factors and development of a predictive score for critically ill COVID?19 patients","abstract":"Background\nCOVID?19?associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) is a major complication of critically ill COVID?19 patients, with a high mortality rate and potentially preventable.\n\n Thus, identifying patients at high risk of CAPA would be of great interest.\n\n We intended to develop a clinical prediction score capable of stratifying patients according to the risk for CAPA at ICU admission.\n\n\nMethods\nSingle centre retrospective case–control study.\n\n A case was defined as a patient diagnosed with CAPA according to 2020 ECMM/ISHAM consensus criteria.\n\n 2 controls were selected for each case among critically ill COVID?19 patients.\n\n\nResults\n28 CAPA patients and 56?matched controls were included.\n\n Factors associated with CAPA included old age (68 years vs.\n\n 62, p = .\n\n033), active smoking (17.9% vs.\n\n 1.8%, p = .\n\n014), chronic respiratory diseases (48.1% vs.\n\n 26.3%, p = .\n\n043), chronic renal failure (25.0% vs.\n\n 3.6%, p = .\n\n005), chronic corticosteroid treatment (28.6% vs.\n\n 1.8%, p &lt; .\n\n001), tocilizumab therapy (92.9% vs.\n\n 66.1%, p = .\n\n008) and high APACHE II at ICU admission (median 13 vs.\n\n 10 points, p = .\n\n026).\n\n A score was created including these variables, which showed an area under the receiver operator curve of 0.854 (95% CI 0.77?0.92).\n\n A punctuation below 6 had a negative predictive value of 99.6%.\n\n A punctuation of 10 or higher had a positive predictive value of 27.9%.\n\n\nConclusion\nWe present a clinical prediction score that allowed to stratify critically ill COVID?19 patients according to the risk for developing CAPA.\n\n This CAPA score would allow to target preventive measures.\n\n Further evaluation of the score, as well as the utility of these targeted preventive measures, is needed.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9115267","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jorge","surname":"Calderón?Parra","email":"jorge050390@gmail.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Patricia","surname":"Mills?Sanchez","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Patricia","surname":"Mills?Sanchez","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Victor","surname":"Moreno?Torres","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Sandra","surname":"Tejado?Bravo","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Isabel","surname":"Romero?Sánchez","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Bárbara","surname":"Balandin?Moreno","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Marina","surname":"Calvo?Salvador","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Francisca","surname":"Portero?Azorín","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Sarela","surname":"García?Masedo","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Elena","surname":"Muñez?Rubio","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Antonio","surname":"Ramos?Martinez","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ana","surname":"Fernández?Cruz","email":"anafcruz999@gmail.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ana","surname":"Fernández?Cruz","email":"anafcruz999@gmail.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"NULL","surname":"NULL","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"NULL","surname":"NULL","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3390/jof8090894","date":"2022-08-22","title":"Challenges in Diagnosing COVID-19-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis in Critically Ill Patients: The Relationship between Case Definitions and Autoptic Data","abstract":"Critically ill COVID-19 patients can develop invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA).\n Considering the weaknesses of diagnostic tests/case definitions, as well as the results from autoptic studies, there is a debate on the real burden of aspergillosis in COVID-19 patients.\n We performed a retrospective observational study on mechanically ventilated critically ill COVID-19 patients in an intensive care unit (ICU).\n The primary objective was to determine the burden of CAPA by comparing clinical diagnosis (through case definitions/diagnostic algorithms) with autopsy results.\n Twenty patients out of 168 (11.9%) developed probable CAPA.\n Seven (35%) were females, and the median age was 66 [IQR 59–72] years.\n Thirteen CAPA patients (65%) died and, for six, an autopsy was performed providing a proven diagnosis in four cases.\n Histopathology findings suggest a focal pattern, rather than invasive and diffuse fungal disease, in the context of prominent viral pneumonia.\n In a cohort of mechanically ventilated patients with probable CAPA, by performing a high rate of complete autopsies, invasive aspergillosis was not always proven.\n It is still not clear whether aspergillosis is the major driver of mortality in patients with outcomes","abstract":"Background\nCOVID?19 patients on mechanical ventilation are at risk to develop invasive aspergillosis.\n\n To provide additional data regarding this intriguing entity, we conducted a retrospective study describing risk factors, radiology and prognosis of this emerging entity in a Brazilian referral centre.\n\n\nMethods\nThis retrospective study included intubated (?18 years) patients with COVID?19 admitted from April 2020 until July 2021 that had bronchoscopy to investigate pulmonary co?infections.\n\n COVID?19?associated aspergillosis (CAPA) was defined according to the 2020 European Confederation of Medical Mycology/International Society of Human and Animal Mycosis consensus criteria.\n\n The performance of tracheal aspirate (TA) cultures to diagnose CAPA were described, as well as the radiological findings, risk factors and outcomes.\n\n\nResults\nFourteen patients (14/87, 16%) had probable CAPA (0.9 cases per 100 ICU admissions).\n\n findings of CAPA were classified as typical of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (64.3%).\n\n The overall mortality rate of probable CAPA was 71.4%.\n\n Age was the only independent risk factor for CAPA [p = .\n\n03; odds ratio (OR) 1.072].\n\n CAPA patients under renal replacement therapy (RRT) may have a higher risk for a fatal outcome (p = .\n\n053, hazard ratio 8.047).\n\n\nConclusions\nCAPA was a prevalent co?infection in our cohort of patients under mechanical ventilation.\n\n Older patients had a higher risk to develop CAPA, and a poor prognosis may be associated with aspergillosis in ICU patients: a French multicentric retrospective cohort","abstract":"Objectives\nThe main objective of this study was to determine the incidence of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) in patients with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU), and to describe the patient characteristics associated with IPA occurrence and to evaluate its impact on prognosis.\n\n\nMethods\nWe conducted a retrospective cohort study including all successive COVID-19 patients, hospitalized in four ICUs, with secondary deterioration and one or more respiratory samples sent to the mycology department.\n\n We used a strengthened IPA testing strategy including seven mycological criteria.\n\n Patients were classified as probable IPA according to the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC)/Mycoses Study Group Education and Research Consortium (MSGERC) classification if immunocompromised, and according to the recent COVID-19-associated IPA classification otherwise.\n\n\nResults\nProbable IPA was diagnosed in 21 out of the 366 COVID-19 patients (5.7%) admitted to the ICU and in the 108 patients (19.4%) who underwent respiratory sampling for deterioration.\n\n No significant differences were observed between patients with and without IPA regarding age, gender, medical history and severity on admission and during hospitalization.\n\n Treatment with azithromycin for ?3 days was associated with the diagnosis of probable IPA (odds ratio 3.1, 95% confidence interval 1.1–8.5, p = 0.02).\n\n A trend was observed with high-dose dexamethasone and the occurrence of IPA.\n\n Overall mortality was higher in the IPA patients (15/21, 71.4% versus 32/87, 36.8%, p &lt; 0.01).\n\n\nConclusion\nIPA is a relatively frequent complication in severe COVID-19 patients and is responsible for increased mortality.\n\n Azithromycin, known to have immunomodulatory properties, may contribute to increase COVID-19 patient's susceptibility to pandemic","abstract":"Background\nCOVID?19?associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) has been reported as an important cause of mortality in critically ill patients with an incidence rate ranging from studies; however, the knowledge on Aspergillus co-infection among patients with COVID-19 was limited.\n\n This study was conducted to identify and isolate fungal agents and to evaluate the prevalence of pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) as well as antifungal susceptibility patterns of Aspergillus species in patients with COVID-19 admitted to Shahid Beheshti Hospital, Kashan, identify the species.\n\n The antifungal activities of fluconazole, itraconazole, voriconazole, amphotericin B against Aspergillus spp.\n\n were evaluated according to the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute manual (M38-A3).\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>From the 119 patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia, CAPA was confirmed in 17 cases (14.3%).\n\n Of these, 12 (70.6%) were males and 5 oryzae (3/17, 17.6%), were identified as etiologic agents of CAPA, using the molecular techniques.\n\n Voriconazole and amphotericin B showed more activity against all isolates.\n\n Moreover, the MIC of fluconazole, itraconazole varied with the tested isolates.\n\n For 3 clinical isolates of A.\n\n fumigatus, 2 isolate of A.\n\n flavus and 3 A.\n\n oryzae, the MIC of fluconazole and itraconazole were???16 µg/mL.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>We observed a high incidence (14.3%) of probable aspergillosis in 119 patients with COVID-19, which might indicate the risk for developing IPA in COVID-19 patients.\n\n When comparing patients with and without CAPA regarding baseline characteristics, CAPA patients were older (p?=0?.\n\n024), had received more frequent systemic corticosteroids (p?=?0.024), and had a higher mortality rate (p?=?0.018).\n\n The outcome of CAPA is usually poor, thus emphasis shall be given to screening and/or prophylaxis in COVID-19 patients with any risk of content-type='genus-species'>Aspergillus</named-content> Test Profiles and Mortality in Critically Ill COVID-19 Patients","abstract":"The literature regarding COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) has shown conflicting observations, including survival of CAPA patients not receiving antifungal therapy and discrepancy between CAPA diagnosis and autopsy findings.\n To gain insight into the pathophysiology of CAPA, we performed a case-control study in which we compared Aspergillus test profiles in CAPA patients and controls in relation to intensive care unit (ICU) mortality.\n This was a multinational case-control study in which Aspergillus test results, use of antifungal therapy, and mortality were collected from critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n Patients were classified using the 2020 European Confederation for Medical Mycology and the International Society for Human and Animal Mycology (ECMM/ISHAM) consensus case definitions.\n We analyzed 219 critically ill COVID-19 cases, including 1 proven, 38 probable, 19 possible CAPA cases, 21 Aspergillus-colonized patients, 7 patients only positive for serum (1,3)-?-d-glucan (BDG), and 133 cases with no evidence of CAPA.\n Mortality was 53.8% in CAPA patients compared to 24.1% in patients without CAPA (P?=?0.001).\n Positive serum galactomannan (GM) and BDG were associated with increased mortality compared to serum biomarker-negative CAPA patients (87.5% versus 41.7%, P?=?0.046; 90.0% versus 42.1%, P?=?0.029, respectively).\n For each point increase in GM or 10-point BDG serum concentration, the odds of death increased (GM, odds ratio [OR] 10.208, 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.621 to 64.291, P?=?0.013; BDG, OR, 1.247, 95% CI, 1.029 to 1.511, P?=?0.024).\n CAPA is a complex disease, probably involving a continuum of respiratory colonization, tissue invasion, and angioinvasion.\n Serum biomarkers are useful for staging CAPA disease progression and, if positive, indicate angioinvasion and a high probability of mortality.\n There is need for a biomarker that distinguishes between respiratory tract colonization and tissue-invasive CAPA disease.\n","id":"PMC8601217","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Mehmet","surname":"Ergün","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Roger J. E.","surname":"Hanson","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3390/diagnostics12051201","date":"2022-05-09","title":"Clinical and Imaging Features of COVID-19-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis","abstract":"Background: COVID-19 superinfection by Aspergillus (COVID-19-associated aspergillosis, CAPA) is increasingly observed due to increased awareness and use of corticosteroids.\n The aim of this study is to compare clinical and imaging features between COVID-19 patients with and without associated pulmonary aspergillosis.\n Material and Methods: In this case–control study, hospitalized patients between March 2020 and March 2021 were evaluated.\n Two observers independently compared 105 chest CTs of 52 COVID-19 patients without pulmonary aspergillosis to 40 chest CTs of 13 CAPA patients.\n The following features were evaluated: lung involvement, predominant main pattern (ground glass opacity, crazy paving, consolidation) and additional lung and chest findings.\n Chronological changes in the abnormal extent upon CT and chronological changes in the main patterns were compared with mixed models.\n Patient-wise comparisons of additional features and demographic and clinical data were performed using Student’s t-test, Chi-squared test, Fisher’s exact tests and Wilcoxon rank-sum tests.\n Results: Compared to COVID-19 patients without pulmonary aspergillosis, CAPA patients were older (mean age (±SD): 70.3 (±7.8) versus 63.5 (±9.5) years (p = 0.01).\n The time-dependent evolution rates for consolidation (p = 0.02) and ground glass (p = 0.006) differed.\n In early COVID-19 disease, consolidation was associated with CAPA, whereas ground glass was less common.\n Chronological changes in the abnormal extent upon CT did not differ (p = 0.29).\n Regardless of the time point, bronchial wall thickening was observed more frequently in CAPA patients (p = 0.03).\n Conclusions: CAPA patients showed a tendency for consolidation in early COVID-19 disease.\n Bronchial wall thickening and higher patient age were associated with CAPA.\n The overall lung involvement was similar between both groups.\n","id":"PMC9140144","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Tim","surname":"Fischer","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yassir","surname":"El Pulmonary Aspergillosis in Patients with and without SARS-CoV-2 Infection","abstract":"The recent European Confederation of Medical Mycology (ECMM) and the International Society for Human and Animal Mycology (ISHAM) 2020 consensus classification proposes criteria to define coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19)-associated invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA), including mycological evidence obtained via non-bronchoscopic lavage.\n Given the low specificity of radiological findings in patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection, this criterion makes it difficult to differentiate between invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) and colonization.\n This unicenter and retrospective study includes 240 patients with isolates of any Aspergillus species in any respiratory samples during a 20-month study (140 IPA and 100 colonization).\n Mortality was high in the IPA and colonization groups (37.1% and 34.0%, respectively; p = 0.61), especially in patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection, where mortality was higher in colonized patients (40.7% vs.\n 66.6.%; p: 0.021).\n Multivariate analysis confirmed the following variables to be independently associated with increased mortality: age &gt; 65 years, acute or chronic renal failure at diagnosis, thrombocytopenia (&lt;100,000 platelets/µL) at admission, inotrope requirement, and SARS-CoV-2 infection, but not the presence of IPA.\n This series shows that the isolation of Aspergillus spp.\n in respiratory samples, whether associated with disease criteria or not, is associated with high mortality, especially in patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection, and suggests an early initiation of treatment given its high mortality rate.\n","id":"PMC9968193","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jesús","surname":"Fortún","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"María","surname":"Mateos","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"María","surname":"Mateos","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Elia during the first wave: the French multicentre MYCOVID study","abstract":"Background\nPatients with severe COVID-19 have emerged as a population at high risk of invasive fungal infections (IFIs).\n\n However, to our knowledge, the prevalence of IFIs has not yet been assessed in large populations of mechanically ventilated patients.\n\n We aimed to identify the prevalence, risk factors, and mortality associated with IFIs in mechanically ventilated patients with COVID-19 under intensive care.\n\n\nMethods\nWe performed a national, multicentre, observational cohort study in 18 French intensive care units (ICUs).\n\n We retrospectively and prospectively enrolled adult patients (aged ?18 years) with RT-PCR-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection and requiring mechanical ventilation for acute respiratory distress syndrome, with all demographic and clinical and biological follow-up data anonymised and collected from electronic case report forms.\n\n Patients were systematically screened for respiratory fungal microorganisms once or twice a week during the period of mechanical ventilation up to ICU discharge.\n\n The primary outcome was the prevalence of IFIs in all eligible participants with a minimum of three microbiological samples screened during ICU admission, with proven or probable (pr/pb) COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) classified according to the recent ECMM/ISHAM definitions.\n\n Secondary outcomes were risk factors of pr/pb CAPA, ICU mortality between the pr/pb CAPA and non-pr/pb CAPA groups, and associations of pr/pb CAPA and related variables with ICU mortality, identified by regression models.\n\n The MYCOVID study is registered with ClinicalTrials.\n\ngov, NCT04368221.\n\n\nFindings\nBetween Feb 29 and July 9, 2020, we enrolled 565 mechanically ventilated patients with COVID-19. 509 patients with at least three screening samples were analysed (mean age 59·4 years [SD 12·5], 400 [79%] men).\n\n 128 (25%) patients had 138 episodes of pr/pb or possible IFIs.\n\n 76 (15%) patients fulfilled the criteria for pr/pb CAPA.\n\n According to multivariate analysis, age older than 62 years (odds ratio [OR] 2·34 [95% CI 1·39–3·92], p=0·0013), treatment with dexamethasone and anti-IL-6 (OR 2·71 [1·12–6·56], p=0·027), and long duration of mechanical ventilation (&gt;14 days; OR 2·16 [1·14–4·09], p=0·019) were independently associated with pr/pb CAPA.\n\n 38 (7%) patients had one or more other pr/pb IFIs: 32 (6%) had candidaemia, six (1%) had invasive mucormycosis, and one (&lt;1%) had invasive fusariosis.\n\n Multivariate analysis of associations with death, adjusted for candidaemia, for the 509 patients identified three significant factors: age older than 62 years (hazard ratio [HR] 1·71 [95% CI 1·26–2·32], p=0·0005), solid organ transplantation (HR 2·46 [1·53–3·95], p=0·0002), and pr/pb CAPA (HR 1·45 [95% CI 1·03–2·03], p=0·033).\n\n At time of ICU discharge, survival curves showed that overall ICU mortality was significantly higher in patients with pr/pb CAPA than in those without, at 61·8% (95% CI 50·0–72·8) versus 32·1% (27·7–36·7; p&lt;0·0001).\n\n\nInterpretation\nThis study shows the high prevalence of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis and candidaemia and high mortality associated with pr/pb CAPA in mechanically ventilated patients with COVID-19. These findings highlight the need for active surveillance of fungal pathogens in patients with severe COVID-19.\nFunding\nPfizer.\n\n\n","id":"PMC8626095","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jean-Pierre","surname":"Gangneux","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Eric","surname":"Dannaoui","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Arnaud","surname":"Fekkar","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Charles-Edouard","surname":"Luyt","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Françoise","surname":"Botterel","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Nicolas","surname":"De patients","abstract":"Background\nCOVID?19?associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) has been widely reported but homogenous large cohort studies are needed to gain real?world insights about the disease.\n\n\nMethods\nWe collected clinical and laboratory data of 1161 patients hospitalised at our Institute from March 2020 to August 2021, defined their CAPA pathology, and analysed the data of glucocorticoid treatment are significant factors for its mortality.\n\n Cellular immune dysregulation may have a central role in CAPA from its development to COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis in critically ill patients: an observational study","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Coronavirus disease 19 (COVID-19)-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) emerged as important fungal complications in patients with COVID-19-associated severe acute respiratory failure (ARF).\n\n Whether mould active antifungal prophylaxis (MAFP) can prevent CAPA remains elusive so far.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>In this observational study, we included all consecutive patients admitted to intensive care units with COVID-19-associated ARF between September 1, 2020, and May 1, 2021. We compared patients with versus without antifungal prophylaxis with respect to CAPA incidence (primary outcome) and mortality (secondary outcome).\n\n Propensity score adjustment was performed to account for any imbalances in baseline characteristics.\n\n CAPA cases were classified according to European Confederation of Medical Mycology (ECMM)/International Society of Human and Animal Mycoses (ISHAM) consensus criteria.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>We included 132 patients, of whom 75 (57%) received antifungal prophylaxis (98% posaconazole).\n\n Ten CAPA cases were diagnosed, after a median of 6 days following ICU admission.\n\n Of those, 9 CAPA cases were recorded in the non-prophylaxis group and one in the prophylaxis group, respectively.\n\n However, no difference in 30-day ICU mortality could be observed.\n\n Thirty-day CAPA incidence estimates were 1.4% (95% CI 0.2–9.7) in the MAFP group and 17.5% (95% CI 9.6–31.4) in the group without MAFP (p?=?0.002).\n\n The respective subdistributional hazard ratio (sHR) for CAPA incidence comparing the MAFP versus no MAFP group was of 0.08 (95% CI 0.01–0.63; p?=?0.017).\n\n\nConclusion\nid='Par4'>In ICU patients with COVID-19 ARF, antifungal prophylaxis was associated with significantly reduced CAPA incidence, but this did not translate into improved survival.\n\n Randomized controlled trials are warranted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of MAFP with respect to CAPA incidence and clinical outcomes.\n\n\nSupplementary Information\nThe online version contains supplementary material available at pulmonary aspergillosis is associated with increased in-hospital mortality and prolonged SARS-CoV-2 viral shedding","abstract":"Background/Purpose\nCoronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) is common in critically ill patients with COVID-19 and is associated with worse outcomes.\n\n However, reports on CAPA and its impact on treatment outcomes in Asian populations are limited.\n\n\nMethods\nPatients with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction-confirmed COVID-19 admitted to intensive care units (ICUs) were retrospectively enrolled in this observational study.\n\n The incidence rate of CAPA during ICU admission was investigated.\n\n The clinical factors associated with CAPA, including corticosteroid exposure, were analyzed.\n\n The impact of CAPA on the treatment outcomes and SARS-CoV-2 viral shedding were explored.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 72 ICU-admitted patients with COVID-19 were included in the analysis.\n\n The incidence rate of CAPA was 15.3% (11/72) in all patients and 23% (11/48) in the mechanically ventilated patients.\n\n The median time from ICU admission to CAPA diagnosis was 15 days.\n\n A lower fibrinogen level (adjusted odds ratio [aOR], 0.983; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.967–0.999) was independently associated with CAPA.\n\n The patients with CAPA had a higher in-hospital mortality rate (55% vs.\n\n 13%, p = 0.001) and a longer SARS-CoV-2 viral shedding time (22 days vs.\n\n 16 days, p = 0.037) than those without CAPA.\n\n\nConclusion\nLower serum fibrinogen levels was independently associated with CAPA among the ICU-admitted patients with COVID-19. The patients with CAPA had a higher in-hospital mortality rate and a longer SARS-CoV-2 viral shedding time than those without CAPA.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9359693","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jhong-Ru","surname":"Huang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hsiao-Chin","surname":"Shen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Chuan-Yen","surname":"Sun","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wei-Chih","surname":"Chen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yuh-Min","surname":"Chen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jia-Yih","surname":"Feng","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kuang-Yao","surname":"Yang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3201/eid2711.211174","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Multinational E.","surname":"Verweij","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3346/jkms.2022.37.e134","date":"2022-03-29","title":"Risk Factors for Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis in Critically Ill Patients: A Nationwide, Multicenter, Retrospective Cohort Study","abstract":"Background\nCoronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is often accompanied by secondary infections, such as invasive aspergillosis.\n\n In this study, risk factors for developing COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) and their clinical outcomes were evaluated.\n\n\nMethods\nThis multicenter retrospective cohort study included critically ill COVID-19 patients from July 2020 through March 2021. Critically ill patients were defined as patients requiring high-flow respiratory support or mechanical ventilation.\n\n CAPA was defined based on the 2020 European Confederation of Medical Mycology and the International Society for Human and Animal Mycology consensus criteria.\n\n Factors associated with CAPA were analyzed, and their clinical outcomes were adjusted by a propensity score-matched model.\n\n\nResults\nAmong 187 eligible patients, 17 (9.1%) developed CAPA, which is equal to 33.10 per 10,000 patient-days.\n\n Sixteen patients received voriconazole-based antifungal treatment.\n\n In addition, 82.4% and 53.5% of patients with CAPA and without CAPA, respectively, received early high-dose corticosteroids (P = 0.022).\n\n In multivariable analysis, initial 10-day cumulative steroid dose &gt; 60 mg of dexamethasone or dexamethasone equivalent dose) (adjusted odds ratio [OR], 3.77; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.03–13.79) and chronic pulmonary disease (adjusted OR, 4.20; 95% CI, 1.26–14.02) were independently associated with CAPA.\n\n Tendencies of higher 90-day overall mortality (54.3% vs.\n\n 35.2%, P = 0.346) and lower respiratory support-free rate were observed in patients with CAPA (76.3% vs.\n\n 54.9%, P = 0.089).\n\n\nConclusion\nOur study showed that the dose of corticosteroid use might be a risk factor for CAPA development and the possibility of CAPA contributing to adverse outcomes in critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9091428","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Si-Ho","surname":"Kim","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jin Analysis of 178 Patients","abstract":"Background: COVID-19-associated fungal infections seem to be a concerning issue.\n The aim of this study was to assess the incidence of fungal infections, the possible risk factors, and their effect on outcomes of critically ill patients with COVID-19. Methods: A retrospective observational study was conducted in the COVID-19 ICU of the First Respiratory Department of National and Kapodistrian University of Athens in Sotiria Chest Diseases Hospital between 27 August 2020 and 10 November 2021. Results: Here, 178 patients were included in the study.\n Nineteen patients (10.7%) developed fungal infection, of which five had COVID-19 associated candidemia, thirteen had COVID-19 associated pulmonary aspergillosis, and one had both.\n Patients with fungal infection were younger, had a lower Charlson Comorbidity Index, and had a lower PaO2/FiO2 ratio upon admission.\n Regarding health-care factors, patients with fungal infections were treated more frequently with Tocilizumab, a high regimen of dexamethasone, continuous renal replacement treatment, and were supported more with ECMO.\n They also had more complications, especially infections, and subsequently developed septic shock more frequently.\n Finally, patients with fungal infections had a longer length of ICU stay, as well as length of mechanical ventilation, although no statistically significant difference was reported on 28-day and 90-day mortality.\n Conclusions: Fungal infections seem to have a high incidence in COVID-19 critically ill patients and specific risk factors are identified.\n However, fungal infections do not seem to burden on mortality.\n","id":"PMC9410292","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Evangelia","surname":"Koukaki","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Nikoletta","surname":"Rovina","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Nikoletta","surname":"Rovina","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kimon","surname":"Tzannis","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kimon","surname":"Tzannis","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Zoi","surname":"Sotiropoulou","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Konstantinos","surname":"Loverdos","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Antonia","surname":"Koutsoukou","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"George","surname":"Dimopoulos","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"David S.","surname":"Perlin","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3904/kjim.2022.069","date":"2022-03-30","title":"Risk factors and clinical impact of COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis: Multicenter retrospective cohort study","abstract":"Background/Aims\nThe risk factors and clinical impacts of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) remain controversial, and no data have been reported in Korea.\n\n This study aimed to investigate the epidemiology and importance of CAPA diagnostic efforts and to identify the predictors of CAPA and the impacts on clinical outcomes.\n\n\nMethods\nBetween January 2020 and May 2021, data of severely to critically ill COVID-19 patients were extracted from seven hospitals of the Catholic Medical Center through a clinical data warehouse.\n\n Corticosteroid use was subcategorized into total cumulative dose, early 7-day dose, mean daily dose, and duration of use.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 2,427 patients were screened, and 218 patients were included.\n\n CAPA was diagnosed in 4.6% (10/218) of all hospitalized and 11.2% (10/89) of intensive care unit patients.\n\n Total cumulative dose (over 1,000 mg as methylprednisolone) and daily high-dose corticosteroid use (over 60 mg/day) were independent predictors but not early 7-day high-dose corticosteroid use (over 420 mg/week) (odds ratio [OR], 1.731; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.350 to 8.571) nor prolonged use (OR, 2.794; 95% CI, 0.635 to 13.928).\n\n In-hospital overall mortality was 11.9% (26 of 218).\n\n CAPA itself did not affect the outcome; rather, daily high-dose steroid use significantly increased the 30-day mortality (hazard ratio, 5.645; 95% CI, 1.225 to 26.091).\n\n\nConclusions\nCAPA was not uncommon, especially in critically ill patients.\n\n Daily high-dose corticosteroid use was the predictor of CAPA and associated with high mortality rates.\n\n High-dose corticosteroids use after early inflammatory phase should be avoided, and active surveillance methods for CAPA are essential for those high-risk patients.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9271713","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Raeseok","surname":"Lee","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Sung-Yeon","surname":"Cho","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Dong-Gun","surname":"Lee","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hyojin","surname":"Ahn","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hyojin","surname":"Ahn","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hyeah","surname":"Choi","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Su-Mi","surname":"Choi","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jae-Ki","surname":"Choi","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jung-Hyun","surname":"Choi","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Shin as risk factor for COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis in intensive care patients","abstract":"Purpose\nid='Par1'>Corticosteroids, in particular dexamethasone, are one of the primary treatment options for critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n\n However, there are a growing number of cases that involve COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA), and it is unclear whether dexamethasone represents a risk factor for CAPA.\n\n Our aim was to investigate a possible association of the recommended dexamethasone therapy with a risk of CAPA.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>We performed a study based on a cohort of COVID-19 patients treated in 2020 in our 13 intensive care units at Charité Universitätsmedizin Berlin.\n\n We used ECMM/ISHM criteria for the CAPA diagnosis and performed univariate and multivariable analyses of clinical parameters to identify risk factors that could result in a diagnosis of CAPA.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>Altogether, among the n?=?522 intensive care 461, p?&lt;?0.008).\n\n They more often had severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) (60% vs.\n\n 41%, p?=?0.024), renal replacement therapy (60% vs.\n\n 41%, p?=?0.024), and they were more CAPA.\n\n\nConclusion\nid='Par4'>In our study, dexamethasone therapy as recommended for COVID-19 was associated with a significant three times increase in the risk of CAPA.\n\n\n\nTrial their impact on mortality.\n A prospective study was conducted.\n We included patients with COVID-19 disease who were admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of respiratory failur.\n Mycological culture (prevalence 11.7%).\n During admission, 57 patients died (19%), and, in the group of CAPA patients, mortality was 31.4%.\n In multivariate analysis, independent risk factors associated with CAPA diagnosis were age (OR: 1.05; 95% CI 1.01–1.09; p = 0.037), chronic lung disease (OR: 3.85; 95% CI 1.02–14.9; p = 0.049) and treatment with tocilizumab during admission (OR: 14.5; 95% 6.1–34.9; p = infection that appears in many patients with COVID-19 disease.\n CAPA is associated with high mortality rates, which may be reduced by early diagnosis and initiation of appropriate antifungal therapy, so screening of COVID-19 ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome) patients for CAPA is Amphotericin B in Mechanically Ventilated COVID-19 Patients to Prevent Invasive Pulmonary Aspergillosis: A Retrospective Cohort Study","abstract":"OBJECTIVES:\nTo assess the CAPA incidence in COVID-19 patients on IMV treated with and without nebulized c-AmB as antifungal prophylaxis.\n\n\nDESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS:\nRetrospective cohort study of consecutive COVID-19 patients admitted to our adult 17-bed ICU in a university-affiliated general hospital in Ede, The Netherlands, between January 25, 2021, and July 9, 2021. Patients not requiring IMV or transferred from or to another ICU were excluded.\n\n From April 9, 2021, daily nebulized amphotericin B in all patients on IMV was initiated.\n\n\nMAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES:\nBronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) was performed in case of positive cultures for Aspergillus from the respiratory tract and/or unexplained respiratory deterioration.\n\n Incidence of probable and proven CAPA was compared between patients treated with and without nebulized antifungal prophylaxis using Pearson chi-square test.\n\n\nRESULTS:\nA total of 39 intubated COVID-19 patients could be analyzed, of which 16 were treated with antifungal prophylaxis and 23 were not.\n\n Twenty-six patients underwent bronchoscopy with BAL.\n\n In patients treated with antifungal prophylaxis, the incidence of probable/proven CAPA was significantly lower when compared with no antifungal prophylaxis (27% vs 67%; p = 0.047).\n\n Incidence of tracheobronchial lesions and positive Aspergillus cultures and BAL-galactomannan was significantly lower in patients treated with antifungal prophylaxis (9% vs 47%; p = 0.040, 9% vs 53%; p = 0.044, and 20% vs 60%; p = 0.047, respectively).\n\n No treatment-related adverse events and no case of proven CAPA were encountered in patients receiving antifungal prophylaxis.\n\n\nCONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE:\nNebulization of c-AmB in critically ill COVID-19 patients on IMV is safe and may be considered as antifungal prophylaxis to prevent CAPA.\n\n However, a randomized controlled trial to confirm this is warranted.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9088229","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Max","surname":"Melchers","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Arthur R. W.","surname":"van Bree","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1093/cid/ciab223","date":"1970-01-01","title":"COVID-19 Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis in Mechanically Ventilated Patients","abstract":"Background\nCOVID-19 associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) occurs in critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n\n Risks and outcomes remain poorly understood.\n\n\nMethods\nA retrospective cohort study of adult mechanically ventilated COVID-19 patients admitted to five Johns Hopkins hospitals was conducted between March and August 2020. CAPA was defined using composite clinical criteria.\n\n Fine and Gray competing risks regression was used to analyze clinical outcomes and multilevel mixed-effects ordinal logistic regression was used to compare longitudinal disease severity scores.\n\n\nResults\nAmongst the cohort of 396 people, 39 met criteria for CAPA.\n\n Compared to those without, patients with CAPA were more likely to have underlying pulmonary vascular disease (41% vs 21.6%, p=0.01), liver disease (35.9% vs 18.2%, p=0.02), coagulopathy (51.3% vs 33.1%, p=0.03), solid tumors (25.6% vs 10.9%, p=0.017), multiple myeloma (5.1% vs 0.3%, p=0.027), corticosteroid exposure during index admission (66.7% vs 42.6%, p=0.005), and had a lower BMI (median 26.6 vs 29.9, p=0.04).\n\n People with CAPA had worse outcomes as measured by ordinal severity of disease scores, requiring longer time to improvement (adjusted odds ratio 1.081.091.1, p&lt;0.001), and advancing in severity almost twice as fast (subhazard ratio, sHR 1.31.82.5, p&lt;0.001).\n\n People with CAPA were intubated twice as long as those without (sHR) 0.40.50.6, p&lt;0.001) and had a longer hospital length of stay [median (IQR) 41.1 (20.5, 72.4) vs 18.5 (10.7, 31.8), p&lt;0.001].\n\n\nConclusion\nCAPA is associated with poor outcomes.\n\n Attention towards preventative measures (screening and/or prophylaxis) is warranted in people with high risk of developing A","surname":"Marr","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.cmi.2021.08.014","date":"2021-08-16","title":"Risk factors and outcome of pulmonary aspergillosis in critically ill coronavirus disease 2019 patients—a multinational observational study by the European Confederation of Medical Mycology","abstract":"Objectives\nCoronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) -associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) has emerged as a complication in critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n\n The objectives of this multinational study were to determine the prevalence of CAPA in patients with COVID-19 in intensive care units (ICU) and to investigate risk factors for CAPA as well as outcome.\n\n\nMethods\nThe European Confederation of Medical Mycology (ECMM) conducted a multinational study including 20 centres from nine countries to assess epidemiology, risk factors and outcome of CAPA.\n\n CAPA was defined according to the 2020 ECMM/ISHAM consensus definitions.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 592 patients were included in this study, including 11 (1.9%) patients with histologically proven CAPA, 80 (13.5%) with probable CAPA, 18 (3%) with possible CAPA and 483 (81.6%) without CAPA.\n\n CAPA was diagnosed a median of 8 days (range 0–31 days) after ICU admission predominantly in older patients (adjusted hazard ratio (aHR) 1.04 per year; 95% CI 1.02–1.06) with any form of invasive respiratory support (HR 3.4; 95% CI 1.84–6.25) and receiving tocilizumab (HR 2.45; 95% CI 1.41–4.25).\n\n Median prevalence of CAPA per centre was 10.7% (range 1.7%–26.8%).\n\n CAPA was associated with significantly lower 90-day ICU survival rate (29% in patients with CAPA versus 57% in patients without CAPA; Mantel–Byar p &lt; 0.001) and remained an independent negative prognostic variable after adjusting for other predictors of survival (HR 2.14; 95% CI 1.59–2.87, p ? 0.001).\n\n\nConclusion\nPrevalence of CAPA varied between centres.\n\n CAPA was significantly more prevalent among older patients, patients receiving invasive ventilation and patients receiving tocilizumab, and was an independent strong predictor of ICU mortality.\n\n\n","id":"PMC8387556","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Juergen","surname":"Prattes","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Joost","surname":"Wauters","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Daniele pulmonary aspergillosis among intubated patients with SARS-CoV-2 or influenza pneumonia: a European multicenter comparative cohort study","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Recent multicenter studies identified COVID-19 as a risk factor for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA).\n\n However, no large multicenter study has compared the incidence of IPA between COVID-19 and influenza patients.\n\n\nObjectives\nid='Par2'>To determine the incidence of putative IPA in critically ill SARS-CoV-2 patients, compared with influenza patients.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par3'>This study was a planned ancillary analysis of the coVAPid multicenter retrospective European cohort.\n\n Consecutive adult patients requiring invasive mechanical ventilation for?&gt;?48 h for SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia or influenza pneumonia were included.\n\n The 28-day cumulative incidence of putative IPA, based on Blot definition, was the primary outcome.\n\n IPA incidence was estimated using the Kalbfleisch and Prentice method, considering extubation (dead or alive) within 28 days as competing event.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par4'>A total of 1047 patients were included (566 in the SARS-CoV-2 group and 481 in the influenza group).\n\n The incidence of putative IPA was lower in SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia group (14, 2.5%) than in influenza pneumonia group (29, 6%), adjusted cause-specific hazard ratio (cHR) 3.29 (95% CI 1.53–7.02, p?=?0.0006).\n\n When putative IPA and Aspergillus respiratory tract colonization were combined, the incidence was also significantly lower in the SARS-CoV-2 group, as compared to influenza group (4.1% vs.\n\n 10.2%), adjusted cHR 3.21 (95% CI 1.88–5.46, p?&lt;?0.0001).\n\n In the whole study population, putative IPA was associated with significant increase in 28-day mortality rate, and length of ICU stay, compared with colonized patients, or those with no IPA or Aspergillus colonization.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par5'>Overall, the incidence of putative IPA was low.\n\n Its incidence was significantly lower in patients with SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia than in those with influenza pneumonia.\n\n\nSupplementary Information\nThe online version contains supplementary material invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in a tertiary care center in Mexico City","abstract":"NULL\nInvasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) is a severe infection caused by aspergillus sp.\n\n that usually develops in patients with severe immunosuppression.\n\n IPA has been recently described in critically ill COVID-19 patients (termed as COVID-associated pulmonary aspergillosis, or CAPA) that are otherwise immunocompetent.\n\n In order to describe the characteristics of patients with CAPA, we conducted a retrospective cohort study in a tertiary care center in Mexico City.\n\n We included all patients with confirmed COVID-19 admitted to the intensive care unit that had serum or bronchoalveolar lavage galactomannan measurements.\n\n We used the criteria proposed by Koehler et al.\n\n to establish the diagnosis of CAPA.\n\n Main outcomes were the need for invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV) and in-hospital mortality.\n\n Out of a total of 83 hospitalized patients with COVID-19 in the ICU, 16 (19.3%) met the criteria for CAPA.\n\n All patients diagnosed with CAPA required IMV whereas only 84% of the patients in the non-IPA group needed this intervention (P = 0.09).\n\n In the IPA group, 31% (n = 5) of the patients died, compared to 13% (n = 9) in the non-CAPA group (P = 0.08).\n\n We conclude that CAPA is a frequent co-infection in critically ill COVID-19 patients and is associated with a high mortality rate.\n\n The timely diagnosis and treatment of IPA in these patients is likely to improve their outcome.\n\n\nLay Summary\nWe studied the characteristics of patients with COVID-19-associated invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA).\n\n Patients with CAPA tended to need invasive mechanical ventilation more frequently and to have a higher mortality rate.\n\n national strategy to diagnose COVID-19 associated invasive fungal disease in the ICU","abstract":"Background\nFungal co-infection is a recognised complication of respiratory virus infections, increasing morbidity and mortality, but can be readily treated if diagnosed early.\n\n An increasing number of small studies describing aspergillosis in COVID-19 patients with severe respiratory distress are being reported, but comprehensive data is lacking.\n\n The aim of this study was to determine the incidence, risk factors and impact of invasive fungal disease in adult COVID-19 patients with severe respiratory distress.\n\n\nMethods\nAn evaluation of a national, multi-centre, prospective cohort evaluation of an enhanced testing strategy to diagnose invasive fungal disease in COVID-19 intensive care patients.\n\n Results were used to generate a mechanism to define aspergillosis in future COVID-19 patients.\n\n\nResults\nOne-hundred and thirty-five adults (median age: 57, M/F: 2·2/1) were screened.\n\n The incidence was 26.7% (14.1% aspergillosis, 12·6% yeast infections).\n\n The overall mortality rate was 38%; 53% and 31% in patients with and without fungal disease, respectively (P: 0.0387).\n\n The mortality rate was reduced by the use of antifungal therapy (Mortality: 38·5% in patients receiving therapy versus 90% in patients not receiving therapy (P: 0.008).\n\n The use of corticosteroids (P: 0.007) and history of chronic respiratory disease (P: 0.05) increased the likelihood of aspergillosis.\n\n\nConclusions\nFungal disease occurs frequently in critically ill, mechanically ventilated COVID-19 patients.\n\n The survival benefit observed in patients receiving antifungal therapy implies that the proposed diagnostic and defining criteria are appropriate.\n\n Screening using a strategic diagnostic approach and antifungal prophylaxis of patients with risk factors will likely enhance the management of COVID-19 patients.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7499527","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"P A Nationwide Population-Based Cohort Study","abstract":"Background\nThere are limited data on outcomes of moderate to severe coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) among patients treated with remdesivir nationwide cohorts of individuals hospitalized with COVID-19 during February through December 2020 were studied.\n\n Death within 30 days and need of mechanical ventilation (MV) were compared by Without Remdesivir Treatment in Hospitalized Patients With COVID-19","abstract":"Question\nDoes time to clinical improvement or time to death differ among hospitalized patients treated with vs without remdesivir (alone or with corticosteroids) for coronavirus disease 2019 outside of a clinical trial?\nFindings\nIn this multicenter comparative effectiveness research study that included 2483 consecutive admissions with a high proportion of non-White individuals, treatment with remdesivir was associated with more rapid clinical improvement than no remdesivir receipt in propensity Caleb","surname":"Alexander","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Amita","surname":"Gupta","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Robert","surname":"Bollinger","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yanxun","surname":"Xu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1056/NEJMoa2100433","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Interleukin-6 Receptor Antagonists in Critically Ill Patients with Covid-19","abstract":"Background\nThe efficacy of interleukin-6 receptor antagonists in critically ill patients with coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) is unclear.\n\n\nMethods\nWe evaluated tocilizumab and sarilumab in an ongoing international, multifactorial, adaptive platform trial.\n\n Adult patients with Covid-19, within 24 hours after starting organ support in the intensive care unit (ICU), were randomly assigned to receive tocilizumab (8 mg per kilogram of body weight), sarilumab (400 mg), or standard care (control).\n\n The primary outcome was respiratory and cardiovascular organ support–free days, on an ordinal scale combining in-hospital death (assigned a value of ?1) and days free of organ support to day 21. The trial uses a Bayesian statistical model with predefined criteria for superiority, efficacy, equivalence, or futility.\n\n An odds ratio greater than 1 represented improved survival, more organ support–free days, or both.\n\n\nResults\nBoth tocilizumab and sarilumab met the predefined criteria for efficacy.\n\n At that time, 353 patients had been assigned to tocilizumab, 48 to sarilumab, and 402 to control.\n\n The median number of organ support–free days was 10 (interquartile range, ?1 to 16) in the tocilizumab group, 11 (interquartile range, 0 to 16) in the sarilumab group, and 0 (interquartile range, ?1 to 15) in the control group.\n\n The median adjusted cumulative odds ratios were 1.64 (95% credible interval, 1.25 to 2.14) for tocilizumab and 1.76 (95% credible interval, 1.17 to 2.91) for sarilumab as compared with control, yielding posterior probabilities of superiority to control of more than 99.9% and of 99.5%, respectively.\n\n An analysis of 90-day survival showed improved survival in the pooled interleukin-6 receptor antagonist groups, yielding a hazard ratio for the comparison with the control group of 1.61 (95% credible interval, 1.25 to 2.08) and a posterior probability of superiority of more than 99.9%.\n\n All secondary analyses supported efficacy of these interleukin-6 receptor antagonists.\n\n\nConclusions\nIn critically ill patients with Covid-19 receiving organ support in ICUs, treatment with the interleukin-6 receptor antagonists tocilizumab and sarilumab improved outcomes, including survival.\n\n (REMAP-CAP ClinicalTrials.\n\ngov number, NCT02735707.\n\n)\n","id":"PMC7953461","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"NULL","surname":"NULL","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.eclinm.2022.101489","date":"2022-05-16","title":"Baricitinib in hospitalised patients with COVID-19: A meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials","abstract":"Background\nTo date, only dexamethasone and tocilizumab have been shown to reduce mortality in patients with COVID-19. Baricitinib is a Janus kinase 1/2 inhibitor with known anti-inflammatory and anti-viral properties.\n\n We performed a meta-analysis of RCTs assessing the role of baricitinib in hospitalised patients with COVID-19.\nMethods\nElectronic databases such as MEDLINE, EMBASE, and Cochrane Central were searched up until March 31, 2022, for RCTs evaluating the efficacy of baricitinib in hospitalised patients with COVID-19. The outcomes assessed were 28-day mortality, progression to invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV) or ECMO, progression to respiratory failure needing positive pressure ventilation, IMV or death, duration of hospitalisation and time to discharge.\n\n The meta-analysis was registered in the PROSPERO database (CRD42022314579).\n\n\nFindings\nFour studies (with 10,815 patients) were included in the analysis.\n\n Pooled analysis using random-effects model showed a statistically significant reduction in 28-day mortality (OR 0.69, 95% CI 0.50-0.94; p=0.04, I2=65%) and composite outcome of progression to severe disease needing positive pressure ventilation, IMV or death (OR 0.89, 95% CI 0.80-0.99, p= 0.03, I2=0%).\n\n There was a favorable trend towards reduced progression to IMV or ECMO (OR 0.76, 95% CI 0.58-1.01; p=0.06, I2=49%) in the baricitinib arm compared to standard therapy, even though it was not statistically significant.\n\n Statistical significance was achieved for all outcomes with fixed-effects model analysis.\n\n\nInterpretation\nIn hospitalised patients with COVID-19, baricitinib was associated with reduced 28-day mortality although there was not a statistically significant reduction in progression to IMV or ECMO.\n\n Baricitinib used in conjunction with standard of care treatments is associated with improved mortality in hospitalised patients with COVID-19 disease.\n\n\nFunding\nNone.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9163705","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Vijairam","surname":"Selvaraj","email":"vijairam.selvaraj@lifespan.org","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Arkadiy","surname":"Finn","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Amos","surname":"Lal","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Mohammad Saud","surname":"Khan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kwame","surname":"Dapaah-Afriyie","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Gerardo P.","surname":"Carino","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/S2213-2600(22)00297-1","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Anti-C5a antibody (vilobelimab) therapy for critically ill, invasively mechanically ventilated patients with COVID-19 (PANAMO): a multicentre, double-blind, randomised, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial","abstract":"Background\nVilobelimab, an anti-C5a monoclonal antibody, was shown to be safe in a phase 2 trial of invasively mechanically ventilated patients with COVID-19. Here, we aimed to determine whether vilobelimab in addition to standard of care improves survival outcomes in this patient population.\n\n\nMethods\nThis randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multicentre phase 3 trial was performed at 46 hospitals in the Netherlands, Germany, France, Belgium, Russia, Brazil, Peru, Mexico, and South Africa.\n\n Participants aged 18 years or older who were receiving invasive mechanical ventilation, but not more than 48 h after intubation at time of first infusion, had a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 60–200 mm Hg, and a confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection with any variant in the past 14 days were eligible for this study.\n\n Eligible patients were randomly assigned (1:1) to receive standard of care and vilobelimab at a dose of 800 mg intravenously for a maximum of six doses (days 1, 2, 4, 8, 15, and 22) or standard of care and a matching placebo using permuted block randomisation.\n\n Treatment was not continued after hospital discharge.\n\n Participants, caregivers, and assessors were masked to group assignment.\n\n The primary outcome was defined as all-cause mortality at 28 days in the full analysis set (defined as all randomly assigned participants regardless of whether a patient started treatment, excluding patients randomly assigned in error) and measured using Kaplan-Meier analysis.\n\n Safety analyses included all patients who had received at least one infusion of either vilobelimab or placebo.\n\n This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.\n\ngov, NCT04333420.\n\n\nFindings\nFrom Oct 1, 2020, to Oct 4, 2021, we included 368 patients in the ITT analysis (full analysis set; 177 in the vilobelimab group and 191 in the placebo group).\n\n One patient in the vilobelimab group was excluded from the primary analysis due to random assignment in error without treatment.\n\n At least one dose of study treatment was given to 364 (99%) patients (safety analysis set).\n\n 54 patients (31%) of 177 in the vilobelimab group and 77 patients (40%) of 191 in the placebo group died in the first 28 days.\n\n The all-cause mortality rate at 28 days was 32% (95% CI 25–39) in the vilobelimab group and 42% (35–49) in the placebo group (hazard ratio 0·73, 95% CI 0·50–1·06; p=0·094).\n\n In the predefined analysis without site-stratification, vilobelimab significantly reduced all-cause mortality at 28 days (HR 0·67, 95% CI 0·48–0·96; p=0·027).\n\n The most common TEAEs were acute kidney injury (35 [20%] of 175 in the vilobelimab group vs 40 [21%] of 189 in the placebo), pneumonia (38 [22%] vs 26 [14%]), and septic shock (24 [14%] vs 31 [16%]).\n\n Serious treatment-emergent adverse events were reported in 103 (59%) of 175 patients in the vilobelimab group versus 120 (63%) of 189 in the placebo group.\n\n\nInterpretation\nIn addition to standard of care, vilobelimab improves survival of invasive mechanically ventilated patients with COVID-19 and leads to a significant decrease in mortality.\n\n Vilobelimab could be considered as an additional therapy for patients in this setting and further research is needed on the role of vilobelimab and C5a in other acute respiratory distress syndrome-causing viral infections.\n\n\nFunding\nInflaRx and the German Federal Government.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9451499","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Alexander P Care and Organ Support Related Mortality in Patients With COVID-19: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis","abstract":"DATA SOURCES:\nA systematic search of PubMed, Embase, and the Cochrane databases was conducted up to December 31, 2021.\nSTUDY SELECTION:\nPreviously peer-reviewed observational studies that reported ICU, mechanical ventilation (MV), renal replacement therapy (RRT) or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)-related mortality among greater than or equal to 100 individual patients.\n\n\nDATA EXTRACTION:\nRandom-effects meta-analysis was used to generate pooled estimates of case fatality rates (CFRs) for in-hospital, ICU, MV, RRT, and ECMO-related mortality.\n\n ICU-related mortality was additionally analyzed by the study country of origin.\n\n Sensitivity analyses of CFR were assessed based on completeness of follow-up data, by year, and when only studies judged to be of high quality were included.\n\n\nDATA SYNTHESIS:\nOne hundred fifty-seven studies evaluating 948,309 patients were included.\n\n The CFR for in-hospital mortality, ICU mortality, MV, RRT, and ECMO were 25.9% (95% CI: 24.0–27.8%), 37.3% (95% CI: 34.6–40.1%), 51.6% (95% CI: 46.1–57.0%), 66.1% (95% CI: 59.7–72.2%), and 58.0% (95% CI: 46.9–68.9%), respectively.\n\n MV (52.7%, 95% CI: 47.5–58.0% vs 31.3%, 95% CI: 16.1–48.9%; p = 0.023) and RRT-related mortality (66.7%, 95% CI: 60.1–73.0% vs 50.3%, 95% CI: 42.4–58.2%; p = 0.003) decreased from 2020 to 2021.\nCONCLUSIONS:\nWe present updated estimates of CFR for patients hospitalized and requiring intensive care for the management of COVID-19. Although mortality remain high and varies considerably worldwide, we found the CFR in patients supported with MV significantly improved since 2020.\n","id":"PMC9988289","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Abhimanyu","surname":"Chandel","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Sahar","surname":"Leazer","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Karl found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1038/s41564-022-01172-2","date":"2022-06-13","title":"COVID-19-associated fungal infections","abstract":"id='Par1'>Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)-associated invasive fungal infections are an important complication in a substantial number of critically ill, hospitalized patients with COVID-19. Three groups of fungal pathogens cause co-infections in COVID-19: Aspergillus, Mucorales and Candida species, including Candida auris.\n Here we review the incidence of COVID-19-associated invasive fungal infections caused by these fungi in low-, middle- and high-income countries.\n By evaluating the epidemiology, clinical risk factors, predisposing features of the host environment and immunological mechanisms that underlie the pathogenesis of these co-infections, we set the scene for future research and development of clinical guidance.\n","id":"PMC9362108","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Martin","surname":"Hoenigl","email":"hoeniglmartin@gmail.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Danila","surname":"Seidel","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Danila","surname":"Seidel","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Rosanne","surname":"Sprute","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Cristina","surname":"Cunha","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Cristina","surname":"Cunha","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Matteo","surname":"Oliverio","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Matteo","surname":"Oliverio","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Gustavo
