and outcomes of co-infection and superinfection with SARS-CoV-2 and other pathogens: A systematic review and meta-analysis","abstract":"Introduction\nThe recovery of other pathogens in patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection has been reported, either at the time of a SARS-CoV-2 infection diagnosis (co-infection) or subsequently (superinfection).\n\n However, data on the prevalence, microbiology, and outcomes of co-infection and superinfection are limited.\n\n The purpose of this study was to examine the occurrence of co-infections and superinfections and their outcomes among patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection.\n\n\nPatients and methods\nWe searched literature databases for studies published from October 1, 2019, through February 8, 2021. We included studies that reported clinical features and outcomes of co-infection or superinfection of SARS-CoV-2 and other pathogens in hospitalized and non-hospitalized patients.\n\n We followed PRISMA guidelines, and we registered the protocol with PROSPERO as: CRD42020189763.\nResults\nOf 6639 articles screened, 118 were included in the random effects meta-analysis.\n\n The pooled prevalence of co-infection was 19% (95% confidence interval [CI]: 14%-25%, I2 = 98%) and that of superinfection was 24% (95% CI: 19%-30%).\n\n Pooled prevalence of pathogen type stratified by co- or superinfection were: viral co-infections, 10% (95% CI: 6%-14%); viral superinfections, 4% (95% CI: 0%-10%); bacterial co-infections, 8% (95% CI: 5%-11%); bacterial superinfections, 20% (95% CI: 13%-28%); fungal co-infections, 4% (95% CI: 2%-7%); and fungal superinfections, 8% (95% CI: 4%-13%).\n\n Patients with a co-infection or superinfection had higher odds of dying than those who only had SARS-CoV-2 infection (odds ratio = 3.31, 95% CI: 1.82–5.99).\n\n Compared to those with co-infections, patients with superinfections had a higher prevalence of mechanical ventilation (45% [95% CI: 33%-58%] vs.\n\n 10% [95% CI: 5%-16%]), but patients with co-infections had a greater average length of hospital stay than those with superinfections (mean = 29.0 days, standard deviation [SD] = 6.7 vs.\n\n mean = 16 days, SD = 6.2, respectively).\n\n\nConclusions\nOur study showed that as many as 19% of patients with COVID-19 have co-infections and 24% have superinfections.\n\n The presence of either co-infection or superinfection was associated with poor outcomes, including increased mortality.\n\n Our findings support the need for diagnostic testing to identify and treat co-occurring respiratory infections among patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection.\n\n\n","id":"PMC8101968","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jackson C","surname":"Huber","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.jointm.2021.07.001","date":"2021-07-07","title":"COVID-19-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis (CAPA)","abstract":"Invasive Pulmonary Aspergillosis (IPA) has been recognized as a possible secondary infection complicating Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and increasing mortality.\n The aim of this review was to report and summarize the available data in the literature concerning the incidence, pathophysiology, diagnosis, and treatment of COVID-19-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis (CAPA).\n Currently, the incidence of CAPA is unclear due to different definitions and diagnostic criteria used among the studies.\n It was estimated that approximately 8.6% (206/2383) of mechanically ventilated patients were diagnosed with either proven, probable, or putative CAPA.\n Classical host factors of invasive aspergillosis are rarely recognized in patients with CAPA, who are mainly immuno-competent presenting with comorbidities, while the role of steroids warrants further investigation.\n Direct epithelial injury and diffuse pulmonary micro thrombi in combination with immune dysregulation, hyper inflammatory response, and immunosuppressive treatment may be implicated.\n Discrimination between two forms of CAPA (e.\ng.\n, tracheobronchial and parenchymal) is required, whereas radiological signs of aspergillosis are not typically evident in patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia.\n In previous studies, the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer/Mycoses Study Group (EORTC/MSG) criteria, a clinical algorithm to diagnose Invasive Pulmonary Aspergillosis in intensive care unit patients (AspICU algorithm), and influenza-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (IAPA) criteria were used for the diagnosis of proven/probable and putative CAPA, as well as the differentiation from colonization, which can be challenging.\n Aspergillus fumigatus is the most commonly isolated pathogen in respiratory cultures.\n Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) and serum galactomannan (GM), ?-d-glucan (with limited specificity), polymerase chain reaction (PCR), and Aspergillus-specific lateral-flow device test can be included in the diagnostic work-up; however, these approaches are characterized by low sensitivity.\n Early treatment of CAPA is necessary, and 71.4% (135/189) of patients received antifungal therapy, mainly with voriconazole, isavuconazole, and liposomal amphotericin B .\n Given the high mortality rate among patients with Aspergillus infection, the administration of prophylactic treatment is debated.\n In conclusion, different diagnostic strategies are necessary to differentiate colonization from bronchial or parenchymal infection in intubated COVID-19 patients with Aspergillus spp.\n in their respiratory specimens vs.\n those not infected with severe acute respiratory syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).\n Following confirmation, voriconazole or isavuconazole should be used for the treatment of CAPA.\n","id":"PMC8346330","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"George","surname":"Dimopoulos","email":"gdimop@med.uoa.gr","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Maria-Panagiota","surname":"Almyroudi","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Pavlos","surname":"Myrianthefs","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jordi","surname":"Rello","email":"jrello@crips.es","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1111/myc.13183","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Bronchoscopy safety precautions for diagnosing COVID-19 associated pulmonary aspergillosis:A simulation study","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1097/MCC.0000000000000977","date":"1970-01-01","title":"COVID-19-associated pulmonary aspergillosis: an underdiagnosed or overtreated infection?","abstract":"Recent findings\nThe incidence of CAPA ranges 3--28% of critically ill patients, depending on the definition used, study design, and systematic or triggered screening.\n\n COVID-19 is associated with direct damage of the respiratory epithelium, immune dysregulation, and common use of immunosuppressive drugs which might promote Aspergillus respiratory tract colonization and invasion.\n\n Positive Aspergillus tests among COVID-19 critically patients might reflect colonization rather than invasive disease.\n\n CAPA usually appears during the second week after starting invasive mechanical ventilation and is independently associated with ICU mortality.\n\n\nSummary\nFurther studies are needed to validate CAPA case definitions, to determine the accurate incidence of CAPA in comparison to adequate controls, and its evolution during the pandemic.\n\n A pro-active diagnostic strategy, based on risk stratification, clinical assessment, and bronchoalveolar lavage could be recommended to provide early antifungal treatment in patients with high probability of CAPA and clinical deterioration.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9593325","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Anahita","surname":"Rouzé","email":"anahita.rouze@chru-lille.fr","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ignacio","surname":"Martin-Loeches","email":"drmartinloeches@gmail.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Saad","surname":"Nseir","email":"saadalla.nseir@chu-lille.fr","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1007/s00134-021-06449-4","date":"2021-05-28","title":"Taskforce report on the diagnosis and clinical management of COVID-19 associated pulmonary aspergillosis","abstract":"Purpose\nid='Par1'>Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) is increasingly reported in patients with severe coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU).\n\n Diagnosis and management of COVID-19 associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) are challenging and our aim was to develop practical guidance.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>A group of 28 international experts reviewed current insights in the epidemiology, diagnosis and management of CAPA and developed recommendations using GRADE methodology.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>The prevalence of CAPA varied between 0 and 33%, which may be partly due to variable case definitions, but likely represents true variation.\n\n Bronchoscopy and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) remain the cornerstone of CAPA diagnosis, allowing for diagnosis of invasive Aspergillus tracheobronchitis and collection of the best validated specimen for Aspergillus diagnostics.\n\n Most patients diagnosed with CAPA lack traditional host factors, but pre-existing structural lung disease and immunomodulating therapy may predispose to CAPA risk.\n\n Computed tomography seems to be of limited value to rule CAPA in or out, and serum biomarkers are negative in 85% of patients.\n\n As the mortality of CAPA is around 50%, antifungal therapy is recommended for BAL positive patients, but the decision to treat depends on the patients’ clinical condition and the institutional incidence of CAPA.\n\n We recommend against routinely stopping concomitant corticosteroid or IL-6 blocking therapy in CAPA patients.\n\n\nConclusion\nid='Par4'>CAPA is a complex disease involving a continuum of respiratory colonization, tissue invasion and angioinvasive disease.\n\n Knowledge gaps including true epidemiology, optimal diagnostic work-up, management strategies and role of host-directed therapy require further study.\n\n\nSupplementary Information\nThe online version contains supplementary material available at found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1177/08850666211047166","date":"2021-09-01","title":"Practice Guidelines for the Diagnosis of COVID-19-Associated Pulmonary Aspergillosis in an Intensive Care Setting","abstract":"Coronavirus disease-2019 (COVID-19)-associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) is a new disease characterized by secondary Aspergillus mold infection in patients with COVID-19. It primarily affects patients with COVID-19 in critical state with acute respiratory distress syndrome, requiring intensive care and mechanical ventilation.\n CAPA has a higher mortality rate than COVID-19, posing a serious threat to affected individuals.\n COVID-19 is a potential risk factor for CAPA and has already claimed a massive death toll worldwide since its outbreak in December 2019. Its second wave is currently progressing towards a peak, while the third wave of this devastating pandemic is expected to follow.\n Therefore, an early and accurate diagnosis of CAPA is of utmost importance for effective clinical management of this highly fatal disease.\n However, there are no uniform criteria for diagnosing CAPA in an intensive care setting.\n Therefore, based on a review of existing information and our own experience, we have proposed new criteria in the form of practice guidelines for diagnosing CAPA, focusing on the points relevant for intensivists and pulmonary and critical care physicians.\n The main highlights of these guidelines include the role of CAPA-appropriate test specimens, clinical risk factors, computed tomography of the thorax, and non-culture-based indirect and direct mycological evidence for diagnosing CAPA in the intensive care unit.\n These guidelines classify the diagnosis of CAPA into suspected, possible, and probable categories to facilitate clinical decision-making.\n We hope that these practice guidelines will adequately address the diagnostic challenges of CAPA, providing an easy-to-use and practical algorithm to clinicians for rapid diagnosis and clinical management of the disease.\n","id":"PMC9353310","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Zia","surname":"Hashim","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Zafar","surname":"Neyaz","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Rungmei Corticosteroid Duration in Intensive Care Patients","abstract":"Background\nCoronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)–associated pulmonary aspergillosis (CAPA) is a potential complication in critically ill COVID-19 patients.\n\n Corticosteroids are standard of care for hospitalized COVID-19 patients but carry an increased risk of secondary infections including CAPA.\n\n The objective of this study was to evaluate if duration of corticosteroid therapy ?10?days versus &gt;10?days affects the risk of developing CAPA.\n\n\nMethods\nThis was a retrospective cohort study of adult patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia requiring mechanical ventilation who received at least 3?days of corticosteroid treatment.\n\n Incidence of CAPA and secondary outcomes were compared using appropriate bivariable analyses.\n\n Steroid duration was evaluated as an independent predictor in a logistic regression model.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 278 patients were included (n = 169 for ?10?days’ steroid duration; n = 109 for &gt;10?days).\n\n CAPA developed in 20 of 278 (7.2%) patients.\n\n Patients treated with &gt;10?days of corticosteroid therapy had significantly higher incidence of CAPA (11.9% vs 4.1%; P = .\n\n0156), and steroid duration &gt;10?days was independently associated with CAPA (odds ratio, 3.17 [95% confidence interval, 1.02–9.83]).\n\n Secondary outcomes including inpatient mortality (77.1% vs 43.2%; P &lt; .\n\n0001), mechanical ventilation–free days at 28 days (0 vs 1.5; P &lt; .\n\n0001), and secondary infections (44.9% vs 28.4% P = .\n\n0220) were worse in the &gt;10?days cohort.\n\n\nConclusions\nCorticosteroid treatment &gt;10?days in critically ill COVID-19 patients is associated with an increased risk of CAPA.\n\n Patients may require corticosteroids for reasons beyond COVID-19 and clinicians should be cognizant of risk of CAPA with prolonged courses.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9984984","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Meera","surname":"Shah","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kelly","surname":"Reveles","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kelly","surname":"Reveles","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Rebecca","surname":"Moote","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Elizabeth","surname":"Hand","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Dean","surname":"Kellogg Recommendations and Future Considerations","abstract":"Invasive mold diseases are devastating systemic infections which demand meticulous care in selection, dosing, and therapy monitoring of antifungal drugs.\n Various circumstances regarding PK/PD properties of the applied drug, resistance/tolerance of the causative pathogen or host intolerability can lead to failure of the initial antifungal therapy.\n This necessitates treatment adaption in the sense of switching antifungal drug class or potentially adding another drug for a combination therapy approach.\n In the current state of drastically limited options of antifungal drug classes adaption of therapy remains challenging.\n Current guidelines provide restricted recommendations only and emphasize individual approaches.\n However, novel antifungals, incorporating innovative mechanisms of action, show promising results in late stage clinical development.\n These will expand options for salvage therapy in the future potentially as monotherapy or in combination with conventional or other novel antifungals.\n We outline current recommendations for salvage therapy including PK/PD considerations as well as elucidate possible future treatment options for invasive aspergillosis and drugs TDM: Trends and update","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12941-017-0235-8","date":"2017-08-31","title":"Voriconazole and posaconazole therapeutic drug monitoring: a retrospective study","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) aims to minimize the clinical impact of posaconazole and voriconazole pharmacokinetic variability.\n\n However, its benefits on clinical outcomes are still being defined.\n\n Additionally, TDM data are limited for posaconazole IV and delayed-release tablet formulations among specific patient populations, including critically ill.\n\n The aim of this study was to determine the percentage of therapeutic posaconazole and voriconazole drug levels across all formulations in a real-world clinical setting and elucidate factors affecting attainment of target concentrations.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>This study was a retrospective cohort study conducted at the University of Colorado Hospital between September 2006 and June 2015 that evaluated patients who received posaconazole or voriconazole TDM as part of routine care.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>Voriconazole (n = 250) and posaconazole (n = 100) levels were analyzed from 151 patients.\n\n Of these, 54% of voriconazole and 69% of posaconazole levels were therapeutic.\n\n For posaconazole, 14/38 (37%), 28/29 (97%) and 27/33 (82%) levels were therapeutic for the oral suspension, IV, and delayed-release tablet, respectively.\n\n Intravenous and delayed-release tablet posaconazole were 20 fold (p &lt; 0.01) and sevenfold (p = 0.002) more likely than the oral suspension to achieve a therapeutic level.\n\n Subsequent levels were more likely to be therapeutic after dose adjustments (OR 3.31; 95% CI 1.3–8.6; p = 0.02), regardless of timing of initial non-therapeutic level.\n\n In a multivariable logistic regression analysis, no characteristics were independently predictive of therapeutic voriconazole levels and only absence of H2RA/PPI use was independently predictive of therapeutic posaconazole levels.\n\n There was no correlation between survival and therapeutic drug levels for either voriconazole (p = 0.67) or posaconazole (p = 0.50).\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>A high percentage of drug levels did not achieve TDM targets for voriconazole and posaconazole oral suspension, supporting the need for routine TDM for those formulations.\n\n The utility of TDM for the IV and delayed-release tablet formulations of posaconazole is less apparent.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5594434","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Whitley clinical algorithm including fungal biomarkers to better diagnose probable invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in ICU","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>The classification of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) issued by the European Organization for the Research and Treatment of Cancer/Mycoses Study Group Education and Research Consortium (EORTC/MSGERC) is used for immunocompromised patients.\n\n An alternative algorithm adapted to the intensive care unit (ICU) population has been proposed (AspICU), but this algorithm did not include microbial biomarkers such as the galactomannan antigen and the Aspergillus quantitative PCR.\n\n The objective of the present pilot study was to evaluate a new algorithm that includes fungal biomarkers (BM-AspICU) for the diagnosis of probable IPA in an ICU population.\n\n\nPatients and methods\nid='Par3'>Data from 35 patients with pathology-proven IPA according to European Organization for the Research and Treatment of Cancer/Mycosis Study Group (EORTC/MSGERC)-2008 criteria were extracted from the French multicenter database of the Invasive Fungal Infections Surveillance Network (RESSIF).\n\n The patients were investigated according to the AspICU algorithm, and the BM-AspICU algorithm in analyzing the clinical, imaging, and biomarker data available in the records, without taking into account the pathology findings.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par4'>Eight patients had to be excluded because no imaging data were recorded in the database.\n\n Among the 27 proven IPAs with complete data, 16 would have been considered as putative IPA with the AspICU algorithm and 24 would have been considered as probable IPA using the new algorithm BM-AspICU.\n\n Seven out of the 8 patients with probable BM-AspICU IPA (and not classified with the AspICU algorithm) had no host factors and no Aspergillus-positive broncho-alveolar lavage fluid (BALF) culture.\n\n Three patients were non-classifiable with any of the two algorithms, because they did not have any microbial criteria during the course of the infection, and diagnosis of proven aspergillosis was done using autopsy samples.\n\n\nConclusion\nid='Par5'>Inclusion of biomarkers could be effective to identify probable IPA in the ICU population.\n\n A prospective study is needed to validate the routine application of the BM-AspICU algorithm in the ICU population.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7938267","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Joffrey","surname":"Hamam","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jean-Christophe","surname":"Navellou","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Anne-Pauline","surname":"Bellanger","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Stéphane","surname":"Bretagne","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hadrien","surname":"Winiszewski","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Emeline","surname":"Scherer","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Gael","surname":"Piton","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Laurence","surname":"Millon","email":"lmillon@chu-besancon.fr","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"NULL","surname":"NULL","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"NULL","surname":"NULL","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]}]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Causes 2":[{"doi":"10.1128/JCM.43.11.5721-5732.2005","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Defining the normal bacterial flora of the oral cavity","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1378/chest.09-1103","date":"1970-01-01","title":"The effect of chronic infection with Aspergillus fumigatus on lung function and hospitalization in patients with cystic fibrosis","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0098502","date":"2014-05-03","title":"Multi-Country Estimate of Different Manifestations of Aspergillosis in Cystic Fibrosis","abstract":"\nAspergillus spp.\n can lead to allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), Aspergillus sensitisation and Aspergillus bronchitis in CF.\n The relative frequencies of these entities have recently been ascertained in a large UK adult CF cohort.\n We have used this data to estimate the burden of aspergillosis and ABPA cases in adult CF patients in 30 countries reporting CF.\n National and international CF registry data was accessed and assessed for completeness and age distribution.\n Published proportions of ABPA (17.7%), Aspergillus sensitisation (14.6%) and Aspergillus bronchitis (30%) in CF were applied to those &gt;18 years and compared with notified ABPA cases.\n Of the 76,201 estimated CF patients worldwide (not including India), 37,714 were &gt;18 years.\n The proportion of adults to children varied from 63% in Norway to 20% in Brazil.\n ABPA caseload in adults is anticipated to be 6,675 cases of which only 2,221 cases (33%) are currently recorded, indicating substantial underdiagnosis.\n The ABPA diagnosis rate compared with estimated rates varies by country from 101% (France) to 14.5% (Greece), although genetic variation could account for genuine differences compared with the UK.\n Aspergillus bronchitis is not currently recognised or recorded in CF registries but there are an anticipated 10,988 adult cases.\n Aspergillus sensitisation, associated with increased bronchiectasis and reduced FEV1, affects an anticipated 5,506 patients without ABPA or Aspergillus bronchitis.\n Together ABPA and Aspergillus bronchitis are estimated to affect 17,989 adults, 47.7% of the adult CF population.\n ABPA also occurs in children and teenagers and 984 cases were documented in registries.\n Diagnosed ABPA rates by age were available for the ECFS registry, USA, UK, Ireland, Belgium and Netherlands.\n The rate was &lt;1% under 4 years, and increased throughout childhood and adolescence, with marked variation between countries.\n Newly published diagnostic criteria and methods should facilitate better recognition of aspergillosis in CF, allowing better CF disease control.\n","id":"PMC4051580","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Joanne","surname":"Armstead","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Julie","surname":"Morris","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"David microbiota in mice.\n\n The aim of this study was to examine the lung microbiome in mice, the most used animal model for inflammatory lung diseases such as COPD, cystic fibrosis and asthma.\n\n\nResults\nUsing a customized 16S rRNA sequencing protocol amplifying the V3-V4 region our study shows that the mice have a lung microbiome that cluster separately from mouse intestinal microbiome (caecum).\n\n The mouse lung microbiome is dominated by Proteobacteria, Firmicutes, Actinobacteria, Bacteroidetes and Cyanobacteria overlapping the vaginal microbiome.\n\n We also show that removal of host tissue or cells from lung fluid during the DNA extraction step has an impact on the resulting bacterial community profile.\n\n Sample preparation needs to be considered when choosing an extraction method and interpreting data.\n\n\nConclusions\nWe have consistently amplified bacterial DNA from mouse lungs that is distinct from the intestinal microbiome in these mice.\n\n The gut microbiome has been extensively studied for its links to development of disease.\n\n Here we suggest that also the lung microbiome could be important in relation to inflammatory lung diseases.\n\n microbiome of chronic rhinosinusitis: culture, molecular diagnostics and biofilm detection","abstract":"Background\nBacteria and fungi are believed to influence mucosal inflammation in chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS).\n\n However their presence and relationship to disease is debated.\n\n This study used multiple detection methods to compare microbial diversity and microbial abundance in healthy and diseased sinonasal mucosa.\n\n The utility of contemporary detection methods is also examined.\n\n\nMethods\nSinonasal mucosa was analyzed from 38 CRS and 6 controls.\n\n Bacterial and fungal analysis was performed using conventional culture, molecular diagnostics (polymerase chain reaction coupled with electrospray ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry) and fluorescence in situ hybridization.\n\n\nResults\nMicrobes were detected in all samples, including controls, and were often polymicrobial.\n\n 33 different bacterial species were detected in CRS, 5 in control patients, with frequent recovery of anaerobes.\n\n Staphylococcus aureus and Propionibacterium acnes were the most common organisms in CRS and controls, respectively.\n\n Using a model organism, FISH had a sensitivity of 78%, and a specificity of 93%.\n\n Many species were detected in both CRS and controls however, microbial abundance was associated with disease manifestation.\n\n\nConclusions\nThis study highlights some cornerstones of microbial variations in healthy and diseased paranasal sinuses.\n\n Whilst the healthy sinus is clearly not sterile, it appears prevalence and abundance of organisms is critical in determining disease.\n\n Evidence from high-sensitivity techniques, limits the role of fungi in CRS to a small group of patients.\n\n Comparison with molecular analysis suggests that the detection threshold of FISH and culture is related to organism abundance and, furthermore, culture tends to select for rapidly growing organisms.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3654890","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Sam","surname":"Boase","email":"samboase@gmail.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Andrew","surname":"Foreman","email":"aforeman@adam.com.au","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Edward","surname":"Cleland","email":"edwardcleland@gmail.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lorwai","surname":"Tan","email":"lorwai.tan@adelaide.edu.au","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Rachel","surname":"Melton-Kreft","email":"RKREFT1@wpahs.org","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Harshita","surname":"Pant","email":"mail@hpant.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Fen found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0042786","date":"2012-07-12","title":"Assessing Bacterial Populations in the Lung by Replicate Analysis of Samples from the Upper and Lower Respiratory Tracts","abstract":"Microbes of the human respiratory tract are important in health and disease, but accurate sampling of the lung presents challenges.\n Lung microbes are commonly sampled by bronchoscopy, but to acquire samples the bronchoscope must pass through the upper respiratory tract, which is rich in microbes.\n Here we present methods to identify authentic lung microbiota in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid that contains substantial oropharyngeal admixture.\n We studied clinical BAL samples from six selected subjects with potential heavy lung colonization.\n A single sample of BAL fluid was obtained from each subject along with contemporaneous oral wash (OW) to sample the oropharynx, and then DNA was extracted from three separate aliquots of each.\n Bacterial 16S rDNA sequences were amplified and products analyzed by 454 pyrosequencing.\n By comparing replicates, we were able to specify the depth of sequencing needed to reach a 95% chance of identifying a bacterial lineage of a given proportion—for example, at a depth of 5,000 tags, OTUs of proportion 0.3% or greater would be called with 95% confidence.\n We next constructed a single-sided outlier test that allowed lung-enriched organisms to be quantified against a background of oropharyngeal admixture, and assessed improvements available with replicate sequence analysis.\n This allowed identification of lineages enriched in lung in some BAL specimens.\n Finally, using samples from healthy volunteers collected at multiple sites in the upper respiratory tract, we show that OW provides a reasonable but not perfect surrogate for bacteria carried into to the lung by a bronchoscope.\n These methods allow identification of microbes that can replicate in the lung despite the background due to oropharyngeal microbes derived from aspiration and bronchoscopic Cigarette Smokers","abstract":"Cigarette smokers have an increased risk of infectious diseases involving the respiratory tract.\n Some effects of smoking on specific respiratory tract bacteria have been described, but the consequences for global airway microbial community composition have not been determined.\n Here, we used culture-independent high-density sequencing to analyze the microbiota from the right and left nasopharynx and oropharynx of 29 smoking and 33 nonsmoking healthy asymptomatic adults to assess microbial composition and effects of cigarette smoking.\n Bacterial communities were profiled using 454 pyrosequencing of 16S sequence tags (803,391 total reads), aligned to 16S rRNA databases, and communities compared using the UniFrac distance metric.\n A Random Forest machine-learning algorithm was used to predict smoking status and identify taxa that best distinguished between smokers and nonsmokers.\n Community composition was primarily determined by airway site, with individuals exhibiting minimal side-of-body or temporal variation.\n Within airway habitats, microbiota from smokers were significantly more diverse than nonsmokers and clustered separately.\n The distributions of several genera were systematically altered by smoking in both the oro- and nasopharynx, and there was an enrichment of anaerobic lineages associated with periodontal disease in the oropharynx.\n These results indicate that distinct regions of the human upper respiratory tract contain characteristic microbial communities that exhibit disordered patterns in cigarette smokers, both in individual components and global structure, which may contribute to the prevalence of respiratory tract complications in this fumigatus.\n\n\nConclusions\nIn light of the recent concept of CF lung microbiota, we viewed the microbial community as a unique pathogenic entity.\n\n We thus interpreted our results to highlight the secondary care have fungal sensitization, and an estimated 4.8 million adults have allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).\n There is much uncertainty about which fungi and fungal allergens are relevant to asthma, the natural history of sensitisation to fungi, if there is an exposure response relationship for fungal allergy, and the pathogenesis and frequency of exacerbations and complications.\n Genetic associations have been described but only weakly linked to phenotypes.\n The evidence base for most management strategies in ABPA, SAFS and related conditions is weak.\n Yet Amplicon-based Taxonomy: Discovery of <italic>Malassezia</italic> as a Prominent Commensal","abstract":"Fungi are a large, complex group, increasingly recognized as emerging threats.\n Their roles as modifiers of health mandate accurate portrayals of fungal communities in humans.\n As an entry point into the airways and gastrointestinal tract, fungi in the mouth are relevant to several biocompartments.\n We have revised current practices in sequence-based taxonomy assignments and employed the improvements to address the question of the fungal genera present in the healthy human mouth.\n The human oral mycobiome was surveyed using massively parallel, high throughput sequencing of internal transcribed spacer 1 (ITS1) amplicons from saliva following robust extraction methods.\n Taxonomy was assigned by comparison to a curated reference dataset, followed by filtering with an empirically determined BLAST E-value match statistic (10?42).\n Nomenclature corrections further refined results by conjoining redundant names for a single fungal genus.\n Following these curation steps, about two-thirds of the initially identified genera were eliminated.\n In comparison with the one similar metagenomic study and several earlier culture-based ones, our findings change the current conception of the oral mycobiome, especially with the discovery of the high prevalence and abundance of the genus Malassezia.\n Previously identified as an important pathogen of the skin, and recently reported as the predominant fungal genus at the nostril and backs of the head and ear, this is the first account of Malassezia in the human mouth.\n Findings from this study were in good agreement with others on the existence of many consensus members of the core mycobiome, and on unique patterns for individual subjects.\n This research offered a cautionary note about unconditional acceptance of lengthy lists of community members produced by automated assignments, provided a roadmap for enhancing the likely biological relevance of sequence-based fungal surveys, and built the foundation for understanding the role of fungi in health and disease of the oral cavity.\n","id":"PMC3948697","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Amanda K.","surname":"Dupuy","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Marika Network Analysis Applied to Complex Biofilm Communities","abstract":"The complexity of the human microbiome makes it difficult to reveal organizational principles of the community and even more challenging to generate testable hypotheses.\n It has been suggested that in the gut microbiome species such as Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron are keystone in maintaining the stability and functional adaptability of the microbial community.\n In this study, we investigate the interspecies associations in a complex microbial biofilm applying systems biology principles.\n Using correlation network analysis we identified bacterial modules that represent important microbial associations within the oral community.\n We used dental plaque as a model community because of its high diversity and the well known species-species interactions that are common in the oral biofilm.\n We analyzed samples from healthy individuals as well as from patients with periodontitis, a polymicrobial disease.\n Using results obtained by checkerboard hybridization on cultivable bacteria we identified modules that correlated well with microbial complexes previously described.\n Furthermore, we extended our analysis using the Human Oral Microbe Identification Microarray (HOMIM), which includes a large number of bacterial species, among them uncultivated organisms present in the mouth.\n Two distinct microbial communities appeared in healthy individuals while there was one major type in disease.\n Bacterial modules in all communities did not overlap, indicating that bacteria were able to effectively re-associate with new partners depending on the environmental conditions.\n We then identified hubs that could act as keystone species in the bacterial modules.\n Based on those results we then cultured a not-yet-cultivated microorganism, Tannerella sp.\n OT286 (clone BU063).\n After two rounds of enrichment by a selected helper (Prevotella oris OT311) we obtained colonies of Tannerella sp.\n OT286 growing on blood agar plates.\n This system-level approach would open the possibility of manipulating microbial communities in a targeted fashion as well as associating certain bacterial modules to clinical traits (e.\ng.\n: obesity, Crohn's disease, periodontal disease, etc).\n","id":"PMC3233593","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Ana COPD","abstract":"Although culture-independent techniques have shown that the lungs are not sterile, little is known about the lung microbiome in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).\n We used pyrosequencing of 16S amplicons to analyze the lung microbiome in two ways: first, using bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) to sample the distal bronchi and air-spaces; and second, by examining multiple discrete tissue sites in the lungs of six subjects removed at the time of transplantation.\n We performed BAL on three never-smokers (NS) with normal spirometry, seven smokers with normal spirometry (“heathy smokers”, HS), and four subjects with COPD (CS).\n Bacterial 16 s sequences were found in all subjects, without significant quantitative differences between groups.\n Both taxonomy-based and taxonomy-independent approaches disclosed heterogeneity in the bacterial communities between HS subjects that was similar to that seen in healthy NS and two mild COPD patients.\n The moderate and severe COPD patients had very limited community diversity, which was also noted in 28% of the healthy subjects.\n Both approaches revealed extensive membership overlap between the bacterial communities of the three study groups.\n No genera were common within a group but unique across groups.\n Our data suggests the existence of a core pulmonary bacterial microbiome that includes Pseudomonas, Streptococcus, Prevotella, Fusobacterium, Haemophilus, Veillonella, and Porphyromonas.\n Most strikingly, there were significant micro-anatomic differences in bacterial communities within the same lung of subjects with advanced COPD.\n These studies are further demonstration of the pulmonary microbiome and highlight global and micro-anatomic changes in these Co-occurrence Relationships in the Human Microbiome","abstract":"The healthy microbiota show remarkable variability within and among individuals.\n In addition to external exposures, ecological relationships (both oppositional and symbiotic) between microbial inhabitants are important contributors to this variation.\n It is thus of interest to assess what relationships might exist among microbes and determine their underlying reasons.\n The initial Human Microbiome Project (HMP) cohort, comprising 239 individuals and 18 different microbial habitats, provides an unprecedented resource to detect, catalog, and analyze such relationships.\n Here, we applied an ensemble method based on multiple similarity measures in combination with generalized boosted linear models (GBLMs) to taxonomic marker (16S rRNA gene) profiles of this cohort, resulting in a global network of 3,005 significant co-occurrence and co-exclusion relationships between 197 clades occurring throughout the human microbiome.\n This network revealed strong niche specialization, with most microbial associations occurring within body sites and a number of accompanying inter-body site relationships.\n Microbial communities within the oropharynx grouped into three distinct habitats, which themselves showed no direct influence on the composition of the gut microbiota.\n Conversely, niches such as the vagina demonstrated little to no decomposition into region-specific interactions.\n Diverse mechanisms underlay individual interactions, with some such as the co-exclusion of Porphyromonaceae family members and Streptococcus in the subgingival plaque supported by known biochemical dependencies.\n These differences varied among broad phylogenetic groups as well, with the Bacilli and Fusobacteria, for example, both enriched for exclusion of taxa from other clades.\n Comparing phylogenetic versus functional similarities among bacteria, we show that dominant commensal taxa (such as Prevotellaceae and Bacteroides in the gut) often compete, while potential pathogens (e.\ng.\n Treponema and Prevotella in the dental plaque) are more likely to co-occur in complementary niches.\n This approach thus serves to open new opportunities for future targeted mechanistic studies of the microbial ecology of the human microbiome.\n","id":"PMC3395616","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Karoline","surname":"Faust","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"J. methods have incompletely defined the etiology of common recalcitrant human fungal skin diseases including athlete’s foot and toenail infections.\n Skin protects humans from invasion by pathogenic microorganisms, while providing a home for diverse commensal microbiota1.\n Bacterial genomic sequence data have generated novel hypotheses about species and community structures underlying human disorders2,3,4.\n However, microbial diversity is not limited to bacteria; microorganisms such as fungi also play major roles in microbial community stability, human health and disease5.\n Genomic methodologies to identify fungal species and communities have been limited compared with tools available for bacteria6.\n Fungal evolution can be reconstructed with phylogenetic markers, including ribosomal RNA gene regions and other highly conserved genes7.\n Here, we sequenced and analyzed fungal communities of 14 skin sites in 10 healthy adults.\n Eleven core body and arm sites were communities.\n These results provide a framework for future investigation of interactions between pathogenic and commensal fungal and bacterial communities in maintaining human health and contributing diseases","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0045001","date":"2012-08-11","title":"The Adult Cystic Fibrosis Airway Microbiota Is Stable over Time and Infection Type, and Highly Resilient to Antibiotic Treatment of Exacerbations","abstract":"Cystic fibrosis (CF) is characterized by defective mucociliary clearance and chronic airway infection by a complex microbiota.\n Infection, persistent inflammation and periodic episodes of acute pulmonary exacerbation contribute to an irreversible decline in CF lung function.\n While the factors leading to acute exacerbations are poorly understood, antibiotic treatment can temporarily resolve pulmonary symptoms and partially restore lung function.\n Previous studies indicated that exacerbations may be associated with changes in microbial densities and the acquisition of new microbial species.\n Given the complexity of the CF microbiota, we applied massively parallel pyrosequencing to identify changes in airway microbial community structure in 23 adult CF patients during acute pulmonary exacerbation, after antibiotic treatment and during periods of stable disease.\n Over 350,000 sequences were generated, representing nearly 170 distinct microbial taxa.\n Approximately 60% of sequences obtained were from the recognized CF pathogens Pseudomonas and Burkholderia, which were detected in largely non-overlapping patient subsets.\n In contrast, other taxa including Prevotella, Streptococcus, Rothia and Veillonella were abundant in nearly all patient samples.\n Although antibiotic treatment was associated with a small decrease in species richness, there was minimal change in overall microbial community structure.\n Furthermore, microbial community composition was highly similar in patients during an exacerbation and when clinically stable, suggesting that exacerbations may represent intrapulmonary spread of infection rather than a change in microbial community composition.\n Mouthwash samples, obtained from a subset of patients, showed a nearly identical distribution of taxa as expectorated sputum, indicating that aspiration may contribute to colonization of the lower airways.\n Finally, we observed a strong correlation between low species richness and poor lung function.\n Taken together, these results indicate that the adult CF lung microbiome is largely stable through periods of exacerbation and antibiotic treatment and that short-term compositional changes in the airway microbiota do not account for CF pulmonary exacerbations.\n","id":"PMC3458854","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Anthony Healthy Individuals","abstract":"The oral microbiome–organisms residing in the oral cavity and their collective genome–are critical components of health and disease.\n The fungal component of the oral microbiota has not been characterized.\n In this study, we used a novel multitag pyrosequencing approach to characterize fungi present in the oral cavity of 20 healthy individuals, using the pan-fungal internal transcribed spacer (ITS) primers.\n Our results revealed the “basal” oral mycobiome profile of the enrolled individuals, and showed that across all the samples studied, the oral cavity contained 74 culturable and 11 non-culturable fungal genera.\n Among these genera, 39 were present in only one person, 16 genera were present in two participants, and 5 genera were present in three people, while 15 genera (including non-culturable organisms) were present in ?4 (20%) participants.\n Candida species were the most frequent (isolated from 75% of participants), followed by Cladosporium (65%), Aureobasidium, Saccharomycetales (50% for both), Aspergillus (35%), Fusarium (30%), and Cryptococcus (20%).\n Four of these predominant genera are known to be pathogenic in humans.\n The low-abundance genera may represent environmental fungi present in the oral cavity and could simply be spores inhaled from the air or material ingested with food.\n Among the culturable genera, 61 were represented by one species each, while 13 genera comprised between 2 and 6 different species; the total number of species identified were 101. The number of species in the oral cavity of each individual ranged between 9 and 23. Principal component (PCO) analysis of the obtained data set followed by sample clustering and UniFrac analysis revealed that White males and Asian males clustered differently from each other, whereas both Asian and White females clustered together.\n This is the first study that identified the “basal mycobiome” of healthy individuals, and provides the basis for a detailed characterization of the in adult patients<","abstract":"Background\nFew studies have suggested the potential role of respiratory viruses in cystic fibrosis (CF) exacerbation, but their real impact is probably underestimated.\n\n\nMethod\nSixty-four sputum samples collected from 46 adult patients were included in the study: 33 samples were collected during exacerbation of CF, and 31 during the stable Treatment of Specimens before DNA Extraction Directly Influences Molecular Detection of Infectious Agents","abstract":"Introduction\nBiological samples, pharmaceuticals or food contain proteins, lipids, polymers, ammoniums and macromolecules that alter the detection of infectious agents by DNA amplification techniques (PCR).\n\n Moreover the targeted DNA has to be released from the complex cell walls and the compact nucleoprotein matrixes and cleared from potential inhibitors.\n\n The goal of the present work was to assess the efficiency of enzymatic pretreatments on infectious agents to make DNA available for further extraction and amplification.\n\n\nMethods\n\nStaphylococcus epidermidis, Streptococcus mitis, Propionibacterium acnes, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Candida albicans, Aspergillus niger and Fusarium solani were mixed with an internal control virus and treated with: 1) proteinase K; 2) lyticase and 3) lyticase followed by proteinase K.\n\n DNAs was manually extracted using the QIAmp DNA Mini kit or the MagNA Pure Compact automate.\n\n DNA extraction yields and the inhibitors were assessed with a phocid Herpesvirus.\n\n Bacterial detection was performed using TaqMan real-time PCR and yeasts and filamentous Fungi with HRM (real-time PCR followed by high-resolution melting analysis).\n\n\nResults\nViral DNA was released, extracted and detected using manual and automatic methods without pre enzymatic treatments.\n\n Either the manual or the automatic DNA extraction systems did not meet the sensitivity expectations if enzymatic treatments were not performed before: lyticase for Fungi and Proteinase K for Bacteria.\n\n The addition of lyticase and proteinase K did not improve results.\n\n For Fungi the detection after lyticase was higher than for Proteinase K, for which melting analysis did not allow fungal specification.\n\n\nDiscussion\nColumns and magnetic beads allowed collecting DNA and separate PCR inhibitors.\n\n Detection rates cannot be related to DNA-avidity of beads or to elution but to the lack of proteolysis.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4061000","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Pablo","surname":"Goldschmidt","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sandrine","surname":"Degorge","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lilia","surname":"Merabet","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Christine","surname":"Chaumeil","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Deborah","surname":"Dean","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Deborah","surname":"Dean","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1099/jmm.0.46510-0","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Comparison Microbiome","abstract":"id='P1'>Studies of the human microbiome have revealed that even healthy individuals differ remarkably in the microbes that occupy habitats such as the gut, skin, and vagina.\n Much of this diversity remains unexplained, although diet, environment, host genetics, and early microbial exposure have all been implicated.\n Accordingly, to characterize the ecology of human-associated microbial communities, the Human Microbiome Project has analyzed the largest cohort and set of distinct, clinically relevant body habitats to date.\n We found the diversity and abundance of each habitat’s signature microbes to vary widely even among healthy subjects, with strong niche specialization both within and among individuals.\n The project encountered an estimated 81–99% of the genera, enzyme families, and community configurations occupied by the healthy Western microbiome.\n Metagenomic carriage of metabolic pathways was stable among individuals despite variation in community structure, and ethnic/racial background proved to be one of the strongest associations of both pathways and microbes with clinical metadata.\n These results thus delineate the range of structural and functional configurations normal in the microbial communities of a healthy population, enabling future characterization of the epidemiology, ecology, and translational found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0090702","date":"2014-01-23","title":"Gut Microbiota Signatures Predict Host and Microbiota Responses to Dietary Interventions in Obese Individuals","abstract":"Background\nInteractions between the diet and intestinal microbiota play a role in health and disease, including obesity and related metabolic complications.\n\n There is great interest to use dietary means to manipulate the microbiota to promote health.\n\n Currently, the impact of dietary change on the microbiota and the host metabolism is poorly predictable and highly individual.\n\n We propose that the responsiveness of the gut microbiota may depend on its composition, and associate with metabolic changes in the host.\n\n\nMethodology\nOur study involved three independent cohorts of obese adults (n?=?78) from Belgium, Finland, and Britain, participating in different dietary interventions aiming to improve metabolic health.\n\n We used a phylogenetic microarray for comprehensive fecal microbiota analysis at baseline and after the intervention.\n\n Blood cholesterol, insulin and inflammation markers were analyzed as indicators of host response.\n\n The data were divided into four training set – test set pairs; each intervention acted both as a part of a training set and as an independent test set.\n\n We used linear models to predict the responsiveness of the microbiota and the host, and logistic regression to predict responder vs.\n\n non-responder status, or increase vs.\n\n decrease of the health parameters.\n\n\nPrincipal Findings\nOur models, based on the abundance of several, mainly Firmicute species at baseline, predicted the responsiveness of the microbiota (AUC ?=? 0.77–1; predicted vs.\n\n observed correlation ?=? 0.67–0.88).\n\n Many of the predictive taxa showed a non-linear relationship with the responsiveness.\n\n The microbiota response associated with the change in serum cholesterol levels with an AUC of 0.96, highlighting the involvement of the intestinal microbiota in metabolic health.\n\n\nConclusion\nThis proof-of-principle study introduces the first potential microbial biomarkers for dietary responsiveness in obese individuals with impaired metabolic health, and reveals the potential of microbiota signatures for personalized nutrition.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3946202","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Katri","surname":"Korpela","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Harry in Infancy: Interaction between Intestinal and Respiratory Tracts and Impact of Nutritional Exposures","abstract":"Pulmonary damage caused by chronic colonization of the cystic fibrosis (CF) lung by microbial communities is the proximal cause of respiratory failure.\n While there has been an effort to document the microbiome of the CF lung in pediatric and adult patients, little is known regarding the developing microflora in infants.\n We examined the respiratory and intestinal microbiota development in infants with CF from birth to 21 months.\n Distinct genera dominated in the gut compared to those in the respiratory tract, yet some bacteria overlapped, demonstrating a core microbiota dominated by Veillonella and Streptococcus.\n Bacterial diversity increased significantly over time, with evidence of more rapidly acquired diversity in the respiratory tract.\n There was a high degree of concordance between the bacteria that were increasing or decreasing over time in both compartments; in particular, a significant proportion (14/16 genera) increasing in the gut were also increasing in the respiratory tract.\n For 7 genera, gut colonization presages their appearance in the respiratory tract.\n Clustering analysis of respiratory samples indicated profiles of bacteria associated with breast-feeding, and for gut samples, introduction of solid foods even after adjustment for the time at which the sample was collected.\n Furthermore, changes in diet also result in altered respiratory microflora, suggesting a link between nutrition and development of microbial communities in the respiratory tract.\n Our findings suggest that nutritional factors and gut colonization patterns are determinants of the microbial development of respiratory tract microbiota in infants with CF and present opportunities for early intervention in CF with altered dietary or probiotic strategies.\n","id":"PMC3428694","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"J. individuals ranged between 8–14 and 1–9, among uninfected and HIV-infected participants, respectively.\n The core oral bacteriome (COB) comprised 14 genera, of which 13 were common between the two albicans was the most common (58% in uninfected and 83% in HIV-infected participants).\n Furthermore, 15 and 12 bacteria-fungi pairs were correlated significantly within uninfected and HIV-infected Assessing Soil Microbial Abundance and Community Structure","abstract":"Soil DNA extraction has become a critical step in describing microbial biodiversity.\n Historically, ascertaining overarching microbial ecological theories has been hindered as independent studies have used numerous custom and commercial DNA extraction procedures.\n For that reason, a standardized soil DNA extraction method (ISO-11063) was previously published.\n However, although this ISO method is suited for molecular tools such as quantitative PCR and community fingerprinting techniques, it has only been optimized for examining soil bacteria.\n Therefore, the aim of this study was to assess an appropriate soil DNA extraction procedure for examining bacterial, archaeal and fungal diversity in soils of contrasting land-use and physico-chemical properties.\n Three different procedures were tested: the ISO-11063 standard; a custom procedure (GnS-GII); and a modified ISO procedure (ISOm) which includes a different mechanical lysis step (a FastPrep ®-24 lysis step instead of the recommended bead-beating).\n The efficacy of each method was first assessed by estimating microbial biomass through total DNA quantification.\n Then, the abundances and community structure of bacteria, archaea and fungi were determined using real-time PCR and terminal restriction fragment length polymorphism approaches.\n Results showed that DNA yield was improved with the GnS-GII and ISOm procedures, and fungal community patterns were found to be strongly dependent on the extraction method.\n The main methodological factor responsible for differences between extraction procedure efficiencies was found to be the soil homogenization step.\n For integrative studies which aim to examine bacteria, archaea and fungi simultaneously, the ISOm procedure results in higher DNA recovery and better represents microbial communities.\n","id":"PMC3439486","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Pierre","surname":"Plassart","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Sébastien","surname":"Terrat","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Bruce","surname":"Thomson","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Robert","surname":"Griffiths","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Samuel","surname":"Dequiedt","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Mélanie","surname":"Lelievre","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Tiffanie","surname":"Regnier","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Virginie","surname":"Nowak","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Mark","surname":"Bailey","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Philippe","surname":"Lemanceau","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Antonio","surname":"Bispo","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Abad","surname":"Chabbi","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Pierre-Alain","surname":"Maron","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Christophe","surname":"Mougel","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lionel","surname":"Ranjard","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Vishal","surname":"Shah","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Vishal","surname":"Shah","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.ppat.1003371","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Asthma airway bacterial communities in adult bronchiectasis patients","abstract":"Background\nChronic airway infection contributes to the underlying pathogenesis of non-cystic fibrosis bronchiectasis (NCFBr).\n\n In contrast to other chronic airway infections, associated with COPD and CF bronchiectasis, where polymicrobial communities have been implicated in lung damage due to the vicious circle of recurrent bacterial infections and inflammation, there is sparse information on the composition of bacterial communities in NCFBr.\n\n Seventy consecutive patients were recruited from an outpatient adult NCFBr clinic.\n\n Bacterial communities in sputum samples were analysed by culture and pyrosequencing approaches.\n\n Bacterial sequences were analysed using partial least square discrimination analyses to investigate trends in community composition and identify those taxa that contribute most to community variation.\n\n\nResults\nThe lower airway in NCFBr is dominated by three bacterial taxa Pasteurellaceae, Streptococcaceae and Pseudomonadaceae.\n\n Moreover, the bacterial community is much more diverse than indicated by culture and contains significant numbers of other genera including anaerobic Prevotellaceae, Veillonellaceae and Actinomycetaceae.\n\n We found particular taxa are correlated with different clinical states, 27 taxa were associated with acute exacerbations, whereas 11 taxa correlated with stable clinical states.\n\n We were unable to demonstrate a significant effect of antibiotic therapy, gender, or lung function on the diversity of the bacterial community.\n\n However, presence of clinically significant culturable taxa; particularly Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Haemophilus influenzae correlated with a significant change in the diversity of the bacterial community in the lung.\n\n\nConclusions\nWe have demonstrated that acute exacerbations, the frequency of exacerbation and episodes of clinical stability are correlated, in some patients, with a significantly different bacterial community structure, that are associated with a presence of particular taxa in the NCFBr lung.\n\n Moreover, there appears to be an inverse relationship between the abundance of P.\n\n aeruginosa and that of of H.\n\n influenzae within the NCFBr lung bacterial community.\n\n This interaction requires further exploration.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4031157","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Paul","surname":"Purcell","email":"p.purcell@hotmail.co.uk","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Hannah","surname":"Jary","email":"hannah.jary@liv.ac.uk","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Audrey","surname":"Perry","email":"Audrey.Perry@nuth.nhs.uk","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"John samples from individuals with cystic fibrosis","abstract":"Background\nHuman-associated microbial communities include fungi, but we understand little about which fungal species are present, their relative and absolute abundances, and how antimicrobial therapy impacts fungal communities.\n\n The disease cystic fibrosis (CF) often involves chronic airway colonization by bacteria and fungi, and these infections cause irreversible lung damage.\n\n Fungi are detected more frequently in CF sputum samples upon initiation of antimicrobial therapy, and several studies have implicated the detection of fungi in sputum with worse outcomes.\n\n Thus, a more complete understanding of fungi in CF is required.\n\n\nResults\nWe characterized the fungi and bacteria in expectorated sputa from six CF subjects.\n\n Samples were collected upon admission for systemic antibacterial therapy and upon the completion of treatment and analyzed using a pyrosequencing-based analysis of fungal internal transcribed spacer 1 (ITS1) and bacterial 16S rDNA sequences.\n\n A mixture of Candida species and Malassezia dominated the mycobiome in all samples (74%–99% of fungal reads).\n\n There was not a striking trend correlating fungal and bacterial richness, and richness showed a decline after antibiotic therapy particularly for the bacteria.\n\n The fungal communities within a sputum sample resembled other samples from that subject despite the aggressive antibacterial therapy.\n\n Quantitative PCR analysis of fungal 18S rDNA sequences to assess fungal burden showed variation in fungal density in sputum before and after antibacterial therapy but no consistent directional trend.\n\n Analysis of Candida ITS1 sequences amplified from sputum or pure culture-derived genomic DNA from individual Candida species found little (&lt;0.5%) or no variation in ITS1 sequences within or between strains, thereby validating this locus for the purpose of Candida species identification.\n\n We also report the enhancement of the publically available Visualization and Analysis of Microbial Population Structures (VAMPS) tool for the analysis of fungal communities in clinical samples.\n\n\nConclusions\nFungi are present in CF respiratory sputum.\n\n In CF, the use of intravenous antibiotic therapy often does not profoundly impact bacterial community structure, and we observed a similar stability in fungal species composition.\n\n Further studies are required to predict the effects of antibacterials on fungal burden in CF and fungal community stability in non-CF populations.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4236224","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Sven patients and non-atopic controls: a community based case control study","abstract":"Background\nThere is emerging evidence for the presence of an extensive microbiota in human lungs.\n\n It is not known whether variations in the prevalence of species of microbiota in the lungs may have aetiological significance in respiratory conditions such as asthma.\n\n The aim of the study was to undertake semi-quantitative analysis of the differences in fungal species in pooled sputum samples from asthma patients and controls.\n\n\nMethods\nInduced sputum samples were collected in a case control study of asthma patients and control subjects drawn from the community in Wandsworth, London.\n\n Samples from both groups were pooled and then tested for eukaryotes.\n\n DNA was amplified using standard PCR techniques, followed by pyrosequencing and comparison of reads to databases of known sequences to determine in a semi-quantitative way the percentage of DNA from known species in each of the two pooled samples.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 136 fungal species were identified in the induced sputum samples, with 90 species more common in asthma patients and 46 species more common in control subjects.\n\n Psathyrella candolleana, Malassezia pachydermatis, Termitomyces clypeatus and Grifola sordulenta showed a higher percentage of reads in the sputum of asthma patients and Eremothecium sinecaudum, Systenostrema alba, Cladosporium cladosporioides and Vanderwaltozyma polyspora showed a higher percentage of reads in the sputum of control subjects.\n\n A statistically significant difference in the pattern of fungi that were present in the respective samples was demonstrated using the Phylogenetic (P) test (P?&lt;?0.0001).\n\n\nConclusion\nThis study is novel in providing evidence for the widespread nature of fungi in the sputum of healthy and asthmatic individuals.\n\n Differences in the pattern of fungi present in asthma patients and controls merit further investigation.\n\n Of particular interest was the presence of Malassezia pachydermatis, which is known to be associated with atopic B.","surname":"Chang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1111/cmi.12216","date":"2013-09-10","title":"Streptococcal co-infection augments <italic>Candida</italic> pathogenicity by amplifying the mucosal inflammatory response","abstract":"Mitis-group streptococci are ubiquitous oral commensals that can promote polybacterial biofilm virulence.\n Using a novel murine oral mucosal co-infection model we sought to determine for the first time whether these organisms promote the virulence of C.\n?albicans mucosal biofilms in oropharyngeal infection and explored mechanisms of pathogenic synergy.\n We found that Streptococcus oralis colonization of the oral and gastrointestinal tract was augmented in the presence of C.\n?albicans.\n S.\n?oralis and C.\n?albicans co-infection significantly augmented the frequency and size of oral thrush lesions.\n Importantly, S.\n?oralis promoted deep organ dissemination of C.\n?albicans.\n Whole mouse genome tongue microarray analysis showed that when compared with animals infected with one organism, the doubly infected animals had genes in the major categories of neutrophilic response/chemotaxis/inflammation significantly upregulated, indicative of an exaggerated inflammatory response.\n This response was dependent on TLR2 signalling since oral lesions, transcription of pro-inflammatory genes and neutrophil infiltration, were attenuated in TLR2?/? animals.\n Furthermore, S.\n?oralis activated neutrophils in a TLR2-dependent manner in vitro.\n In summary, this study identifies a previously unrecognized pathogenic synergy between oral commensal bacteriaand C.\n?albicans.\n This is the first report of the ability of mucosal commensal bacteria to modify the virulence of an opportunistic fungal pathogen.\n","id":"PMC3956708","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"H","surname":"Xu","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"T","surname":"Sobue","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"A","surname":"Thompson","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Z","surname":"Xie","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"K","surname":"Poon","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"A","surname":"Ricker","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"J","surname":"Cervantes","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"P lung","abstract":"Opportunistic infections are a major cause of morbidity and mortality in severely immunocompromised patients, such as those receiving chemotherapy or with haematological malignancy, aplastic anaemia or HIV infection, or recipients of solid-organ or stem cell transplants.\n In addition, the increasing use of biological therapies will result in more patients at risk of opportunistic infections, albeit to a lesser degree than classic causes of immunocompromise.\n The type and degree of immune defect dictates the profile of potential opportunistic pathogens; T-cell mediated defects increase the risk of viral (cytomegalovirus and respiratory viruses) and Pneumocystis jirovecii infections, whereas neutrophil defects are associated with bacterial pneumonia and invasive aspergillosis.\n However, patients often have combinations of immune defects and a wide range of other opportunistic infections can cause pneumonia.\n The radiological pattern of disease (best assessed by CT scan) and speed of onset also help identify the likely pathogen(s), which can then be supported by targeted investigation including early use of bronchoscopy in selected patients.\n Rapid and expert clinical assessment can identify the most likely pathogens, which can then be treated aggressively and so provide the best opportunity for a positive outcome.\n","id":"PMC7108292","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Ricardo J.","surname":"José","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jeremy of <italic>Aspergillus fumigatus</italic>\n","abstract":"Alveolar macrophages represent a first-line innate host defense mechanism for clearing inhaled Aspergillus fumigatus from the lungs, yet contradictory data exist as to which alveolar macrophage recognition receptor is critical for innate immunity to A.\n fumigatus.\n Acknowledging that the A.\n fumigatus cell wall contains a high beta-1,3–glucan content, we questioned whether the beta-glucan receptor dectin-1 played a role in this recognition process.\n Monoclonal antibody, soluble receptor, and competitive carbohydrate blockage indicated that the alveolar macrophage inflammatory response, specifically the production of tumor necrosis factor-? (TNF-?), interleukin-1? (IL-1?), IL-1?, IL-6, CXCL2/macrophage inflammatory protein-2 (MIP-2), CCL3/macrophage inflammatory protein-1? (MIP-1?), granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF), and granulocyte monocyte–CSF (GM-CSF), to live A.\n fumigatus was dependent on recognition via the beta-glucan receptor dectin-1. The inflammatory response was triggered at the highest level by A.\n fumigatus swollen conidia and early germlings and correlated to the levels of surface-exposed beta glucans, indicating that dectin-1 preferentially recognizes specific morphological forms of A.\n fumigatus.\n Intratracheal administration of A.\n fumigatus conidia to mice in the presence of a soluble dectin-Fc fusion protein reduced both lung proinflammatory cytokine/chemokine levels and cellular recruitment while modestly increasing the A.\n fumigatus fungal burden, illustrating the importance of beta-glucan–initiated dectin-1 signaling in defense against this pathogen.\n Collectively, these data show that dectin-1 is centrally required for the generation of alveolar macrophage proinflammatory responses to A.\n fumigatus and to our knowledge provides the first in vivo evidence for the role of dectin-1 in fungal innate defense.\n","id":"PMC1311140","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Chad","surname":"Steele","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Rekha fumigatus</italic> and human immune cells; what have we learned about pathogenicity and host immunity?","abstract":"Invasive aspergillosis is a significant threat to health and is a major cause of mortality in immunocompromised individuals.\n Understanding the interaction between the fungus and the immune system is important in determining how the immunocompetent host remains disease free.\n Several studies examining the direct interaction between Aspergillus fumigatus and purified innate immune cells have been conducted to measure the responses of both the host cells and the pathogen.\n It has been revealed that innate immune cells have different modes of action ranging from effective fungal killing by neutrophils to the less aggressive response of dendritic cells.\n Natural killer cells do not phagocytose the fungus unlike the other innate immune cells mentioned but appear to mediate their antifungal effect through the release of gamma interferon.\n Transcriptional analysis of A.\n fumigatus interacting with these cells has indicated that it can adapt to the harsh microenvironment of the phagosome and produces toxins, ribotoxin and gliotoxin, that can induce cell death in the majority of innate immune cells.\n These data point toward potential novel antifungal treatments including the use of innate immune cells as antifungal vaccines.\n","id":"PMC3525292","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Charles Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0006854","date":"2009-08-03","title":"Insights into the Mechanisms of Protective Immunity against <italic>Cryptococcus neoformans</italic> Infection Using a Mouse Model of Pulmonary Cryptococcosis","abstract":"\nCryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that causes life-threatening pneumonia and meningoencephalitis in immune compromised individuals.\n Previous studies have shown that immunization of BALB/c mice with an IFN-?-producing C.\n neoformans strain, H99?, results in complete protection against a second pulmonary challenge with an otherwise lethal cryptococcal strain.\n The current study evaluated local anamnestic cell-mediated immune responses against pulmonary cryptococcosis in mice immunized with C.\n neoformans strain H99? compared to mice immunized with heat-killed C.\n neoformans (HKC.\nn.\n).\n Mice immunized with C.\n neoformans strain H99? had significantly reduced pulmonary fungal burden post-secondary challenge compared to mice immunized with HKC.\nn.\n Protection against pulmonary cryptococcosis was associated with increased pulmonary granulomatous formation and leukocyte infiltration followed by a rapid resolution of pulmonary inflammation, which protected the lungs from severe allergic bronchopulmonary mycosis (ABPM)-pathology that developed in the lungs of mice immunized with HKC.\nn.\n Pulmonary challenge of interleukin (IL)-4 receptor, IL-12p40, IL-12p35, IFN-?, T cell and B cell deficient mice with C.\n neoformans strain H99? demonstrated a requirement for Th1-type T cell-mediated immunity, but not B cell-mediated immunity, for the induction of H99?-mediated protective immune responses against pulmonary C.\n neoformans infection.\n CD4+ T cells, CD11c+ cells, and Gr-1+ cells were increased in both proportion and absolute number in protected mice.\n In addition, significantly increased production of Th1-type/pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines, and conversely, reduced Th2-type cytokine production was observed in the lungs of protected mice.\n Interestingly, protection was not associated with increased production of cytokines IFN-? or TNF-? in lungs of protected mice.\n In conclusion, immunization with C.\n neoformans strain H99? results in the development of protective anti-cryptococcal immune responses that may be measured and subsequently used in the development of immune-based therapies to combat pulmonary cryptococcosis.\n","id":"PMC2731172","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Karen infection","abstract":"One component of host defense at mucosal surfaces seems to be epithelium-derived antimicrobial peptides.\n Antimicrobial peptides are classified on the basis of their structure and amino acid motifs.\n Peptides of the defensin, cathelicidin, and histatin classes are found in humans.\n In the airways, ?-defensins and the cathelicidin LL-37/hCAP-18 originate from neutrophils.\n ?-Defensins and LL-37/hCAP-18 are produced by the respiratory epithelium and the alveolar macrophage and secreted into the airway surface fluid.\n Beside their direct antimicrobial function, antimicrobial peptides have multiple roles as mediators of inflammation with effects on epithelial and inflammatory cells, influencing such diverse processes as proliferation, immune induction, wound healing, cytokine release, chemotaxis, protease-antiprotease balance, and redox homeostasis.\n Further, antimicrobial peptides qualify as prototypes of innovative drugs that might be used as antibiotics, anti-lipopolysaccharide drugs, or modifiers of
