found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.2147/IDR.S370964","date":"2022-10-11","title":"The Comparison of Metagenomic Next-Generation Sequencing with Conventional Microbiological Tests for Identification of Pathogens and Antibiotic Resistance Genes in Infectious Diseases","abstract":"Background\nMetagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) has been widely studied, due to its ability of detecting all the microbial genetic information unbiasedly in a sample at one time and not relying on traditional culture.\n\n However, the application of mNGS in the diagnosis of clinical pathogens remains challenging.\n\n\nMethods\nFrom December 2019 to March 2021, 134 specimens including Broncho alveolar lavage fluid (BAFL), blood, sputum, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), bile, pleural fluid, pus, were continuously collected in The First Hospital of Qinhuangdao, and their retrospective diagnoses were classified into infectious disease (128, 95.5%) and noninfectious disease (6, 4.5%).\n\n The pathogen-detection performance of mNGS was compared with conventional microbiological tests (CMT) and culture method.\n\n In addition, the antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) and evolutionary relationship of common drug-resistant A.\n\n baumannii were also analyzed.\n\n\nResults\nCompared with CMT and culture methods, mNGS showed higher sensitivity in pathogen detection (74.2% vs 57.8%; P &lt; 0.001 and 66.3% vs 31.7%; P &lt; 0.001, respectively).\n\n Importantly, for cases that mNGS-positive only, 18 (35%) cases result in diagnosis modification, and 7 (23%) cases confirmed the clinical diagnosis.\n\n In 17 cases that A.\n\n baumannii were both detected in mNGS and culture, ade genes were the most frequently detected ARGs (from 13 cases), followed by sul2 and APH(3”)-Ib (both from 12 cases).\n\n High consistency was observed among these ARGs and the related phenotype (100% for ade genes, 91.6% for sul2 and APH(3”)-Ib).\n\n A.\n\n baumannii strains were classified into three groups, and most were well-clustered.\n\n It suggested those strains may be the epidemic strains.\n\n\nConclusion\nIn our study, mNGS had a higher sensitivity than CMT and culture method.\n\n And the result of ARGs frequency and cluster analysis of A.\n\n baumannii was of great significance to the anti-infective therapy.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9586124","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Hongzhi","surname":"Lu","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Li","surname":"Ma","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Hong","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Li","surname":"Feng","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Ying","surname":"Yu","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Yihan","surname":"Zhao","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Li","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yujiao","surname":"Zhou","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Li","surname":"Song","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wushuang","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jiangman","surname":"Zhao","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Lanxiang","surname":"Liu","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Lanxiang","surname":"Liu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12890-019-1022-4","date":"2019-12-06","title":"Metagenomic next-generation sequencing for mixed pulmonary infection diagnosis","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is emerging as a promising technique for pathogens detection.\n\n However, reports on the application of mNGS in mixed pulmonary infection remain scarce.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>From July 2018 to March 2019, 55 cases were enrolled in this retrospective analysis.\n\n Cases were classified into mixed pulmonary infection (36 [65.5%]) and non-mixed pulmonary infection (19 [34.5%]) according to primary diagnoses.\n\n The performances of mNGS and conventional test on mixed pulmonary infection diagnosis and pathogen identification were compared.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>The sensitivity of mNGS in mixed pulmonary infection diagnosis was much higher than that of conventional test (97.2% vs 13.9%; P?&lt; 0.01), but the specificity was the opposite (63.2% vs 94.7%; P?= 0.07).\n\n The positive predictive value of mNGS was 83.3% (95% CI, 68.0–92.5%), and the negative predictive value was 92.3% (95% CI, 62.1–99.6%).\n\n A total of 5 (9.1%) cases were identified as mixed pulmonary infection by both conventional tests and mNGS, however, the pathogens identification results were consistent between these two methods in only 1 (1.8%) case.\n\n In summary, the pathogens detected by mNGS in 3 (5.5%) cases were consistent with those by conventional test, and only 1 (1.8%) case was mixed pulmonary infection.\n\n According to our data, mNGS had a broader spectrum for pathogen detection than conventional tests.\n\n In particular, application of mNGS improved the diagnosis of pulmonary fungal infections.\n\n Within the 55 cases, mNGS detected and identified fungi in 31 (56.4%) cases, of which only 10 (18.2%) cases were positive for the same fungi by conventional test.\n\n The most common pathogen detected by mNGS was Human cytomegalovirus in our study, which was identified in 19 (34.5%) cases of mixed pulmonary infection.\n\n Human cytomegalovirus and Pneumocystis jirovecii, which were detected in 7 (12.7%) cases, were the most common co-pathogens in the group of mixed pulmonary infection.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>mNGS is a promising technique to detect co-pathogens in mixed pulmonary infection, with potential benefits in speed and sensitivity.\n\n\nTrial registration\nid='Par5'>(retrospectively registered): ChiCTR1900023727.\n\n Registrated 9 JUNE 2019.\n","id":"PMC6921575","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jiahui","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Yelei","surname":"Han","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jing","surname":"Feng","email":"tjydfj@sina.com","contributions":"2"}]},{"doi":"10.2147/IDR.S235182","date":"2020-01-24","title":"Metagenomic Next-Generation Sequencing versus Traditional Pathogen Detection in the Diagnosis of Peripheral Pulmonary Infectious Lesions","abstract":"Purpose\nThe aim of this study was to evaluate the value of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) in peripheral pulmonary infection management by comparing the diagnostic yield of mNGS and traditional pathogen detection methods on interventional specimens obtained by bronchoscopy.\n\n\nPatients and Methods\nThis study enrolled patients suspected with pulmonary infection who were admitted to Tianjin Medical University General Hospital from June 2018 to August 2019. Specimens were obtained from bronchoscopy for mNGS analysis and traditional pathogen detection (including bronchoalveolar lavage fluid microbial culture, smear microscopy, and lung biopsy histopathology), and the diagnostic yields were compared between mNGS and traditional methods to evaluate the diagnostic value of mNGS in peripheral pulmonary infection diagnosis.\n\n\nResults\nIn this study, by comparing mNGS with traditional pathogen detection, the results indicated that, first, mNGS identified at least one microbial species in almost 89% of the patients with pulmonary infection; second, mNGS detected microbes related to human diseases in 94.49% of samples from pulmonary infection patients who had received negative results from traditional pathogen detection; third, the accuracy and sensitivity of mNGS are higher than those of traditional pathogen detection; and, finally, mNGS could simultaneously detect and identify a large variety of pathogens.\n\n\nConclusion\nMetagenomic NGS analysis provided fast and precise pathogen detection and identification, contributing to prompt and accurate treatment of peripheral pulmonary infection.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7036976","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jie","surname":"Huang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Erlie","surname":"Jiang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Donglin","surname":"Yang","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jialin","surname":"Wei","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Jialin","surname":"Wei","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Mingfeng","surname":"Zhao","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Jing","surname":"Feng","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jie","surname":"Cao","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12879-020-05746-5","date":"2020-12-27","title":"The diagnostic value of metagenomic next?generation sequencing in infectious diseases","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Although traditional diagnostic techniques of infection are mature and price favorable at present, most of them are time-consuming and with a low positivity.\n\n Metagenomic next?generation sequencing (mNGS) was studied widely because of identification and typing of all pathogens not rely on culture and retrieving all DNA without bias.\n\n Based on this background, we aim to detect the difference between mNGS and traditional culture method, and to explore the relationship between mNGS results and the severity, prognosis of infectious patients.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>109 adult patients were enrolled in our study in Shanghai Tenth People’s Hospital from October 2018 to December 2019. The diagnostic results, negative predictive values, positive predictive values, false positive rate, false negative rate, pathogen and sample types were analyzed by using both traditional culture and mNGS methods.\n\n Then, the samples and clinical information of 93 patients in the infected group (ID) were collected.\n\n According to whether mNGS detected pathogens, the patients in ID group were divided into the positive group of 67 cases and the negative group of 26 cases.\n\n Peripheral blood leukocytes, C-reactive protein (CRP), procalcitonin (PCT) and neutrophil counts were measured, and the concentrations of IL-2, IL-4, IL-6, TNF-?, IL-17A, IL-10 and INF-? in the serum were determined by ELISA.\n\n The correlation between the positive detection of pathogens by mNGS and the severity of illness, hospitalization days, and mortality were analyzed.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>109 samples were assigned into infected group (ID, 92/109, 84.4%), non-infected group (NID, 16/109, 14.7%), and unknown group (1/109, 0.9%).\n\n Blood was the most abundant type of samples with 37 cases, followed by bronchoalveolar lavage fluid in 36 cases, tissue, sputum, pleural effusion, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), pus, bone marrow and nasal swab.\n\n In the ID group, the majority of patients were diagnosed with lower respiratory system infections (73/109, 67%), followed by bloodstream infections, pleural effusion and central nervous system infections.\n\n The sensitivity of mNGS was significantly higher than that of culture method (67.4% vs 23.6%; P?&lt;?0.001), especially in sample types of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (P?=?0.002), blood (P?&lt; 0.001) and sputum (P?=?0.037), while the specificity of mNGS was not significantly different from culture method (68.8% vs 81.3%; P?=?0.41).\n\n The number of hospitals stays and 28-day-motality in the positive mNGS group were significantly higher than those in the negative group, and the difference was statistically significant (P?&lt;?0.05).\n\n Age was significant in multivariate logistic analyses of positive results of mNGS.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>The study found that mNGS had a higher sensitivity than the traditional method, especially in blood, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid and sputum samples.\n\n And positive mNGS group had a higher hospital stay, 28-day-mortality, which means the positive of pathogen nucleic acid sequences detection may be a potential high-risk factor for poor prognosis of adult patients and has significant clinical value.\n\n MNGS should be used more in early pathogen diagnosis in the future.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7805029","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Hongxia","surname":"Duan","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Xuan","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Aihong","surname":"Mei","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Ping","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yang","surname":"Liu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xiaofeng","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Weiwei","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Changhui","surname":"Wang","email":"wang-chang-hui@hotmail.com","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Shuanshuan","surname":"Xie","email":"xieshuanshuan@aliyun.com","contributions":"2"},{"firstname":"Shuanshuan","surname":"Xie","email":"xieshuanshuan@aliyun.com","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3389/fmicb.2022.868160","date":"2022-03-21","title":"Metagenomic Next-Generation Sequencing vs. Traditional Pathogen Detection in the Diagnosis of Infection After Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation in Children","abstract":"Infection is a severe complication of allo-HSCT in children, however, the accurate detection of the infection is hard.\n In this study, we traced the records of 101 pediatric recipients with allo-HSCT to investigate the pathogens of infection, and collected 54 bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, 32 blood, and 15 cerebrospinal fluid samples.\n In these samples, 87 was with post-transplant infection and 14 without infection.\n Using the metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) and traditional pathogen detection, we compared their sensitivity and specificity to detect pathogens of infection.\n Our results showed that mNGS was more sensitive (89.7%) than conventional pathogen detection (21.8%), with a difference of 67.9% (P &lt; 0.001), However, mNGS was less specific (78.5%) than traditional methods (92.9%), with a difference of 14.4% (P = 0.596).\n The sensitivity of mNGS for diagnosing pulmonary infections, bloodstream infections or viremia, and CNS infections post-transplant were 91.7, 85.7, and 90.9%, respectively.\n In contrast, the sensitivity of conventional testing for diagnosing pulmonary infections, bloodstream infections or viremia, and CNS infections post-transplant were 22.9, 21.4, and 18.2%, respectively.\n There were significant differences in the sensitivity of mNGS and conventional testing in BALF, blood, and CSF samples, with P values of 0.000, 0.000, and 0.002 respectively.\n Among the patients with pulmonary infection, 11 pathogens were both identified by mNGS and conventional testing, and 33 by mNGS only.\n The percentage with the mNGS-positive result was 44/48 (91.7%), including viruses (n = 12), bacteria (n = 17), fungi (n = 9) and mixed infections (n = 6).\n Among the patients diagnosed with fungal pneumonia (n = 9), the most prevalent pathogenic fungi were Pneumocystis jiroveci (n = 6), which were also detected in 4 patients with mixed infectious pneumonia.\n In the 28 blood specimens of patients with bloodstream infections or viremia, five patients were positive by both mNGS and conventional testing, 19 were positive by mNGS, and 1 was positive by traditional testing only.\n The percentage with the mNGS-positive results was 24/28 (85.7%), including viruses (n = 12), bacteria (n = 4), fungi (n = 3), and mixed infections (n = 5).\n Of the 15 CSF specimens enrolled, 11 patients were eventually diagnosed with CNS infections.\n Ten pathogens were identified by mNGS in the 11 patients, including viruses (n = 8), bacteria (n = 1), and fungi (n = 1).\n These results suggest that mNGS is more sensitive than conventional pathogen detection for diagnosing infections post HSCT in children which may help the clinic diagnosis.\n Pneumocystis jiroveci was the most frequent pathogen of pulmonary infections post-transplant, while viruses were the most common pathogens of CNS infections in allo-HSCT found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1093/ve/vex012","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Global patterns in coronavirus diversity","abstract":"Since the emergence of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and Middle East Respiratory Syndrom Coronavirus (MERS-CoV) it has become increasingly clear that bats are important reservoirs of CoVs.\n Despite this, only 6% of all CoV sequences in GenBank are from bats.\n The remaining 94% largely consist of known pathogens of public health or agricultural significance, indicating that current research effort is heavily biased towards describing known diseases rather than the ‘pre-emergent’ diversity in bats.\n Our study addresses this critical gap, and focuses on resource poor countries where the risk of zoonotic emergence is believed to be highest.\n We surveyed the diversity of CoVs in multiple host taxa from twenty countries to explore the factors driving viral diversity at a global scale.\n We identified sequences representing 100 discrete phylogenetic clusters, ninety-one of which were found in bats, and used ecological and epidemiologic analyses to show that patterns of CoV diversity correlate with those of bat diversity.\n This cements bats as the major evolutionary reservoirs and ecological drivers of CoV diversity.\n Co-phylogenetic reconciliation analysis was also used to show that host switching has contributed to CoV evolution, and a preliminary analysis suggests that regional variation exists in the dynamics of this process.\n Overall our study represents a model for exploring global viral diversity and advances our fundamental understanding of CoV biodiversity and the potential risk factors associated with zoonotic emergence.\n","id":"PMC5467638","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Simon characterization of the 2019 novel human-pathogenic coronavirus isolated from a patient with atypical pneumonia after visiting Wuhan","abstract":"A mysterious outbreak of atypical pneumonia in late 2019 was traced to a seafood wholesale market in Wuhan of China.\n Within a few weeks, a novel coronavirus tentatively named as 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) was announced by the World Health Organization.\n We performed bioinformatics analysis on a virus genome from a patient with 2019-nCoV infection and compared it with other related coronavirus genomes.\n Overall, the genome of 2019-nCoV has 89% nucleotide identity with bat SARS-like-CoVZXC21 and 82% with that of human SARS-CoV.\n The phylogenetic trees of their orf1a/b, Spike, Envelope, Membrane and Nucleoprotein also clustered closely with those of the bat, civet and human SARS coronaviruses.\n However, the external subdomain of Spike’s receptor binding domain of 2019-nCoV shares only 40% amino acid identity with other SARS-related coronaviruses.\n Remarkably, its orf3b encodes a completely novel short protein.\n Furthermore, its new orf8 likely encodes a secreted protein with an alpha-helix, following with a beta-sheet(s) containing six strands.\n Learning from the roles of civet in SARS and camel in MERS, hunting for the animal source of 2019-nCoV and its more ancestral virus would be important for understanding the origin and evolution of this novel lineage B betacoronavirus.\n These findings provide the basis for starting further studies on the pathogenesis, and optimizing the design of diagnostic, antiviral and vaccination strategies for this emerging infection.\n","id":"PMC7067204","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jasper SARS.\n","id":"PMC2750777","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Lanying","surname":"Du","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yuxian","surname":"He","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yusen","surname":"Zhou","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Shuwen","surname":"Liu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Bo-Jian","surname":"Zheng","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Shibo","surname":"Jiang","email":"sjiang@nybloodcenter.org","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1016/S0140-6736(04)15788-7","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Interaction between heptad repeat 1 and 2 regions in spike protein of SARS-associated coronavirus: implications for virus fusogenic mechanism and identification of fusion inhibitors","abstract":"Background\nStudies on the fusion-inhibitory peptides derived from the heptad repeat 1 and 2 (HR1 and HR2) regions of the HIV-1 envelope glycoprotein gp41 provided crucial information on the viral fusogenic mechanism.\n\n We used a similar approach to study the fusogenic mechanism of severe-acute-respiratory-syndrome-associated coronavirus (SARS-CoV).\n\n\nMethods\nWe tested the inhibitory activity against infection of two sets of peptides corresponding to sequences of SARS-CoV spike protein HR1 and HR2 regions and investigated the interactions between the HR1 and HR2 peptides by surface plasmon resonance, sedimentation equilibration analysis, circular dichroism, native polyacrylamide-gel electrophoresis, size exclusion high-performance liquid chromatography, and computer-aided homology modelling and molecule docking analysis.\n\n\nFindings\nOne peptide, CP-1, derived from the HR2 region, inhibited SARS-CoV infection in the micromolar range.\n\n CP-1 bound with high affinity to a peptide from the HR1 region, NP-1. CP-1 alone had low -helicity and self-associated to form a trimer in phosphate buffer (pH 7·2).\n\n CP-1 and NP-1 mixed in equimolar concentrations formed a six-helix bundle, similar to the fusogenic core structure of HIV-1 gp41.\nInterpretation\nAfter binding to the target cell, the transmembrane spike protein might change conformation by association between the HR1 and HR2 regions to form an oligomeric structure, leading to fusion between the viral and target-cell membranes.\n\n At the prefusion intermediate state, CP-1 could bind to the HR1 region and interfere with the conformational changes, resulting in inhibition of SARS-CoV fusion with the target cells.\n\n CP-1 might be modifiable to increase its anti-SARS-CoV activity and could be further developed as an antiviral agent for treatment or prophylaxis of SARS-CoV infection.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7140173","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Shuwen","surname":"Liu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Gengfu","surname":"Xiao","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yibang","surname":"Chen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yuxian","surname":"He","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jinkui","surname":"Niu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Carlos Domain","abstract":"Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is an infectious virus that was first reported in 2012. The MERS-CoV genome encodes four major structural proteins, among which the spike (S) protein has a key role in viral infection and pathogenesis.\n The receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the S protein contains a critical neutralizing domain and is an important target for development of MERS vaccines and therapeutics.\n In this review, we describe the relevant features of the MERS-CoV S-protein RBD, of neutralizing immunogenicity index to the rational design of MERS coronavirus subunit vaccines","abstract":"Viral subunit vaccines often contain immunodominant non-neutralizing epitopes that divert host immune responses.\n These epitopes should be eliminated in vaccine design, but there is no reliable method for evaluating an epitope's capacity to elicit neutralizing immune responses.\n Here we introduce a new concept ‘neutralizing immunogenicity index' (NII) to evaluate an epitope's neutralizing immunogenicity.\n To determine the NII, we mask the epitope with a glycan probe and then assess the epitope's contribution to the vaccine's overall neutralizing immunogenicity.\n As proof-of-concept, we measure the NII for different epitopes on an immunogen comprised of the receptor-binding domain from MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV).\n Further, we design a variant form of this vaccine by masking an epitope that has a negative NII score.\n This engineered vaccine demonstrates significantly enhanced efficacy in protecting transgenic mice from lethal MERS-CoV challenge.\n Our study may guide the rational design of highly effective subunit vaccines to combat MERS-CoV and other life-threatening found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0076225","date":"2013-08-21","title":"Delays in Appropriate Antibiotic Therapy for Gram-Negative Bloodstream Infections: A Multicenter, Community Hospital Study","abstract":"Background\nGram-negative bacterial bloodstream infection (BSI) is a serious condition with estimated 30% mortality.\n\n Clinical outcomes for patients with severe infections improve when antibiotics are appropriately chosen and given early.\n\n The objective of this study was to estimate the association of prior healthcare exposure on time to appropriate antibiotic therapy in patients with gram-negative BSI.\n\n\nMethod\nWe performed a multicenter cohort study of adult, hospitalized patients with gram-negative BSI using time to event analysis in nine community hospitals from 2003-2006. Event time was defined as the first administration of an antibiotic with in\nvitro activity against the infecting organism.\n\n Healthcare exposure status was categorized as community-acquired, healthcare-associated, or hospital-acquired.\n\n Time to appropriate therapy among groups of patients with differing healthcare exposure status was assessed using Kaplan-Meier analyses and multivariate Cox proportional hazards models.\n\n\nResults\nThe cohort included 578 patients with gram-negative BSI, including 320 (55%) healthcare-associated, 217 (38%) community-acquired, and 41 (7%) hospital-acquired infections.\n\n 529 (92%) patients received an appropriate antibiotic during their hospitalization.\n\n Time to appropriate therapy was significantly different among the groups of healthcare exposure status (log-rank p=0.02).\n\n Time to first antibiotic administration regardless of drug appropriateness was not different between groups (p=0.3).\n\n The unadjusted hazard ratios (HR) (95% confidence interval) were 0.80 (0.65-0.98) for healthcare-associated and 0.72 (0.63-0.82) for hospital-acquired, relative to patients with community-acquired BSI.\n\n In multivariable analysis, interaction was found between the main effect and baseline Charlson comorbidity index.\n\n When Charlson index was 3, adjusted HRs were 0.66 (0.48-0.92) for healthcare-associated and 0.57 (0.44-0.75) for hospital-acquired, relative to patients with community-acquired infections.\n\n\nConclusions\nPatients with healthcare-associated or hospital-acquired BSI experienced delays in receipt of appropriate antibiotics for gram-negative BSI compared to patients with community-acquired BSI.\n\n This difference was not due to delayed initiation of antibiotic therapy, but due to the inappropriate choice of antibiotic.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3789716","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Rebekah found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.2147/IDR.S316881","date":"2021-08-19","title":"Disseminated Coinfection by <italic>Mycobacterium fortuitum</italic> and <italic>Talaromyces marneffei</italic> in a Non-HIV Case","abstract":"Background\nMycobacterium fortuitum is a rapidly growing non-tuberculous mycobacterium (NTM) with weak pathogenicity.\n\n Here, we present a rare case of disseminated M.\n\n fortuitum and Talaromyces marneffei coinfection in a human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) negative patient.\n\n\nCase Presentation\nA 28-year-old female was admitted to our hospital due to 2 months of swelling of lymph nodes on the right side of her cervix, accompanied by repeated low fever for more than 1 month.\n\n Biopsy of the right cervical lymph node and endobronchial ultrasound-guided transbronchial fine needle aspiration (EBUS-TBNA) both suggested granulomatous inflammation.\n\n The bacterial culture and mycobacteria examination of the lesion as well as HIV antibody test were all negative.\n\n Disseminated T.\n\n marneffei infection was diagnosed by the quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) results from the blood showing 1798 copies/ul.\n\n In the meantime, treatment with amphotericin B combined with cefoxitin was administered for suspected NTM infection.\n\n However, the once-dropped fever recurred and the lymph nodes continued to swell.\n\n Metagenomics next-generation sequencing (mNGS) detection of the lymph nodes indicated M.\n\n fortuitum.\n\n After combination treatment with amphotericin B, voriconazole, linazolamide, and imipenem, the patient’s body temperature returned to normal, the lymph node swelling was gradually reduced, and the lung lesion was absorbed.\n\n\nConclusion\nWe report the first case of an HIV-negative patient diagnosed with disseminated M.\n\n fortuitum and T.\n\n marneffei coinfection with nonspecific clinical manifestation, in order to heighten awareness of these and clinical characteristics of pertussis in children and their close contacts in households: A cross-sectional survey in Zhejiang Province, China","abstract":"Background\nDespite the expanded immunization programs, the “re-emergence of pertussis” has become a global concern in recent years.\n\n At present, the prevalence of pertussis in China is seriously underestimated, and the role of close contact on the disease spreading in children remains unclear.\n\n\nObjectives\nOur study aimed to investigate pertussis’s epidemiological and clinical characteristics in children and their close contacts in households, as well as the antimicrobial resistance of Bordetella pertussis (B.\n\n pertussis) in Zhejiang Province, China.\n\n\nMethods\nWe have collected the retrospective and prospective data of children who were suspected of pertussis and their close contacts in households from January 1, 2018, to December 31, 2020, in the Children’s Hospital, Zhejiang University School of Medicine, Hangzhou, Zhejiang, China.\n\n Nasopharyngeal swabs were collected and cultured for B.\n\n pertussis.\n\n Antibiotics susceptibility test was determined by using E-test methods.\n\n Clinical information was collected from the medical records systems.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 350 index patients and their 946 family members (close contacts in households) from 350 families were recruited.\n\n B.\n\n pertussis strains were isolated from 130 (37.1%) index patients and 116 (12.3%) close contacts.\n\n 37 index patients had negative culture results for B.\n\n pertussis while their close contacts were positive.\n\n A higher positive rate was found in female adults than that in male adults (16.3% vs.\n\n 5.1%, P &lt; 0.01).\n\n The positive rate in index patients from multi-child families was significantly higher than that from one-child families (51.7% vs.\n\n 37.7%, P &lt; 0.05).\n\n 53.3% of the pertussis patients were under 6 months of age.\n\n 98 (75.4%) isolates had MICs ? 256 mg/L to erythromycin, azithromycin, and clindamycin, and 127 (97.7%) had MICs &lt; 0.016 mg/L to piperacillin.\n\n\nConclusion\nInfants under 6 months of age are at high risk of pertussis, and close contacts in households are prone to cluster infection.\n\n Culture for B.\n\n pertussis both in children and their close contacts contributes to improving the diagnosis rate of pertussis in children.\n\n Isolates of B.\n\n pertussis in China are highly resistant to macrolides.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9434343","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Luo-Na","surname":"Lin","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jin-Si","surname":"Zhou","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Chun-Zhen","surname":"Hua","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Guan-Nan","surname":"Bai","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yu-Mei","surname":"Mi","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ming-Ming","surname":"Zhou","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1155/2020/8715756","date":"2020-11-13","title":"Detection of Viruses by Multiplex Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction in Bronchoalveolar Lavage Fluid of Patients with Nonresponding Community-Acquired Pneumonia","abstract":"Background\n Nonresponding pneumonia is responsible for the most mortality of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).\n\n However, thus far, it is not clear whether viral infection plays an important role in the etiology of nonresponding CAP and whether there is a significant difference in the clinical characteristics between viral and nonviral nonresponding CAP.\n\n \nMethods\n From 2016 to 2019, nonresponding CAP patients were retrospectively enrolled in our study.\n\n All patients received bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) and virus detection in BAL fluid by multiplex real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR), and clinical, laboratory, and radiographic data were collected.\n\n \nResults\n A total of 43 patients were included.\n\n The median age was 62 years, and 65.1% of patients were male.\n\n Overall, 20 patients (46.5%) were identified with viral infection.\n\n Of these viruses, influenza virus (n?=?8) and adenovirus (n?=?7) were more frequently detected, and others included herpes simplex virus, human enterovirus, cytomegalovirus, human coronavirus 229E, rhinovirus, and parainfluenza virus.\n\n Compared with nonviral nonresponding CAP, only ground-glass opacity combined with consolidation was a more common imaging manifestation in viral nonresponding CAP.\n\n However, no obvious differences were found in clinical and laboratory findings between the presence and the absence of viral infections.\n\n \nConclusions\n Viral infections were particularly frequent in adults with nonresponding CAP.\n\n The ground-glass opacity combined with consolidation was a specific imaging manifestation for viral nonresponding CAP, while the clinical and laboratory data showed no obvious differences between viral and nonviral nonresponding resistant bacteria or fungi may increase the risk of invasive infections in hospitalized children and are difficult to treat in intensive care units.\n The purpose of this study was to use metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to understand the bloodstream microbiomes of children with suspected sepsis in a pediatric intensive care unit (PICU).\n mNGS were performed on microbial cell-free nucleic acid from 34 children admitted to PICU, and potentially pathogenic microbes were identified.\n The associations of serological inflammation indicators, lymphocyte subpopulations, and other clinical phenotypes were also examined.\n mNGS of blood samples from children in PICU revealed potential eukaryotic microbial pathogens.\n The abundance of Pneumocystis jirovecii was positively correlated with a decrease in total white blood cell count and immunodeficiency.\n Hospital-acquired pneumonia patients showed a significant increase in blood bacterial species richness compared with community-acquired pneumonia children.\n The abundance of bloodstream bacteria was positively correlated with serum procalcitonin level.\n Microbial genome sequences from potential pathogens were metagenomics","abstract":"id='Par1'>Clinical metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS), the comprehensive analysis of microbial and host genetic material (DNA and RNA) in samples from patients, is rapidly moving from research to clinical laboratories.\n This emerging approach is changing how physicians diagnose and treat infectious disease, with applications spanning a wide range of areas, including antimicrobial resistance, the microbiome, human host gene expression (transcriptomics) and oncology.\n Here, we focus on the challenges of implementing mNGS in the clinical laboratory and address potential solutions for maximizing its impact on patient care and public health.\n","id":"PMC6858796","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Charles Y.","surname":"Chiu","email":"charles.chiu@ucsf.edu","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Steven A.","surname":"Miller","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Steven A.","surname":"Miller","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1101/gr.238170.118","date":"2019-02-25","title":"Laboratory validation of a clinical metagenomic sequencing assay for pathogen detection in cerebrospinal fluid","abstract":"Metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) for pan-pathogen detection has been successfully tested in proof-of-concept case studies in patients with acute illness of unknown etiology but to date has been largely confined to research settings.\n Here, we developed and validated a clinical mNGS assay for diagnosis of infectious causes of meningitis and encephalitis from cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in a licensed microbiology laboratory.\n A customized bioinformatics pipeline, SURPI+, was developed to rapidly analyze mNGS data, generate an automated summary of detected pathogens, and provide a graphical user interface for evaluating and interpreting results.\n We established quality metrics, threshold values, and limits of detection of 0.2–313 genomic copies or colony forming units per milliliter for each representative organism type.\n Gross hemolysis and excess host nucleic acid reduced assay sensitivity; however, spiked phages used as internal controls were reliable indicators of sensitivity loss.\n Diagnostic test accuracy was evaluated by blinded mNGS testing of 95 patient samples, revealing 73% sensitivity and 99% specificity compared to original clinical test results, and 81% positive percent agreement and 99% negative percent agreement after discrepancy analysis.\n Subsequent mNGS challenge testing of 20 positive CSF samples prospectively collected from a cohort of pediatric patients hospitalized with meningitis, encephalitis, and/or myelitis showed 92% sensitivity and 96% specificity relative to conventional microbiological testing of CSF in identifying the causative pathogen.\n These results demonstrate the analytic performance of a laboratory-validated mNGS assay for pan-pathogen detection, to be used clinically for diagnosis of neurological infections from CSF.\n","id":"PMC6499319","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Steve","surname":"Miller","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Samia Report: Metagenomic Next-Generation Sequencing Confirmed a Case of Central Nervous System Infection With <italic toggle='yes'>Brucella melitensis</italic> in Non-endemic Areas","abstract":"Brucellosis is a highly contagious zoonotic disease caused by bacteria that belong to the genus Brucella.\n It is a major endemic disease in northern China.\n We reported a rare case of central nervous system (CNS) infection caused by Brucella melitensis in a patient living in non-endemic areas.\n The medical history of the patient included chronic headache and trunk numbness.\n Based on the presented clinical symptoms and medical examinations, a clinical diagnosis of binocular uveo-encephalitis was made in the local hospital.\n The patient's symptoms were unrelieved after being treated with empiric therapy.\n Soon after, the patient was admitted to our hospital because of the obnubilation and coma in the trip.\n We ran a few examinations and sent the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) for metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) immediately.\n The Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) examination was unremarkable, and bilateral mastoid inflammation was attached.\n Metagenomic next-generation sequencing suggested a CNS infection caused by Brucella melitensis.\n Then, the results of the serum agglutination test and quantitative polymerase chain reaction assay also confirmed that.\n After being treated with doxycycline, rifampin, and cefatriaxone, consciousness of the patient was restored and headache diminished.\n Two months later, a lumbar puncture was used to check the pressure of the CSF, and the total course of treatment was more than 6 months.\n This case highlighted the potential value of mNGS in early clinal diagnosis.\n We believe that mNGS may be a complementary method for rapid identification of infection of CNS caused by the of Metagenomic Next-Generation Sequencing in the Diagnosis of Pulmonary Infectious Pathogens From Bronchoalveolar Lavage Samples","abstract":"Background\nMetagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a powerful method for pathogen detection.\n\n In this study, we assessed the value of mNGS for bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) samples in the diagnosis of pulmonary infections.\n\n\nMethods\nFrom February 2018 to April 2019, BAL samples were collected from 235 patients with suspected pulmonary infections.\n\n mNGS and microbial culture were performed to evaluate the effectiveness of mNGS in pulmonary infection diagnosis.\n\n\nResults\nWe employed mNGS to evaluate the alpha diversity, results suggesting that patients with confirmed pathogens had a lower microbial diversity index compared to that of patients with uncertain pathogens.\n\n For the patients admitted to the respiratory intensive care unit (RICU) or on a ventilator, they experienced a lower diversity index than that of the patients in the general ward or not on a ventilator.\n\n In addition, mNGS of BAL had a diagnostic sensitivity of 88.89% and a specificity of 14.86% in pulmonary infection, with 21.16% positive predictive value (PPV) and 83.87% negative predictive value (NPV).\n\n When rare pathogens were excluded, the sensitivity of mNGS decreased to 73.33%, and the specificity increased to 41.71%.\n\n For patients in the simple pulmonary infection group and the immunocompromised group, the main infection types were bacterial infection (58.33%) and mixed-infection (43.18%).\n\n Furthermore, mNGS had an advantage over culture in describing polymicrobial ecosystem, demonstrating the microbial distribution and the dominant strains of the respiratory tract in patients with different underlying diseases.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe study indicated that mNGS of BAL samples could provide more accurate diagnostic information in pulmonary infections and demonstrate the changes of respiratory microbiome in different underlying diseases.\n\n This method might play an important role in the clinical use of antimicrobial agents in the future.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7991794","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Yuqian","surname":"Chen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wei","surname":"Feng","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kai","surname":"Ye","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Li","surname":"Guo","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Han","surname":"Xia","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yuanlin","surname":"Guan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Limin","surname":"Chai","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wenhua","surname":"Shi","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Cui","surname":"Zhai","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jian","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xin","surname":"Yan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Qingting","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Qianqian","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Cong","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Pengtao","surname":"Liu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Manxiang","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.2147/IDR.S365757","date":"2022-05-27","title":"Clinical Application and Evaluation of Metagenomic Next-Generation Sequencing in Pulmonary Infection with Pleural Effusion","abstract":"Purpose\nMetagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a novel technique of pathogens detection that plays an increasingly important role in clinical practice.\n\n In this study, we explored the application value of mNGS in pulmonary infection combined with pleural effusion applied to samples of pleural effusion fluid.\n\n\nPatients and Methods\nWe reviewed 80 cases of pulmonary infection with pleural effusion between August 2020 and October 2021. Among them, 40 patients were placed in the mNGS group and underwent both culture and mNGS testing; the patients in the control group were only subjected to culture test.\n\n The effectiveness of mNGS was evaluated for microbial composition and diagnostic accuracy in every pleural effusion specimen type.\n\n\nResults\nWe found that the positive rate of mNGS was 70% (28/40).\n\n The comparison between mNGS and culture method resulted that the sensitivity was 100% (95% CI: 29.2–100%) and the specificity was 64.9% (95% CI: 47.5–79.8%).\n\n The positive predictive value of mNGS was 18.8% (95% CI, 13.0–26.3%), and the negative predictive value was 100%.\n\n The most commonly identified potential pathogens were bacteria, such as Streptococcus, Prevotella, Parvimonas, Porphyromonas and Gemella.\n\n The most detected fungal infection was Candida and Pneumocystis.\n\n A total of 11 patients were identified as mixed infection by mNGS.\n\n Treatment regimen adjustments were made according to mNGS results and the overall length of hospital stay in the mNGS group was shorter compared to that of the control group.\n\n\nConclusion\nIn this study, mNGS produced higher positive rates than the culture method in detecting pathogens in the pleural effusion specimens.\n\n The technology performed satisfactorily, providing more diagnostic evidence and reducing the length of hospital stay.\n\n\n","id":"PMC9167844","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Huifen","surname":"Xu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xiaoman","surname":"Hu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wenyu","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hong","surname":"Chen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Fangfei","surname":"Yu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xiaofei","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Weili","surname":"Zheng","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Kaiyu","surname":"Han","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.2147/IDR.S385925","date":"2022-10-27","title":"Analysis of Metagenomic Next-Generation Sequencing Results of 25 Pus Samples","abstract":"Purpose\nTo explore the clinical value of detecting pathogens in pus samples by metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS).\n\n\nMethods\nThe 25 pus samples from infected patients were collected in this research.\n\n The positive rate and consistency of pathogenic bacteria detected by mNGS and conventional methods were compared.\n\n The pathogen types detected by the two methods were analyzed.\n\n Furthermore, the modifications of antibiotic treatment therapy were also evaluated based on mNGS results.\n\n\nResults\nThe sensitivity of mNGS method in detecting pathogenic bacteria in pus samples was better than that of conventional method (96% vs 40%; P &lt; 0.01).\n\n Only 10 samples were detected pathogens by conventional methods, but 24 samples were detected by mNGS method.\n\n In specific, the results of conventional methods showed 10 samples had 11 kinds of pathogenic bacteria, of which 9 samples were single pathogen and 1 sample had two kinds of pathogenic bacteria.\n\n The results of mNGS method showed 24 samples were detected with 54 kinds of pathogenic bacteria, of which 15 samples were detected with single pathogen, and 9 samples were detected with two or more kinds of pathogenic bacteria.\n\n The two methods had 9(36%) consistent results, 14 (56%) completely different results, and 2 (8%) partially consistent results, and the kappa value was 0.19. Notably, mNGS could detect viruses, anaerobic bacteria, and other uncommon pathogens simultaneously.\n\n\nConclusion\nThe application of mNGS in the detection of pus specimens from different parts not only have high accuracy rate and also reduce the turnaround time of diagnosis.\n\n In addition, the performance of mNGS detection of anaerobic bacteria and caustic bacteria is better than conventional methods.\n\n The mNGS diagnosis in pus sample may play an important role in clinical diagnosis and treatment strategy diagnostic performance of metagenomic next-generation sequencing when applied to clinical practice","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1128/spectrum.01488-22","date":"2022-09-12","title":"Application of Metagenomic Next-Generation Sequencing (mNGS) Using Bronchoalveolar Lavage Fluid (BALF) in Diagnosing Pneumonia of Children","abstract":"Pneumonia is the leading cause of death in children; the pathogens are often difficult to diagnose.\n In this study, the performance of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) using bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) samples from 112 children with confirmed pneumonia has been evaluated.\n mNGS performed a significantly higher positive detection rate (91.07%, 95% confidence interval [CI] 83.80% to 95.40%) and coincidence rate against the final diagnosis (72.32%, 95% CI 62.93% to 80.15%) than that of conventional methods (70.54%, 95% CI 61.06% to 78.58% and 56.25%, 95% CI 46.57% to 65.50%, respectively) (P &lt; 0.01 and P &lt; 0.05, respectively).\n Bacteria, viruses, and their mixed infections were common in children with pneumonia.\n Streptococcus pneumoniae was the most common bacterial pathogen in children with pneumonia, while Haemophilus parainfluenzae and Haemophilus influenzae seemed more likely to cause nonsevere pneumonia in children.\n In contrast, human cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection and the simultaneous bacterial infections could cause severe pneumonia, especially in children with underlying diseases.\n After adjustments of antibiotics based on mNGS and conventional methods, the conditions improved in 109 (97.32%) children.\n mNGS of BALF samples has shown great advantages in diagnosing the pathogenic etiology of pneumonia in children, especially when considering the limited volumes of BALF and the previous use of empirical antibiotics, contributing to the timely adjustment of antibiotic treatments, which can potentially improve the prognosis and decrease the mortality.\n","id":"PMC9603332","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Aimei","surname":"Yang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Chen","surname":"Chen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yan","surname":"Hu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Guilang","surname":"Zheng","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Peiling","surname":"Chen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Zhiwei","surname":"Xie","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Huifeng","surname":"Fan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yueyu","surname":"Sun","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Peiqiong","surname":"Wu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wenhui","surname":"Jiang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Chun","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jingwen","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Dongwei","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jing","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xiaoyin","surname":"Hu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Han","surname":"Xia","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Genquan","surname":"Yin","email":"yingenquan@126.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yuxiong","surname":"Guo","email":"2003kellylaw@163.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Eleanor A.","surname":"Powell","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Eleanor A.","surname":"Powell","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3389/fcimb.2020.567615","date":"2020-12-04","title":"Improving Pulmonary Infection Diagnosis with Metagenomic Next Generation Sequencing","abstract":"Pulmonary infections are among the most common and important infectious diseases due to their high morbidity and mortality, especially in older and immunocompromised individuals.\n However, due to the limitations in sensitivity and the long turn-around time (TAT) of conventional diagnostic methods, pathogen detection and identification methods for pulmonary infection with greater diagnostic efficiency are urgently needed.\n In recent years, unbiased metagenomic next generation sequencing (mNGS) has been widely used to detect different types of infectious pathogens, and is especially useful for the detection of rare and newly emergent pathogens, showing better diagnostic performance than traditional methods.\n There has been limited research exploring the application of mNGS for the diagnosis of pulmonary infections.\n In this study we evaluated the diagnostic efficiency and clinical impact of mNGS on pulmonary infections.\n A total of 100 respiratory samples were collected from patients diagnosed with pulmonary infection in Shanghai, China.\n Conventional methods, including culture and standard polymerase chain reaction (PCR) panel analysis for respiratory tract viruses, and mNGS were used for the pathogen detection in respiratory samples.\n The difference in the diagnostic yield between conventional methods and mNGS demonstrated that mNGS had higher sensitivity than traditional culture for the detection of pathogenic bacteria and fungi (95% vs 54%; p&lt;0.001).\n Although mNGS had lower sensitivity than PCR for diagnosing viral infections, it identified 14 viral species that were not detected using conventional methods, including multiple subtypes of human herpesvirus.\n mNGS detected viruses with a genome coverage &gt;95% and a sequencing depth &gt;100× and provided reliable phylogenetic and epidemiological information.\n mNGS offered extra benefits, including a shorter TAT.\n As a complementary approach to conventional methods, mNGS could help improving the identification of respiratory infection agents.\n We recommend the timely use of mNGS when infection of mixed or rare pathogens is suspected, especially in immunocompromised individuals and or individuals with severe conditions that require urgent treatment.\n","id":"PMC7874146","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Yi-Yi","surname":"Qian","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hong-Yu","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yang","surname":"Zhou","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hao-Cheng","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yi-Min","surname":"Zhu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xian","surname":"Zhou","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yue","surname":"Ying","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Peng","surname":"Cui","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hong-Long","surname":"Wu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wen-Hong","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jia-Lin","surname":"Jin","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jing-Wen","surname":"Ai","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12879-022-07381-8","date":"2022-04-13","title":"Diagnostic value of metagenomic next-generation sequencing of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid for the diagnosis of suspected pneumonia in immunocompromised patients","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>To evaluate the diagnostic value of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) in immunocompromised patients for the diagnosis of suspected pneumonia in comparison with that of conventional microbiological tests (CMTs).\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>Sixty-nine immunocompromised patients with suspected pneumonia received both CMTs and mNGS of BALF were analyzed retrospectively.\n\n The diagnostic value was compared between CMTs and mNGS, using the clinical composite diagnosis as the reference standard.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>Sixty patients were diagnosed of pneumonia including fifty-two patients with identified pathogens and eight patients with probable pathogens.\n\n Taking the composite reference standard as a gold standard, 42 pathogens were identified by CMTs including nine bacteria, 17 fungi, 8 virus, 6 Mycobacterium Tuberculosis, and two Legionella and 19(45%) of which were detected by BALF culture.\n\n As for mNGS, it identified 76 pathogens including 20 bacteria, 31 fungi, 14 virus, 5 Mycobacterium Tuberculosis, four Legionella and two Chlamydia psittaci.\n\n The overall detection rate of mNGS for pathogens were higher than that of CMTs.\n\n However, a comparable diagnostic accuracy of mNGS and CMTs were found for bacterial and viral infections.\n\n mNGS exhibited a higher diagnostic accuracy for fungal detection than CMTs (78% vs.\n\n 57%, P?&lt;?0.05), which mainly because of the high sensitivity of mNGS in patients with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) (100% vs.\n\n 28%, P?&lt;?0.05).\n\n Nineteen patients were identified as pulmonary co-infection, mNGS test showed a higher detection rate and broader spectrum for pathogen detection than that of CMTs in co-infection.\n\n Moreover, Pneumocystis jirovecii was the most common pathogen in co-infection and mNGS have identified much more co-pathogens of PJP than CMTs.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>mNGS of BALF improved the microbial detection rate of pathogens and exhibited remarkable advantages in detecting PJP and identifying co-infection in immunocompromised patients.\n\n\nSupplementary Information\nThe online version contains supplementary material available at the Leap from Research Laboratory to Clinic: Challenges and Opportunities for Next-Generation Sequencing in Infectious Disease Diagnostics","abstract":"Next-generation DNA sequencing (NGS) has progressed enormously over the past decade, transforming genomic analysis and opening up many new opportunities for applications in clinical microbiology laboratories.\n The impact of NGS on microbiology has been revolutionary, with new microbial genomic sequences being generated daily, leading to the development of large databases of genomes and gene sequences.\n The ability to analyze microbial communities without culturing organisms has created the ever-growing field of metagenomics and microbiome analysis and has generated significant new insights into the relation between host and microbe.\n The medical literature contains many examples of how this new technology can be used for infectious disease diagnostics and pathogen analysis.\n The implementation of NGS in medical practice has been a slow process due to various challenges such as clinical trials, lack of applicable regulatory guidelines, and the adaptation of the technology to the clinical environment.\n In April 2015, the American Academy of Microbiology (AAM) convened a colloquium to begin to define these issues, and in this document, we present some of the concepts that were generated from these discussions.\n","id":"PMC4669390","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Brittany","surname":"Goldberg","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Heike","surname":"Sichtig","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Chelsie","surname":"Geyer","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Nathan","surname":"Ledeboer","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"George M.","surname":"Weinstock","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.2147/IDR.S364525","date":"2022-06-30","title":"The Value of Metagenomic Next-Generation Sequencing in Hematological Malignancy Patients with Febrile Neutropenia After Empiric Antibiotic Treatment Failure","abstract":"Background\nIt was crucial to use empirical antibiotics in febrile neutropenia (FN) patients.\n\n However, most patients still died from infection due to poor efficacy.\n\n Metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a rapid microbiological diagnostic method.\n\n The value of mNGS in patients with FN remains to be studied, especially after empiric antibiotic treatment.\n\n\nMethods\nWe retrospectively analyzed the differences between mNGS and the traditional methods in 192 patients with hematological malignancies who have received empiric antibiotic treatment.\n\n Samples were collected when patient had chills or half an hour before peak body temperature.\n\n And we compared the differences between FN and non-FN patients, mainly including types of pathogens and the diagnostic value of different pathogens.\n\n\nResults\nDespite receiving empirical treatment, the pathogen detection rate of mNGS was significantly higher than the traditional method (80.21% vs 25.00%, P&lt;0.001).\n\n And it has obvious advantages in detecting mixed pathogens infection (80.21% vs 4.17%, P&lt;0.001).\n\n Then, we found that mNGS saw more pathogens in the FN than in the non-FN group, especially fungus.\n\n 21/33 (63.63%) of FN patients was diagnosed with fungal infections.\n\n The fungal detection rate in FN was significantly higher than non-FN group (32.35% vs 12.22%, P=0.001).\n\n Besides, the sensitivity of mNGS was higher than the traditional methods in both FN and non-FN group (P&lt;0.001), but no significant difference in specificity (P&gt;0.05).\n\n In the FN group, empiric antibiotic treatment of 46/102 (45.10%) patients did not treat all the pathogens detected by mNGS.\n\n After adjusting the antimicrobial regimen according to the results of mNGS, the effective rate at 72 hours and 7 days was 22/46 (47.83%) and 24/102 (52.17%), respectively.\n\n\nConclusion\nmNGS had a significant impact on the diagnosis of infection and the second-line antimicrobial therapy in FN.\n\n mNGS plays a more important role in FN patients, especially in the diagnosis of fungal infections.\n\n\nPurpose\nFirstly, we compared the difference between mNGS and the traditional methods in the diagnosis of infection.\n\n Secondly, we assessed the value of mNGS in FN patients by comparing it with non-FN patients, including types of pathogens and the diagnostic value of different pathogens.\n\n In order to show that mNGS plays a more important role in found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.2147/IDR.S370964","date":"2022-10-11","title":"The Comparison of Metagenomic Next-Generation Sequencing with Conventional Microbiological Tests for Identification of Pathogens and Antibiotic Resistance Genes in Infectious Diseases","abstract":"Background\nMetagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) has been widely studied, due to its ability of detecting all the microbial genetic information unbiasedly in a sample at one time and not relying on traditional culture.\n\n However, the application of mNGS in the diagnosis of clinical pathogens remains challenging.\n\n\nMethods\nFrom December 2019 to March 2021, 134 specimens including Broncho alveolar lavage fluid (BAFL), blood, sputum, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), bile, pleural fluid, pus, were continuously collected in The First Hospital of Qinhuangdao, and their retrospective diagnoses were classified into infectious disease (128, 95.5%) and noninfectious disease (6, 4.5%).\n\n The pathogen-detection performance of mNGS was compared with conventional microbiological tests (CMT) and culture method.\n\n In addition, the antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) and evolutionary relationship of common drug-resistant A.\n\n baumannii were also analyzed.\n\n\nResults\nCompared with CMT and culture methods, mNGS showed higher sensitivity in pathogen detection (74.2% vs 57.8%; P &lt; 0.001 and 66.3% vs 31.7%; P &lt; 0.001, respectively).\n\n Importantly, for cases that mNGS-positive only, 18 (35%) cases result in diagnosis modification, and 7 (23%) cases confirmed the clinical diagnosis.\n\n In 17 cases that A.\n\n baumannii were both detected in mNGS and culture, ade genes were the most frequently detected ARGs (from 13 cases), followed by sul2 and APH(3”)-Ib (both from 12 cases).\n\n High consistency was observed among these ARGs and the related phenotype (100% for ade genes, 91.6% for sul2 and APH(3”)-Ib).\n\n A.\n\n baumannii strains were classified into three groups, and most were well-clustered.\n\n It suggested those strains may be the epidemic strains.\n\n\nConclusion\nIn our study, mNGS had a higher next-generation sequencing for mixed pulmonary infection diagnosis","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is emerging as a promising technique for pathogens detection.\n\n However, reports on the application of mNGS in mixed pulmonary infection remain scarce.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>From July 2018 to March 2019, 55 cases were enrolled in this retrospective analysis.\n\n Cases were classified into mixed pulmonary infection (36 [65.5%]) and non-mixed pulmonary infection (19 [34.5%]) according to primary diagnoses.\n\n The performances of mNGS and conventional test on mixed pulmonary infection diagnosis and pathogen identification were compared.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>The sensitivity of mNGS in mixed pulmonary infection diagnosis was much higher than that of conventional test (97.2% vs 13.9%; P?&lt; 0.01), but the specificity was the opposite (63.2% vs 94.7%; P?= 0.07).\n\n The positive predictive value of mNGS was 83.3% (95% CI, 68.0–92.5%), and the negative predictive value was 92.3% (95% CI, 62.1–99.6%).\n\n A total of 5 (9.1%) cases were identified as mixed pulmonary infection by both conventional tests and mNGS, however, the pathogens identification results were consistent between these two methods in only 1 (1.8%) case.\n\n In summary, the pathogens detected by mNGS in 3 (5.5%) cases were consistent with those by conventional test, and only 1 (1.8%) case was mixed pulmonary infection.\n\n According to our data, mNGS had a broader spectrum for pathogen detection than conventional tests.\n\n In particular, application of mNGS improved the diagnosis of pulmonary fungal infections.\n\n Within the 55 cases, mNGS detected and identified fungi in 31 (56.4%) cases, of which only 10 (18.2%) cases were positive for the same fungi by conventional test.\n\n The most common pathogen detected by mNGS was Human cytomegalovirus in our study, which was identified in 19 (34.5%) cases of mixed pulmonary infection.\n\n Human cytomegalovirus and Pneumocystis jirovecii, which were detected in 7 (12.7%) cases, were the most common co-pathogens in the group of mixed pulmonary infection.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>mNGS is a promising technique to detect co-pathogens in mixed pulmonary infection, with potential benefits in speed and sensitivity.\n\n\nTrial Next-Generation Sequencing versus Traditional Pathogen Detection in the Diagnosis of Peripheral Pulmonary Infectious Lesions","abstract":"Purpose\nThe aim of this study was to evaluate the value of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) in peripheral pulmonary infection management by comparing the diagnostic yield of mNGS and traditional pathogen detection methods on interventional specimens obtained by bronchoscopy.\n\n\nPatients and Methods\nThis study enrolled patients suspected with pulmonary infection who were admitted to Tianjin Medical University General Hospital from June 2018 to August 2019. Specimens were obtained from bronchoscopy for mNGS analysis and traditional pathogen detection (including bronchoalveolar lavage fluid microbial culture, smear microscopy, and lung biopsy histopathology), and the diagnostic yields were compared between mNGS and traditional methods to evaluate the diagnostic value of mNGS in peripheral pulmonary infection diagnosis.\n\n\nResults\nIn this study, by comparing mNGS with traditional pathogen detection, the results indicated that, first, mNGS identified at least one microbial species in almost 89% of the patients with pulmonary infection; second, mNGS detected microbes related to human diseases in 94.49% of samples from pulmonary infection patients who had received negative results from traditional pathogen detection; third, the accuracy and sensitivity of mNGS are higher than those of traditional pathogen detection; and, finally, mNGS could simultaneously detect and identify a large variety of pathogens.\n\n\nConclusion\nMetagenomic NGS analysis provided fast and precise pathogen detection and identification, contributing to prompt and accurate treatment of peripheral pulmonary infection.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7036976","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Jie","surname":"Huang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Erlie","surname":"Jiang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Donglin","surname":"Yang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jialin","surname":"Wei","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jialin","surname":"Wei","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Mingfeng","surname":"Zhao","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jing","surname":"Feng","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jie","surname":"Cao","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1186/s12879-020-05746-5","date":"2020-12-27","title":"The diagnostic value of metagenomic next?generation sequencing in infectious diseases","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Although traditional diagnostic techniques of infection are mature and price favorable at present, most of them are time-consuming and with a low positivity.\n\n Metagenomic next?generation sequencing (mNGS) was studied widely because of identification and typing of all pathogens not rely on culture and retrieving all DNA without bias.\n\n Based on this background, we aim to detect the difference between mNGS and traditional culture method, and to explore the relationship between mNGS results and the severity, prognosis of infectious patients.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>109 adult patients were enrolled in our study in Shanghai Tenth People’s Hospital from October 2018 to December 2019. The diagnostic results, negative predictive values, positive predictive values, false positive rate, false negative rate, pathogen and sample types were analyzed by using both traditional culture and mNGS methods.\n\n Then, the samples and clinical information of 93 patients in the infected group (ID) were collected.\n\n According to whether mNGS detected pathogens, the patients in ID group were divided into the positive group of 67 cases and the negative group of 26 cases.\n\n Peripheral blood leukocytes, C-reactive protein (CRP), procalcitonin (PCT) and neutrophil counts were measured, and the concentrations of IL-2, IL-4, IL-6, TNF-?, IL-17A, IL-10 and INF-? in the serum were determined by ELISA.\n\n The correlation between the positive detection of pathogens by mNGS and the severity of illness, hospitalization days, and mortality were analyzed.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>109 samples were assigned into infected group (ID, 92/109, 84.4%), non-infected group (NID, 16/109, 14.7%), and unknown group (1/109, 0.9%).\n\n Blood was the most abundant type of samples with 37 cases, followed by bronchoalveolar lavage fluid in 36 cases, tissue, sputum, pleural effusion, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), pus, bone marrow and nasal swab.\n\n In the ID group, the majority of patients were diagnosed with lower respiratory system infections (73/109, 67%), followed by bloodstream infections, pleural effusion and central nervous system infections.\n\n The sensitivity of mNGS was significantly higher than that of culture method (67.4% vs 23.6%; P?&lt;?0.001), especially in sample types of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (P?=?0.002), blood (P?&lt; 0.001) and sputum (P?=?0.037), while the specificity of mNGS was not significantly different from culture method (68.8% vs 81.3%; P?=?0.41).\n\n The number of hospitals stays and 28-day-motality in the positive mNGS group were significantly higher than those in the negative group, and the difference was statistically significant (P?&lt;?0.05).\n\n Age was significant in multivariate logistic analyses of positive results of mNGS.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>The study found that mNGS had a higher sensitivity than the traditional method, especially in blood, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid and sputum samples.\n\n And positive mNGS group had a higher hospital stay, 28-day-mortality, which means the positive of pathogen nucleic acid sequences detection may be a potential high-risk factor for poor prognosis of adult patients and has significant clinical value.\n\n MNGS should be used more in early pathogen diagnosis in the future.\n\n\n","id":"PMC7805029","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"","authors":[{"firstname":"Hongxia","surname":"Duan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xuan","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Aihong","surname":"Mei","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ping","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yang","surname":"Liu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xiaofeng","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Weiwei","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Changhui","surname":"Wang","email":"wang-chang-hui@hotmail.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Shuanshuan","surname":"Xie","email":"xieshuanshuan@aliyun.com","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Shuanshuan","surname":"Xie","email":"xieshuanshuan@aliyun.com","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3389/fmicb.2022.868160","date":"2022-03-21","title":"Metagenomic Next-Generation Sequencing vs. Traditional Pathogen Detection in the Diagnosis of Infection After Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation in Children","abstract":"Infection is a severe complication of allo-HSCT in children, however, the accurate detection of the infection is hard.\n In this study, we traced the records of 101 pediatric recipients with allo-HSCT to investigate the pathogens of infection, and collected 54 bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, 32 blood, and 15 cerebrospinal fluid samples.\n In these samples, 87 was with post-transplant infection and 14 without infection.\n Using the metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) and traditional pathogen detection, we compared their sensitivity and specificity to detect pathogens of infection.\n Our results showed that mNGS was more sensitive (89.7%) than conventional pathogen detection (21.8%), with a difference of 67.9% (P &lt; 0.001), However, mNGS was less specific (78.5%) than traditional methods (92.9%), with a difference of 14.4% (P = 0.596).\n The sensitivity of mNGS for diagnosing pulmonary infections, bloodstream infections or viremia, and CNS infections post-transplant were 91.7, 85.7, and 90.9%, respectively.\n In contrast, the sensitivity of conventional testing for diagnosing pulmonary infections, bloodstream infections or viremia, and CNS infections post-transplant were 22.9, 21.4, and 18.2%, respectively.\n There were significant differences in the sensitivity of mNGS and conventional testing in BALF, blood, and CSF samples, with P values of 0.000, 0.000, and 0.002 respectively.\n Among the patients with pulmonary infection, 11 pathogens were both identified by mNGS and conventional testing, and 33 by mNGS only.\n The percentage with the mNGS-positive result was 44/48 (91.7%), including viruses (n = 12), bacteria (n = 17), fungi (n = 9) and mixed infections (n = 6).\n Among the patients diagnosed with fungal pneumonia (n = 9), the most prevalent pathogenic fungi were Pneumocystis jiroveci (n = 6), which were also detected in 4 patients with mixed infectious pneumonia.\n In the 28 blood specimens of patients with bloodstream infections or viremia, five patients were positive by both mNGS and conventional testing, 19 were positive by mNGS, and 1 was positive by traditional testing only.\n The percentage with the mNGS-positive results was 24/28 (85.7%), including viruses (n = 12), bacteria (n = 4), fungi (n = 3), and mixed infections (n = 5).\n Of the 15 CSF specimens enrolled, 11 patients were eventually diagnosed with CNS infections.\n Ten pathogens were identified by mNGS in the 11 patients, including viruses (n = 8), bacteria (n = 1), and fungi (n = 1).\n These results suggest that mNGS is more sensitive than conventional pathogen
